If we are to have an intelligent debate about Aboriginal affairs, it ought to focus on issues like that and not be distracted as to who is taking the most morally superior position when it comes to responses to Mabo or responses to the land fund. We can talk for days, for weeks, indeed months, about that and if, as a consequence, the most wretched amongst our number are not advanced or not promoted—
Mr Dodd interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —We hear lots of speeches about how every so often those who represent the people of Australia in this building ought to look beyond the short-term political point or the political advantage. We have done that. We are acknowledging that, if the deadlock continues, you opposite will not suffer and we over here will not suffer; but the people the land fund is meant to develop will suffer. We are not going to be a party to that. We are, therefore, going to take the course of action that I have indicated.

PARA.TAB: I want to make it clear to those who sit opposite that they do not have a mortgage on compassion. As my colleague the honourable member for Chisholm (Dr Wooldridge), the shadow minister for health, said yesterday, it is not a problem that additional dollars alone can solve although, obviously, financial provision is tremendously important. It goes to a lot of other things as well. There is an obligation on all of us to address those other things, but addressing those other things has to occur within a number of important guidelines and understandings.

One of those guidelines and understandings so far as the coalition is concerned now, and will always be so far as the Liberal and National parties are concerned, is that Aboriginal affairs has to be addressed within the concept of a single, undivided nation of which all Australians, whether indigenous Australians or other Australians, are treated equally, governed by a common set of laws to which all of us are equally accountable and governed by a number of common values and common principles as Australian citizens. It will never be part of the policy of the Liberal and National parties to see the development of Aboriginal affairs policy within the concept of the tribalisation or fragmentation of this nation. We are one people and one nation, with one future, and one common obligation to treat each of us with dignity and respect.

I hope that the debate on Aboriginal affairs from now on will focus on policies and measures that improve the dignity, the independence, the lifestyle, the health, the education, the employment prospects and the family stability of Australia's Aborigines. It ought not to be distracted by arguments as to who is more compassionate. It ought not to be distracted by challengeable concepts of intergenerational guilt. Of course injustices were done to the original people, but those injustices were not committed by current generations of Australians and, so far as I am concerned, I am not going to be a party to the guilt industry, but I am going to be a party to—
Mr Tickner interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad the minister says he is not a party to the guilt industry. I am delighted to hear that, and I hope his acknowledgment is recorded. What this parliament has to do is to embrace commonsense, contemporary policies to improve the conditions of Aborigines—to improve their self-respect, their independence and their self-reliance. Those policies have to be developed not within the context of notions of intergenerational guilt and not within the context of the fragmentation of this country but within the context of the unity of this country under a common set of Australian values and a common body of law.

PARA.TAB: Finally, what the coalition has decided to do on this legislation is against a background of press comment about a double dissolution. I would love to have an election at the present time, and all of my colleagues over here would love to have an election at the present time. The only people who do not want to have an election at the present time are those who sit opposite. So this decision taken by the coalition has nothing at all to do with question of the timing of elections. We would love to have an election.

If the Prime Minister wants to have an election on this or indeed any other issue he only has to hop in that flagless white car of his and go out to Yarralumla and advise the Governor-General to grant him a double dissolution. This decision has absolutely nothing to do with that. This decision has been taken by us because we believe that, given that there is a clear deadlock between the two houses of parliament, the people who will suffer from that deadlock will be the Aboriginal community of Australia. In those circumstances, the sensible, proper thing to do, having regard to the interests of the Aboriginal community of Australia, is to do what the coalition has resolved to do.

We will maintain, by voting against the minister's motion, a demonstration of support for the Senate amendments. But when the bill introduced by the Prime Minister comes on for debate next week, we will not vote against that legislation in either the House of Representatives or the Senate. Upon the election of a Howard-Fischer government, whenever that occurs, we will act to amend the land fund legislation to bring it into line with what has been passed by the Senate. In that fashion, we not only serve the interests of the Aboriginal community but we also produce better legislation and, most importantly, we return debate on Aboriginal affairs to areas of government accountability where it ought to be. We will also return the general political and economic debate of this community to the other failings of the government and all the other areas of government accountability.

If any members opposite imagine that the behaviour of the Prime Minister and the government over the past few days on this issue has been some kind of clever political tactic, I think they are sadly wrong. We will get the debate back to where you are weakest and, in the process, we will look after the interests of the Aboriginal community.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SNOWDON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased that the opposition has at last seen the importance of passing this piece of legislation, however disingenuous that support might be. To hear what the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) has said this morning must confirm in everyone's mind how disingenuous the opposition is in relation to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs—without question.

PARA.TAB: What these people have done today is to indicate to the parliament, to the people of Australia, that they are prepared to accept the proposals put forward by the government in the context of the land fund bill on the basis that when and if—in the very unlikely event—they be elected to government they will immediately move to amend the legislation in accordance with the principles of the amendments passed by the Senate. There, in its entirety, is the message to the Australian community. These people are absolutely disingenuous.

What is also interesting is that whilst the Leader of the Opposition has spoken about the need for a cohesive approach to this particular issue, an issue on which we join him—we would say there is a need for a cohesive approach, that we should have a national bipartisan approach to these issues—what he has demonstrated in his contribution is an absolute and fundamental misunderstanding about the thrust of the land fund bill. What he has done by supporting the proposals which have come from the Senate is to indicate absolutely that he has no idea about the importance of land and its relationship to Aboriginal people.

The Leader of the Opposition has entirely ignored the evidence put forward on any number of occasions by royal commissioners, Aboriginal leadership and politicians. The government has indicated in the Senate that so clearly is it committed to the idea of bipartisanship that it accepted 29 amendments proposed in that other place. But it has, quite rightly, chosen to reject what Senator Gareth Evans has called the seven deadly sins. It was the opposition leader's support of the seven deadly sins that should have us concerned and should be of concern to the whole community.

I want to refer to those points but before I do I want to make a general observation about the proposals in the opposition leader's speech on the One Nation concept—the idea that we are all governed by a common law. We all understand that; no-one questions it. But what we are arguing is that we need to deal specially and differently in some cases with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. They need to be given special recognition in law as a result of past injustices about which he spoke. We acknowledged their alienation from their land base by passing the Mabo legislation and, prior to that, the land rights legislation in the Northern Territory; and we are looking at this land fund bill and the social justice package.

We acknowledge the need to give Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people special treatment. We acknowledge the need to address special needs. We acknowledge the need to address the principles in Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander law. That is the difference. The relationship with land is integral and key to that. The Leader of the Opposition has also said the opposition is not about a guilt trip. No-one is; but he refers to the injustices of the past without acknowledging the injustices of the present. That is another key failing of his contribution and of the proposals which have been put by the opposition. He has a fundamental lack of understanding about the injustices to which Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people are subjected in this nation today.

The Leader of the Opposition has said he looks forward to a very good debate—and no doubt a volatile debate at times—about Aboriginal health and housing issues. He says that should be the primary debate. Let me just point out to him that, as we know, the government has already rejected the amendments in the Senate which refer to tying the proposals put forward in this legislation to the questions of disadvantage and health and housing.

I will go to comments by a member of the Liberal Party, a person who I understand is up for preselection for the Liberal Party, Dr Brendan Nelson. Dr Nelson, along with Barbara Flick, has published a document entitled Land, Rights, Laws: Issues of Native Title. In it, they talk about rights and entitlements. They have acknowledged the primacy of Aboriginal interest in land and the need to address that land issue quite separately but in conjunction with issues to deal with health and housing. They understand that, unless we address this land issue, the possibility of getting a fruitful outcome in health and education is more difficult. That goes to statements which have been made by various Aboriginal leaders over at least the history of Australia's occupation by non-Aboriginal people.

When I look at the contribution which the opposition leader has made I become alarmed that he has demonstrated no understanding of these things. If we are going to express bipartisan support, we must at least agree on the fundamentals. It is difficult to understand what fundamental agreements we might have, if we have a basic disagreement about the importance of land to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and the way it ought to be dealt with.

In talking about how land should be dealt with, I note that the opposition has said that it should be made available to individuals and trustees. I wonder why the opposition has not had the wisdom to read what the various reports, which have been presented to government over the last 20 years by learned people in the form of royal commissions—the Woodward commission, the Seaman inquiry for the Western Australian government—have said about the nature of land, land ownership and title. What all of them have done is reject the notion that land should be made available to an individual. In fact, they have said—as they have committed themselves to understanding the nature of Aboriginal association with land—that land ownership must be inalienable; it should not be sold; it should not be dealt with in a way in which non-Aboriginal people deal with land.

Land is fundamental to Aboriginal spirituality, yet it is something which the opposition will not understand. The opposition still purports to be dealing with the interests of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people—indeed the interests of the Australian community—by going down this path. It says that people should be able to deal with this land—which, after all, is recognition of their spiritual attachment—as if they were real estate agents. They are not real estate agents. I have lived and worked with Aboriginal people for many years and I have not heard one Aboriginal person put this view. We have had the land rights act operating in the Northern Territory since 1976—inalienable freehold title. Not one Aboriginal person that I have spoken to in the Northern Territory has put the view that they want individual ownership.

Then we have the position with regard to ATSIC. It is very important that we understand this. What the opposition is doing by taking the approach that it has taken thus far and by adopting the approach that the Leader of the Opposition has put forward this morning—that, in the unlikely event it were to get power, it would turn over this legislation—is absolutely pulling the rug from underneath any semblance of recognition of ATSIC and the authority it might have in the Aboriginal and Torres Straight Islander community. We should be very aware of the position of ATSIC. The ATSIC commissioners have made their position abundantly clear on numerous occasions. Lois O'Donoghue and Charlie Perkins have, at various times—

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—You laugh. What are you laughing at? That absolutely ignores the reality of what ATSIC does. It absolutely ignores the structures of ATSIC. I was at a regional council meeting of ATSIC last week in the Northern Territory. There was a group of representatives from across the top end of the Northern Territory, each one of them representing a view of their communities. They were a representative group. You might not like it, but they were representative. The fact is that ATSIC is representative. You don't like it, but it is. What you ought to do is acknowledge that and say that they do represent and speak on behalf of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.

PARA.TAB: There is no point taking this argument to the point of saying that because there are some administrative difficulties with ATSIC—and there may well be—you throw the baby out with the bathwater, which is what you have done. You do not acknowledge at all the role of the leadership in ATSIC as representing the general interests of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities across Australia.

The opposition should understand what it is doing. Not only are you disparaging this land fund bill; you are also disparaging the representative nature of ATSIC, the ATSIC commissioners and the prestige with which they are held in the Aboriginal community. This is what you are doing. We have the shadow spokesperson basically saying that ATSIC leadership does not consult and does not represent Aboriginal people. Is that not what you are saying? The ATSIC leadership has made it clear where they stand on the land fund bill. They have said to the government that they want this bill, not your bill, and you should support it. But what you are saying is that if you get into government you will totally undermine the basis of this legislation. How disingenuous are you?

The opposition has now felt the blowtorch to the belly and caved in. That is what this is about. As Senator Gareth Evans said last night, we have now achieved the result we wanted, because our primary objective was to get the land fund bill through. You would not have supported this land fund bill if you did not think there was going to be a double dissolution. That is very clear. The opposition leader almost said as much this morning.

I want to finish my contribution by saying to the House that this is a very important day for the Australian community. We have got the opposition falling to pieces, falling away, in terms of its attitude to the land fund bill in this parliament. But it is saying to the Australian community that, if and when it is elected, it will change this bill to reflect the hideous prospect which was proposed by the Senate. The only reason that they have come in here today to give in, if you like, is not, as the Leader of the Opposition says, the interests of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people; it is as a result of self-interest. That needs to be properly understood. Nevertheless, self-interest is a legitimate interest and we accept the support of the opposition on this piece of legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALKER.NAME: Mr TIM FISCHER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in support of the very statesmanlike comments made by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) with regard to this measure. I want to point out at the outset that we could have done better than have the comments which the member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon) has just made. He ignores, for example, the contribution of the New South Wales Land Council to this particular debate, which was strongly at variance with the view put by ATSIC. So there is a diversity of opinion amongst Aboriginals with regard to Labor's land fund legislation.

PARA.TAB: Mr Dodd interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —You might just spend a bit of time working on the problems of Kowanyama in your electorate and explain to them how the legislation before the House this day is going to lift equality of opportunity for education and the health and housing circumstances of the people of Kowanyama. Have you been to Kowanyama in the electorate of Leichhardt?
—Of course I have.
—I am pleased to see that you might have been there. It is a pity that you have not tried to rectify some of the tremendous problems that exist in that particular community.

PARA.TAB: We are considering this legislation on the eve of another major ruling by the full bench of the High Court of Australia in relation to Mabo. I think in November the High Court finally took oral evidence, and some additional evidence was given after that. I managed to sit in for some of the full bench hearings here in Canberra on the Western Australian legislation and, inter alia, the federal Mabo legislation. The High Court is about to revisit the Mabo issue for the first time since its original decision. I point out to the House that that may well have ramifications for the core Mabo issues. It may necessitate another Mabo bill of one kind or another coming forward from the government. However, that remains to be seen and I am certainly not categorical about that.

What I place on the public record is that, as we consider all the ramifications of the Mabo issue with regard to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and their health, education and housing circumstances, we need to be conscious of not only the parliamentary deliberation but also the fact that the High Court is about to revisit this issue. I understand that there will be a further ruling sometime between now and the end of April, at the latest.

The second point is that in government we will review the core aspects of Labor's land funding apparatus for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. I want to make it very clear that it would be part of our proper decision to relate the legislation to members of Aboriginal communities in very diverse circumstances. I quote in part from the report of the Senate Select Committee on the Land Fund Bill:
A corporation is not an appropriate vehicle for the management of modern [Aboriginal] communities. It is another imposed regime . . .

SPEECH.PARA: That evidence was taken from Rosemary O'Grady, the spokesperson of the Kamali people.

TALK.START.PARA: —She's a non-Aboriginal lawyer.
—But you will concede she was representing the Kamali people. I think that we ought to maintain a degree of reasonable standards associated with this debate, and I have always done so.

PARA.TAB: In that context, when we review this legislation in government we will look forward, hopefully, to the support of the Australian Democrats and the Greens (WA). Hopefully, better still, the votes will be such that we will have a working majority in both houses of parliament so that we can get this right in the interests of Aboriginal people, in the interests of Australia as a nation as a whole.

I praise the members of the committee and the senators who worked hard on this issue across the board. The committee was chaired by Senator Ian Campbell. In addition to the senators who were members of the committee, a senator for the Northern Territory, Senator Grant Tambling, and others certainly put in a huge amount of effort to bring forward responsible, reasonable amendments which have enjoyed a degree of support. I do not say more than that. I say that those amendments enjoyed a degree of support in the Aboriginal and Torres Strait community. Once in government, we will pursue those amendments and, indeed, will this day vote one more time for them in the deliberations of the House on this measure.
On the legal side, it is worthy of note by members of the public and others that this bill is back before the House this morning because of section 57 of the constitution, which states:
If the House of Representatives passes any proposed law, and the Senate rejects or fails to pass it, or passes it with amendments to which the House of Representatives will not agree . . .

SPEECH.PARA: It goes on from that point. Ultimately, late yesterday, the Senate passed the government's original land fund bill. The government construes that it was so amended that it did not constitute a passage of the government's original measure. But that has to be then tested on the floor of the House of Representatives today in accordance with section 57 of the constitution.

PARA.TAB: If we had taken a view otherwise, it might be said for the record that, in broad terms, the trigger mechanism would have commenced from this day. But we do have the other complexity of the government arguing that the 1951 convention applied. The government lost that argument—in fact, Minister Evans ran up the white flag on that particular argument last night when he conceded he was wrong in saying that the trigger started back on 28 November. There was a very good reason for saying that.

That 1951 convention involved a bill that was deadlocked between the House of Representatives and the Senate and was resubmitted after a three-month period. On the second time around, the Senate referred that particular banking legislation to a committee. At that time, Governor-General McKell construed that as a failure to pass on the second time around and the double dissolution then applied.On this occasion, the Senate is yet to deal with this legislation a second time around. For the benefit of clarification, that ought to be placed very clearly on the record of proceedings here today.

In many ways this is a very unsatisfactory circumstance. As we speak here today there is a degree of agony, a degree of absolute unacceptability with regard to the actual conditions that exist across Cape York, western New South Wales and the Northern Territory. I am pleased that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has come into the House because he went to Cape York, I think, last weekend and perhaps saw first-hand some of those conditions. But I am sorry that the Prime Minister did not go to Kowanyama and see the conditions there.

It takes a quantum leap of imagination to think that this particular measure will, within a short period of time, greatly improve the health, housing and educational circumstances of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders right across Australia. At the end of the day, that is what members on both sides of the House should be about, as those are the real issues of concern. The coalition has taken a very responsible position throughout the course of this debate for reasons that have been well stated by the Leader of the Opposition and, shortly, will be again by the shadow minister for Aboriginal affairs, the member for Hindmarsh (Mrs Gallus). At the end of the day, we will be quite properly reviewing this in government.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the government introduced the response to the High Court decision in relation to Mabo, it introduced a bill for an act to give meaning to the notion that there was a basis in the common law of Australia arising from Aboriginal custom and tradition to accept that there was a title available to those who maintain a traditional connection with the land, and to establish who was entitled to that land, how it would be allocated, how it would be decided and what those rights might be. It was thus a historic piece of property in cultural law.

PARA.TAB: At the time of its introduction the government made clear that though this established in law a very great principle it would apply to those people who were still able to establish a traditional connection with the land and it would not apply to those who had formerly been dispossessed. Hence we said in the response to the High Court decision, to make clear the government's commitment to justice for Aboriginal people, that we would also introduce a land fund bill that would give Aboriginal people a capacity to buy land, particularly in areas where title may have been extinguished, where there had been a grant of interest for a short period—a pastoral lease or something as we saw recently in events alluded to in the remarks by Justice French. In those circumstances Aboriginal people could actually buy land and they would have a secure title to it. It was and remains a central matter in the dispensing of justice to Aboriginal people.

The government was determined to get the Mabo bill, the native title bill, through. We stood our ground against intransigence in the Senate, we wore the admonition of the then Leader of the Opposition that it was a day of shame, we withstood the attenuated pressures of the opportunism of the coalition parties in the Senate, and during that period the Western Australian Greens, and said that we would campaign for this, in the country if necessary, were there a failure to pass it. Our determination to get our way, our way being justice for Aboriginal people, paid off for them when the bill was passed at the end of 1993.

In accordance with the commitment we made we then said we would introduce an Aboriginal land fund bill, and we did this. According to our commitment we proposed that bill to the House of Representatives, and then it went to the Senate in September of last year. From September until yesterday and today the Senate dallied with the bill, behaved opportunistically towards it, sought to undermine the central tenets of it, and then introduced a long, drawn-out process supposedly of consultation which only revealed what a sham process the Senate had embarked upon under the stewardship of the Liberal and National parties and the Western Australian Greens.

Yesterday, Mr Speaker, the Senate passed the bill, and it passed it with the amendments which the government objected to. Those amendments were to give priority now to those Aboriginal people who suffer the most disadvantage—as though, of course, there could be any secure test of the relative disadvantage of people or the relative dispossession. If one is dispossessed, one is dispossessed. The notion that the courts would then be asked to make judgments about these things was, of course, simply only a device and a sleight of hand.

The second problem with it was that they wanted to see a reference to grants to individuals and trustees being made possible, encompassing the whole notion of the traditional connection of Aboriginal communities with the land, and the protection of that land in the hands of communities being put asunder. The third problem was that another requirement, that grants of interest in land have regard to health, housing and so on, meant that the character of the bill changed from being a land fund bill to an appropriation bill that was interested in health, housing and other things. That completely denied the bill its integrity in terms of dealing with land.

The fourth problem was that they required the ILC, before acquiring land, to consult with those Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people who had traditional or historic links to the land in question. The device there was that, without any resolution of some of these issues, the body itself would not be able to conduct its affairs in an executive way. It discusses the removal of the ILC power to control effectively the disposal of land; in other words, it deals with the right of individual people to hold the land and actually dispose of it. It also referred to a group of proposals relating to regional strategies, as though they should in some way impair the capacity of the fund to actually do what we require of it.

This week the opposition parties had every chance to make a decision in favour of Aboriginal people without these devices, tricks and sleights of hand, and after this attenuated period, and send the legislation back with integrity to the House of Representatives for passage. They did not do this. They had the chance to decide on issues of justice. They denied themselves the chance, they denied Aboriginal people the chance, and they sent it back here.

The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) today made it very clear that, were he to be the Prime Minister of this country, the coalition would seek to again run these amendments—amendments which would tear the hell out of the bill. It is again said with insincerity towards the lot of Aboriginal people and that which is required for them. The government will today decide how to present the bill to the House—a bill which the Leader of the Opposition now says he will agree to have passed in the Senate. We will present a bill that will reflect the integrity of the bill first proposed to the House of Representatives and the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will pass the bill you introduced two days ago. That is the bill I will pass.
—You are out of order. Sit down. The passage of this will be great for Aboriginal people. It will be a great day for Aboriginal people only because the government stood its ground against—

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Prime Minister might wait for a moment. Since this legislation came before the parliament this morning, there has been an opportunity for members on both sides to be heard in silence. I request that that same privilege be extended to the Prime Minister.
—It will be a great day for Aboriginal people only because the government stood its ground on this and threatened the coalition with a double dissolution.
—Tomorrow! Tomorrow.
—The member for Hindmarsh will have her chance.

—We saw the honourable member with the Native Title Bill. We saw you. It was as though you were touched with a Zero weed wand and that faded away any advocacy of yours. You shrunk away whenever there was any reaction from the Right. We have seen you.
—Have you?

—Too right we have. Let me make it clear: by standing firmly for justice for Aboriginal people, we got the native title bill through. If coalition members were to refuse the passage of the bill and we sought to exercise the provisions of the constitution, that would allow ultimately a joint sitting of both houses to pass its opinion on this legislation to again grant to Aboriginal people that which is just and decent.

PARA.TAB: As a consequence and in the face of that, the coalition decided to send to the House yesterday a bill which in no way maintains the integrity of the original bill. But, in sending it back, the Leader of the Opposition understood that he started the three-month metre ticking.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not worried about that. I'd like it fast forwarded.
—Yes, I know about you, brother. We put the challenge up to you, and you buckled.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Prime Minister has the call.

—The empirical test is that we put up the challenge and you buckled. You are now saying you do not like the bill. You had a chance in the Senate to do justice to Aboriginal people and you did not. You sent the bill back full of these shoddy and appalling amendments. When we faced you up to it, you decided to say today that you would pass the bill but that when you became a government—and if you had your way—you would put all of these amendments back into the legislation. In other words, you would deny Aboriginal people that which this parliament would have given.You have proved by your actions that you have not changed your view.

PARA.TAB: The Leader of the Opposition said that he is taking the decision to pass the bill because of the risk of a deadlock between the houses. Again, I repeat the point to make it clear: he will alter it if he gets into government. He said that he detected in the broad Australian community a desire to solve the problem. He is not about leading in the resolution of the problem; he is only detecting and following a desire to solve the problem. Instead of standing on some principles, he says that he will pass the bill but then if he gets into government he will seek to amend it in ways which would render it completely inoperable.

The Leader of the Opposition also said that nobody has a monopoly on virtue in respect of Aboriginal affairs. This is true, but those in the coalition who have been virtuous about Aboriginal policy are not on the front bench; they are either on the back bench or out of the parliament. There has been no virtue on your front bench. Fancy talking about playing politics after your shabby performance. You have done nothing but play politics.

We saw how influential you were with John Hewson. You just sort of backed away and faded away when the Right of the Liberal Party said they would not have the native title legislation. The people on that side of the House who have a keen commitment to justice and compassion for Aboriginal people are not on the front bench; they are either out of the parliament now or on the back bench. It falls on the government again to stand resolutely in favour of those things which are just and decent for Aboriginal people.
Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—We faced you up to it and we busted your opportunism.
—I warn the member for Ballarat!

—Let me say a couple of things about the bizarre behaviour of the Western Australian Greens on this bill. They made an unholy alliance with the coalition in the Senate and abstained from the Senate vote yesterday. They do not deserve to be taken seriously. They have played games with the lives and interests of Aboriginal people for their own shoddy political reasons. This should be duly noted by all those Australians who are interested in the welfare of Aboriginal people and by Aboriginal people themselves.

PARA.TAB: It will be a great day for Aboriginal people when this bill goes through, and it is getting through because of the resolute strengths of the government to see that justice is done. When the coalition faced up to the fact that the government would take it on and run it up against a double dissolution of parliament and we would propose this at a joint sitting of both houses, it buckled. Aboriginal people will now get their appropriate justice. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is leaving. Never before have I been so disappointed with a Prime Minister of this country carrying on in such a way. He is totally and utterly incapable of getting out of the gutter. Those opposite with grinning faces should really look at what they have put up as the Prime Minister of this country. He cannot under any circumstances get out of the slime or the gutter and miss an opportunity to play politics. He made a political speech in Redfern about how much he cared for Aboriginal people. Ever since then, he has been playing Aboriginal affairs as a political football. He has done nothing else.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister had an opportunity today to come into the House, as did our Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), and say, `This is what we are going to do. Let's address the issues that are really hurting people out there. Let's get behind those Aboriginal people who are dying. Let's look at the serious problems. Let's get this over and out of the way.' What happened? He came into this House and made the most feeble political points that he could make. He could not resist doing that. There is not one inch of statesman in your Prime Minister. He comes from the gutter, and he is determined to stay in the gutter.

Let us look at some of the comments of the Prime Minister. He seemed to be a little confused in relation to which bill he was talking about. I am not surprised at that, considering the number of bills running around at the moment. Let me make this clear: we will not be voting for the ATSIC Amendment (Indigenous Land Corporation and Land Fund) Bill 1994; we will be voting in support of the amendments moved by the Senate. We are doing this because we do not want Aboriginal affairs to become a total political football and we do not want bills to be going backwards and forwards.

It is time to start addressing the most important issues. Let us look at some of the issues we have brought up in the Senate—issues which the Prime Minister believes have `gutted' and `undermined' the bill. He referred to the Senate committee `dallying' in relation to this bill. The committee travelled 12,000 kilometres and listened to 224 people. What did the Prime Minister do? He rushed off to one community. When the second bill is brought down next week, it is with great regret that we will put it through without the amendments asked for by members of the Aboriginal community at large. They have said, `The government did not consult.'

I draw the attention of the House to words of the minister when he introduced the original bill. He said, `We have consulted extensively, more extensively than ever before on this bill.' What did we find when we went around the country? Aboriginal group after Aboriginal group said, `We were not consulted. This government does not reflect our community; it reflects the community over there.' Aboriginal people are not homogeneous. There are different Aboriginal communities around Australia, and they were excluded by this government from participating in this bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —They were not consulted?

—They were not consulted. When they wrote to the government asking for consultation, they were sent the completed bill. This government failed to consult. We consulted with Aboriginal people, and the government did not.

PARA.TAB: I turn to our amendments. Those opposite are obviously not interested in what I have to say. I will continue my remarks for the benefit of those in the gallery who perhaps have a genuine interest in Aboriginal affairs, unlike government members, who have an interest in disruption and in playing political football.

I turn to some of the amendments that we are supposed to be discussing—these so `horrific' amendments. First of all, let us address the so-called health and housing amendment which we are saying is changing the nature of the bill. That amendment says that when the ILC is giving grants to Aboriginal communities buying the land it should look at what is going to happen with that land. Will the people be able to provide housing on the land? Will they be able to provide sealed roads? One of the big problems in Aboriginal health is the dust from the unsealed roads getting into people's eyes. Where there is not sufficient water for continual washing we get infectious diseases.

That brings up the second point. Should the ILC buy a piece of land where there is no available good ground water—there may be water that is too brackish to use—and where there is no piped water? How is that going to affect the health of the Aboriginal people who move into that community? It means that we are going to see more pictures similar to those that we saw when Graham Richardson went to Central Australia. We saw Aboriginal people living in humpies in a state of health that is reminiscent of Third World countries.

I do not know how the people in the gallery feel about that but, as an Australian, I am absolutely appalled and ashamed that we have people in Australia who live in that condition. I might remind those opposite that these people live in that condition after 12 years of Labor government.

Our amendment did not say to the ILC, `Don't buy the land.' It said, `Look, when you are buying the land for heaven's sake take these things into consideration: is there sewerage; how is that land going to be serviced by water; are you going to buy a piece of land that Aboriginal people will move on to and then find that they do not have water to wash?' The kids will be playing in the sewerage and will come up again and again with those infectious diseases that the rest of Australia has not seen since the last century.

Was this such a terrible amendment to this bill? It was an amendment that did not say, `Don't buy the land'; it simply said, `When you buy the land look at what is going to happen afterwards and think of the health of Aboriginal people on that land.' It was an essential amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ten per cent cut in Fightback.
—Order! The member for Leichhardt.

—It did not gut that bill; it made it better. That is what those opposite cannot accept. If those opposite were serious about Aboriginal welfare and the land fund bill, Mr Speaker, what do you think they would have done? Would they not have said, `Okay. You have some concerns from talking to Aboriginal people. Let's sit down and discuss your amendments'? No, they did not.
—You made up this amendment without any consultation whatsoever.

—Before the amendments were introduced to the House the Prime Minister was out there in front of the television cameras saying, `We will not agree to any of these amendments.' He had not even seen them.

PARA.TAB: Mr Dodd interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I warn the honourable member for Leichhardt.

—What happened when it got to the Senate? There was a little bit of difference in the Senate. Suddenly the amendments were not so bad and the government agreed to pass them. That was a nice backflip on the part of the government which the Prime Minister has not mentioned.

PARA.TAB: I would like to get on to some of the other amendments that are important. I refer to the attitude about individual trusts. The government has tried to mislead the Australian public by saying that our amendment meant that we would be handing land to individual people. If the government would care to read the amendment it would find that it said that the Indigenous Land Corporation, the body that buys the land, can give the land to corporations—which is in the bill at the moment—or individuals or trusts. It does not say that the ILC has to do this; it simply widens the options.

The Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer) read from a quotation which indicated that corporations are not a natural form for Aboriginal people. For most of those people family trusts are a much more understandable form. We did not even say, `You have to give it to family trusts.' We said we would widen the legislation to allow the Indigenous Land Corporation to provide for family trusts as well as corporations if that was what the Indigenous Land Corporation so decided.

The amendment was simply to give the ILC more power to consider those Aboriginal people who are not comfortable with corporations. Does that surprise people? How many here today really understand corporations? When you ask an Aboriginal community, with an overall extremely low level of literacy and a non-understanding of what goes on in the commercial world, to form a corporation, you are really asking it to do something which is alien to its whole traditional culture. Yet that is what this government says is the natural form for Aboriginal people. It has decided that that is what is right for Aboriginal people and to hell with the rest of the community, and to hell with those Aboriginal people who came to us saying, `The government did not consult with us. We cannot live with the bill in this form. Would you please get the bill amended so it applies to us?'

The government is very sensitive about our proposal for the extra $3 million. Most of the Australian public, despite our efforts to get the information out, are not aware that the coalition and the Greens in the Senate actually voted for an extra $3 million to go into the land fund for administration. The request was rushed into this House so quickly that I do not think that members on the other side even knew what was happening. It was in and out in a few seconds.

There is a land fund. We thought that it was important that the money in the land fund be spent only on land and not be eaten up in administration, the way so much money is in these areas. We said that we would vote $3 million into the fund for administration but that that was all that could be spent on administration; the rest of the money would be for the purchase of land.

What did the government do? It said, `No way.' It rushed that request out of the Senate and into the House without any warning. I was in my room at the time. If I had not been able to run as fast as I can, I would have missed it altogether and would not have been able to tell this House what our position was. The Whip was given one minute's notice, and that is how long it took me to get out of my room. It was a despicable act on the part of the government, getting the request back into this House without allowing for proper debate on the extra $3 million.

What did the government do then? It circulated amongst the general community not that we had voted an extra $3 million for administration, but that we had simply wanted to cap administration expenses. There was no mention of the extra money. It sent out letters to Aboriginal people, misleading them on this point, saying that we wanted to cap administration and that it thought that was an unreasonable fettering of the ILC.

I turn now to the issue of traditional ownership. One of our amendments was designed to require the ILC to consult with traditional owners prior to the acquisition of land or making a grant for the acquisition of land. We thought it was an extremely sensible amendment and we are yet to discover why the government knocked it back.

If the ILC is buying land for one group of Aboriginal people, it makes sense that, first of all, the traditional people be consulted with. If it is buying land for traditional people, that is fine. But what happens if the ILC believes that it is buying land for one group of Aboriginal people while there are other Aboriginal people who have traditionally used that land—people who may not have a claim under the Mabo legislation because the land was subject to a pastoral lease? Their Mabo claim has been wiped out, yet they have been traditional owners.What will be the result for those two tribes of Aboriginal people? The result will be fighting, argument and bloodshed. Yet the government, because it refuses to consider sensible amendments, purely for party political reasons, totally refused that amendment.

In conclusion, I sum up my reaction as one of incredible disappointment at the way in which the government has decided to use Aboriginal affairs not only as a political football but as a way of scoring political points when out there is one of the most serious problems facing Australia today. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The shadow minister for Aboriginal affairs, the member for Hindmarsh (Mrs Gallus), appealed to the gallery during her speech. I appeal to the gallery to discount everything it has just heard from the member for Hindmarsh because she has just engaged in a total rewrite of history. Let us not forget that most of the amendments we are discussing here today were amendments that she brought into this House before she had had one ounce of consultation with any Aboriginal people whatsoever.

PARA.TAB: One of the major reasons why most of the amendments were rejected by the government in the first place was that she had not engaged in any sort of consultation. In fact, she was told very clearly right across the board that most of her amendments were not acceptable to Aboriginal people. The opposition then set up this farce of a Senate select committee which spent a week at Christmas time running around desperately trying to get a few people in Aboriginal Australia to back its opinions. It did manage to find a few people who would say, `Yes, I agree with this one,' or `I agree with that one.' But the fact is that the Senate has absolutely no expertise in Aboriginal affairs. It is great at bagging Aboriginal people, it is great at knocking ATSIC and it is great at engaging in political campaigns against Aboriginal interests, but it has not done any real hard work on Aboriginal affairs.

The only really good intensive discussion of Aboriginal affairs in a balanced and reasonable way occurs in this House. We have the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, which has been in existence for 17 years, and which I am proud to be the chair of at this time. It has a long history and, because of the work of that committee, we actually engage in much greater consultation amongst Aboriginal people.

Over the last five years I have been on that committee, I have visited probably over 100 Aboriginal communities and have spoken to thousands of Aboriginal people—a hell of a lot more than the shadow minister for Aboriginal affairs has done. I know a lot more about Aboriginal affairs than the shadow minister for Aboriginal affairs says.

I would like to make just one point. The coalition was able to get away with a lot of the amendments it put forward in the Senate only because of the unholy alliance it had with the Western Australian Greens. It greatly disappoints me that the Western Australian Greens were willing to sell their souls to the coalition on this deal. They put this bill through months of delay, forced through the Senate a whole pile of amendments and then did not even have the guts to stand up in the Senate and vote for it. They avoided it. They abstained from the vote. That is how strong their commitment is to Aboriginal people and how strong their commitment is to the amendments. They did not even have the guts to vote on the bill when it went into the Senate. That just shows you exactly what the Greens are worth. It is a worthless organisation, and the miserable two in the Senate at the moment will be decimated at the next election.

Regardless of the cowardly motives of the opposition in wanting to avoid a double dissolution and facing the people of Australia where they know they are going to be beaten, I am pleased that the coalition has agreed to vote for the second government bill when it comes to the House next Tuesday, because I am sick of the unnecessary delays that have occurred. I am strongly in support of this land acquisition fund. I believe it is a very important new initiative in social justice for Aboriginal people. I just wish the people on the other side would really start talking about accountability and start targeting state and territory governments.

Let us not forget who has the major responsibility for the provision of health services throughout this country—state and territory governments. Who is responsible for building housing, building roads and putting in water supplies? State, territory and local governments. It is they that have been failing in their responsibilities. The opposition never talks about or accepts that. It comes in here and talks about states rights all the time, but it never talks about states responsibilities. It is about time states responsibilities in Aboriginal affairs started getting an airing in this House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I came into this chamber this morning from the middle of a meeting with a subcommittee of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation where we are working on the council's recommendations to the government for the social justice package. I would like to spend the few minutes that I have available to me this morning perhaps trying to move away a little from some of the hot air, self-righteous indignation and accusations that have been flowing around and talk about some constructive things for our indigenous population.

PARA.TAB: I would urge the government to grasp the opportunity that is now clearly before it that this legislation is going to go through the parliament. The fact that we are going to vote against this particular piece of legislation this morning to support our Senate colleagues but have indicated quite clearly that when the second bill comes on next week we will not oppose it gives the government an opportunity not to have to put lots of its effort, energies, time and rhetoric into that piece of legislation but to now turn its attention to doing some constructive things in so many other areas of urgent and desperate Aboriginal need.

There is no question that we all accept the importance of land to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. The way in which that is expressed might vary from person to person or community to community, and there may be different strengths and views within this chamber. But the fundamental recognition is there and the coalition has accepted that principle with this bill throughout.

I think we also need to be conscious that there are a number of areas where, unfortunately, the government's good intentions—and I accept that the minister has acted with good intentions for a long time in so many other areas of Aboriginal disadvantage, such as health, housing, education, employment and so on—have not borne the fruits that we would all like to have seen. The reality is that health is still a major disaster in this country. The one statistic that comes back to me repeatedly is life expectancy—18 years less for an Aboriginal male born today compared with somebody in the wider community, and for females it is 15 years.

If we look at the housing situation, we are talking about $2 billion just to catch up on the backlog. If we look at levels of education, we realise it is not just education but it is all interlinked. Health impacts on that as well with so many of our Aboriginal children going to school with middle ear infection that they have not got a hope in either the health or the education stakes. And unemployment is so much worse in the indigenous community.

We clearly have a number of problems with the ATSIC experiment. Without bucketing, in any sense, ATSIC—and I have been one of its strongest supporters in this place—there are quite clearly a number of areas that need addressing, and the government should be giving it that attention.

I urge the government in dealing with these matters to go out and consult with the Aboriginal community on a far wider basis than it did with this land bill. I think it has had a tendency to deal with Aboriginal people who are elected to ATSIC, but unfortunately they do not represent the majority. They have dealt with the land councils but there are many others in Aboriginal communities who hold contrary views and who need to be consulted.

In my role since I have come into this parliament I have been to many of those communities regularly and I can assure the House that although the government is claiming its views are so unanimously supported, that is simply not the case. I am concerned that the government has chosen to take a divisive attitude in so many areas of Aboriginal affairs. To hear the Prime Minister talk about the need for cross-party support and then come in here and say, `Now I am going to pull this second bill, I am going to introduce a third bill next week,' seems to me to be merely trying to take party political advantage.

I would have thought the interests of indigenous people in this country would have been far better served by accepting that the coalition is going to not oppose the second bill and to then get on with the urgent business of dealing with Aboriginal disadvantage. The government is talking about its three tranches—the native title legislation, the land fund and the social justice package which is upcoming and essentially about rights. They are all important to indigenous people and most people in this chamber accept the principles. But we argue about the implementation.

I really urge the government to change its priorities now that it has a guarantee of getting that legislation through and to turn its attention much more to dealing with those practical things on the ground because when I go to Aboriginal communities that is what they tell me they want fixed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allotted for the consideration of these amendments has expired. The question is that Senate amendments Nos 1 to 3 made in place of request not pressed, and further amendments Nos 4 to 17, 23 to 27, 31 to 33, 35, 41 to 43, 45 to 48, 51 to 56, 63 and 65 (Group 1) be disagreed to.

PARA.TAB: Question put.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner The Hon R.E.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Mr TICKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate's further amendments Nos 1 to 3, 18 to 22, 28 to 30, 34, 36 to 40, 44, 49, 50, 57 to 62, 64, 66, and 67 (Group 2) be agreed to.

SPEECH.PARA: As has already been said by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), only a Labor government could deliver legislation to produce this land fund. But, in debating the bill currently before the House, we now turn to amendments which have been agreed to by the government. In doing so, I must emphasise that the government has, once again, shown its bona fides and its good faith in agreeing to some 29 amendments made by the Senate to the land fund bill.

PARA.TAB: What we are not prepared to do is agree to amendments which are bad law and that would make, for example, grants to individual people on one day and allow the land to be sold off the next day with a total absence of accountability. However, the 29 amendments that we are accepting is evidence of our commitment to try to achieve the greatest degree of cross-party support.

The coalition is now indicating that it will support the Prime Minister's bill because of the fear of a double dissolution. As the minister, I welcome the support for whatever reason, although the point about the coalition's motivation, which has been made in a very telling way, shows how scared the coalition is to face a full Senate election.

Notwithstanding the government's concern on a number of issues about the Senate amendments, we think that the additional operational burdens on the Indigenous Land Corporation are survivable if these amendments are accepted. We believe that one of them—a Democrat amendment—clearly improves the bill. It is the so-called `top-up' amendment, No. 57, which provides that, if at the end of a 10-year period the land fund does not reach the investment target expected of it, an extra amount will be paid from consolidated revenue to top up the land fund. That is a very important guarantee which ensures that after the initial 10 years the fund will be self-sustaining.

A number of other amendments which the government is prepared to accept are technical ones. For example, the title of the bill has been changed, the minister will be required to table the national strategy in parliament within 15 days of receiving it and the terms and conditions which the Indigenous Land Corporation may impose on a loan is spelt out rather than left to the discretion of the Indigenous Land Corporation.

Still other amendments have been accepted by us because they do not fundamentally offend the spirit of the bill and, of course, those amendments are incorporated in the new bill that the Prime Minister introduced into the parliament. An example of that would be the provision that the ILC must report to the minister if its obligations not to reveal secret material affects its functions.

In view of the prolonged debate that this bill has received, and the fact that the government is accepting the amendments that I am currently speaking about, I will truncate my remarks and allow opposition speakers to make a contribution.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will also make my comments brief because the government has decided to shorten this debate. I know there are many people on my side who would have a lot to say but, unfortunately, they will not be able to do so.

PARA.TAB: May I clearly point out to the minister sitting at the table, the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner), that we would like nothing more than to go to an election right now. PARA.TAB: In this debate, once again, the opposition has no planned policy on Aboriginal affairs. I want to comment on this issue because these land fund measures are about Australia taking responsibility for its past. As a collective, all the present citizens of this country have a collective responsibility for past wrongs just, indeed, as I hope we would see that Germany has a collective responsibility for its wrongs done to minorities during the Second World War and just as we would expect the Japanese to have a collective responsibility for the wrongs done to our POWs.

To say that we will not have any truck with the guilt industry is an absolute disgrace. It is my view, very strongly held, that until we as a community accept our responsibility for these issues and acknowledge them, as indeed has been done by the Prime Minister in his Redfern speech, in his second reading speeches on the two land fund bills before this parliament and in his speech at Hopevale, there is no real chance of reconciliation.

This bill is about land and is about the Aboriginal people's spiritual involvement with the land. The aim of this bill is to make sure that for those communities who cannot get justice through the Mabo legislation there will be access to land, independence and a return to their spiritual roots. TALK.START.PARA: —I must indicate my thanks to the honourable member for Capricornia (Ms Henzell) for finishing early and allowing me some time to speak on the ATSIC Amendment (Indigenous Land Corporation and Land Fund) Bill. Having thanked her, I must refer to her statement that the government has demonstrated its commitment. The government has demonstrated its commitment to failure of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. If we look at the areas of health, education, housing and employment—everywhere we look—it is a record of failure.

PARA.TAB: The government has been in office for 12 years. What has happened in those 12 years? Aboriginal men still have a life expectancy 18 years less than me. In fact, probably almost every Aboriginal man born the year that I was born is dead already. That is the likelihood, and that is a disgrace and a shame. Aboriginal women have 15 years less life expectancy than my wife. How can we, and my friends on the other side of the House, talk about responsibility, commitment and guilt? What is absolutely unkind about this legislation is that it cruelly raises the expectations of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. I flag this particular point because the Torres Strait is an area of great interest to me personally. I have a lot of friends there, and I go there from time to time. I am really concerned about what this bill will do for people in the Torres Strait.

I believe that this bill is a sham, and I have believed that ever since the bill was introduced. It cruelly raises expectations. I hope the minister will be able to inform me if I am wrong. I hope I am wrong because I do not believe that this sort of confidence trick on the indigenous people of Australia is at all appropriate.

The Prime Minister spoke about justice for Aboriginal people. They are being denied justice in the important areas of health, housing and education. The honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon) spoke about the ATSIC leadership representing all Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. I do not think for one second that the ATSIC leadership represents the people in my electorate who live at New Burnt Bridge. The minister at the table will recall visiting New Burnt Bridge with me. I have praised him many times since then for going and I do so again. I also applaud his commitment, as he provided $2.3 million for it.

But I come back to the fact that, although the money has already been provided, years later not a single house has been built and people are still living in disgraceful Third World conditions. They complained to the Ombudsman because of a dispute with the regional office of ATSIC at Lismore. What has ATSIC done? It has taken out injunctions to stop the Ombudsman's report going to this minister, the Prime Minister and this parliament. I do not believe ATSIC enjoys the confidence of all Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander people at all. In fact, I know that to be true.

I will complete my remarks so the honourable member for Oxley (Mr Les Scott) will have at least a couple of minutes to speak. This bill is not what it seems. It provides about an extra $24 million a year in new money for 10 years, and it is not going to do what is required of it. I come back to the point that we must solve the health, housing, education and employment problems. We have had 12 years of failure by the present government. It should face up to the event. I say this to all of those on the government side who talk about elections: if you want an election, bring one on now. We are ready and we will beat you.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Shipping in and around the Great Barrier Reef

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I rise to make a statement about shipping in and around our unique national treasure, the Great Barrier Reef. Presently, ships use two routes to traverse the reef. What is known as the inner route travels from the Torres Strait in the north, to Gladstone in the south. The alternative route—the outer route—commences in the Prince of Wales Channel, leaves the Torres Strait at Bligh Entrance, and continues southwards through the Coral Sea to Sandy Cape, just south of Gladstone.

PARA.TAB: All ships entering and leaving the inner and outer routes have to cross the Torres Strait. At present, pilotage is compulsory in the inner route between Cairns and the Torres Strait for all oil and chemical tankers and liquid natural gas carriers, regardless of size, and all other ships over 70 metres in length.

The most hazardous parts of the reef to navigate are in the Torres Strait and in the northern section of the inner passage. Narrow channels, strong tides and the presence of fishing boats all enhance the risk of a grounding. Furthermore, in the case of the outer route, the process of skirting the reef and the largely uncharted waters pose a similar risk of grounding. With some 87 million tonnes of international trade—mostly Australian exports—shipped through the region annually, this ever present danger is a matter of great concern.

Altogether, there are some 2,100 local and international vessel movements annually, including 1,700 through the inner route, 600 of which do not call at any Queensland port inside the reef. This leaves some 400 vessels using the outer route. Whilst pilotage in the inner route is, as I said, mandatory for all oil and chemical tankers, liquid natural gas carriers and other ships over 70 metres in length, it is not compulsory in the international waters of the Torres Strait.

Each year, 30 loaded oil tankers enter the Torres Strait and transit the inner route, while a similar number travel north along the inner route under ballast. Twenty tankers transit the outer route southward. The government considers that there is no compelling reason for those 30 tankers not to join the 20 tankers using the outer route southward.

Few Australians would think of the Great Barrier Reef as a shipping lane. It is seen by most as a precious natural asset—and, indeed, it is. That is certainly the view of the government, and that is why we are determined to take all reasonable steps to minimise the potential for shipping disaster. But in doing so we must strike a balance between protecting the natural environment and maintaining viable shipping lanes.

The government has already taken a number of significant steps to safeguard the reef and to improve safety in shipping. Last September I announced new administrative procedures for issuing single voyage permits to foreign vessels. This places an obligation on shippers to undertake thorough safety checks before chartering foreign vessels. This condition came into effect this week. In addition, shippers applying for permits involving bulk carriers and all types of tankers must now certify vital information on the condition of the ship, as well as the qualifications of its crew.

As part of the government's response to the House of Representatives Ships of shame report, targeted inspections have doubled and now more than one in two foreign flagged vessels are subject to inspection when they call into Australian ports. This rigorous inspection regime has unquestionably deterred substandard shippers from calling into Australia.

Today we can boast the toughest inspection regime in the world; one in which monthly ship detention reports are published to bring substandard shipping to worldwide attention. In terms of the reef itself, by introducing a regime of compulsory pilotage for the inner route in October 1991, Australia made this transit route one of the world's few recognised compulsory pilotage areas.

More recently, in October 1993, the government announced a detailed review of shipping in the Great Barrier Reef and the Torres Strait. We did so to ensure that the management of shipping operations maximises environmental protection and minimises the risk of accidents and pollution. This review has been conducted in conjunction with the Queensland government. A wide range of interested parties, including the shipping industry and environmental groups, has been consulted. The report is presently being finalised and will be released by the government soon.

Nevertheless, today I want to announce a number of initiatives that will improve the safety of shipping in the Great Barrier Reef and the Torres Strait. The initiatives involve minimising shipping pressure on the inner route; additional steps to improve the safety of ships that use the inner route; improved navigational safety in the Torres Strait; and improving the safety and the reliability of the outer route.

We are undertaking these initiatives in the knowledge that many vessels use the Great Barrier Reef inner route because of a lack of suitable charting of the outer route through the Coral Sea. In order to improve the charting of the outer reef, I can today announce that the Australian Maritime Safety Authority, AMSA, will provide funding for the production of these charts. The task will involve surveying that will begin at Bramble Cay in the eastern approaches to the Torres Strait and go down the Queensland coast to the end of the reef just north of Fraser Island, a total distance of some 2,000 kilometres. Once this charting is done, those vessels not calling at Queensland ports that currently use the inner route, will, unless there are exceptional circumstances, have absolutely no reason to do so.

Simultaneously with this charting, AMSA will proceed with the introduction of a mandatory ship reporting regime for the Great Barrier Reef and the Torres Strait. AMSA will also seek to implement a reporting system with the agreement of the International Maritime Organisation, IMO, and will aim to have the measures in place before the end of this year.

Meanwhile I can assure the House that the Queensland government has been cooperating with the Commonwealth in moving towards the introduction of a vessel traffic system to cover both the North East Channel and the Torres Strait. The Commonwealth is very grateful for the Queensland government's assistance with this task.

Together, AMSA and the Queensland government have been looking very closely at initiatives to improve maritime safety in northern waters. Extensive studies by consultants of potential high-technology solutions to the navigational problems of the region have now been completed. AMSA and the Queensland government are now negotiating joint ventures to ensure these initiatives can be introduced at the earliest time and in the most cost-effective way.

One of the first stages of this cooperative approach will be the introduction of a vessel traffic system to cover the Torres Strait, the Great North Eastern Channel route near Cape York, and the inner route. Extended coverage of this radar traffic system will provide accurate real time information and reduce the prospect of ship collision and groundings. This will be a vast improvement on the present situation where authorities rely on positions radioed in from vessels. It will provide cover of, and information relating to the important `choke' points—where channels are narrow and the hazard to shipping is greatly increased.

Furthermore, it will assist the Australian and the Queensland agencies involved in vessel traffic to enhance safety by monitoring vessel movements more closely. Extension of the compulsory pilotage area in the northern part of the Great Barrier Reef to cover the Torres Strait area would further reduce the risk of groundings and collisions. After all, human error is the greatest risk to safe shipping.

The Torres Strait is an important and busy international shipping lane and Australia must be cognisant of the role of our neighbour, Papua New Guinea, and the international maritime community in seeking ways to improve safety in this ecologically vulnerable region. As the Torres Strait is a recognised international waterway, the extension of compulsory pilotage will involve comprehensive international negotiations. A successful outcome to these negotiations will be far more difficult to achieve than for the Barrier Reef, which lies totally within Australian waters.

I have asked AMSA to pursue the question of compulsory pilotage in the Torres Strait. Indeed, it will now become AMSA's highest international priority in negotiations through the IMO. It is pleasing to note that around 70 per cent of shipping that is currently transiting the Torres Strait already uses marine pilots on a voluntary basis. Yet there are a number of foreign flag vessels which place commercial considerations before their environmental conscience. We now intend to seek international acceptance of the need to carry pilots in these waters.

While insisting on the greater use of pilotage in the marine environments, we recognise that technology is constantly offering new ways to improve safety. The latest differential global positioning systems, DGPS, offer improved navigational safety. With DGPS, positioning accuracy is better than 10 metres. This technology is now available and is being trialled successfully by AMSA in Bass Strait and off the Pilbara.

Today I announce the establishment of a new DGPS broadcasting station on Horn Island in the Torres Strait. It will be opened by October this year and will greatly improve the accuracy of ship positioning and assist individual ships to navigate safely in these difficult waters. With the establishment of this station AMSA will insist on the compulsory use by pilots of transportable global positioning equipment. This will ensure that all ships being piloted do so with the benefit of the improved DGPS navigational services.

The next few years will see the introduction of computer based charting systems that provide further improvements to all navigational systems on all types of vessels. As of now, a large amount of work has already been completed on this technology. The development of such a system can and should have implications beyond just the reef. It has the capacity to extend to all of our precious Australian coastline. That makes it a huge undertaking. Such technology is costly to develop but it is an investment that Australia must make in the interests of our marine environment and the safety of shipping.

To this day, shipping oil spills remain the greatest threat to our coastline. They are a constant threat over which we must be forever vigilant. Vigilance will help prevention or, in the event of an unavoidable spillage, the ability to minimise the damage to our marine environment.

The Australian government is in the process of negotiating a memorandum of understanding with Papua New Guinea on cooperation and assistance in the event of a marine pollution incident affecting either country. This is of particular relevance to the Torres Strait. There is already considerable cooperation with Papua New Guinea involving AMSA providing significant assistance to the PNG government.

Following a major review of Natplan in 1993, some 30 recommendations were made to improve planning and the capacity to respond to a major spill. Twenty-six actions have now been implemented and the remaining four are to be completed by the end of 1995. Actions relevant to the Great Barrier Reef include: the positioning of additional equipment in North Queensland and training for its use; development of a MOU between AMSA, Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, GBRMPA, and Queensland for safe havens for disabled or damaged ships; priority for research funding going to a bioremediation proposal to be managed by the GBRMPA; and extension of the on scene spill model to cover the Ribbon Reefs area. Reefplan, the regional version of Natplan, is currently undergoing its own review, which will be completed in mid-1995. The emphasis will be on prevention, on planning and on a rapid response.

When taken together as a package, all these federal government measures enhance shipping safety in this most sensitive of areas. We have a great responsibility to current and future generations to protect what is the world's biggest and most beautiful reef, one of the world's great ecological treasures. As a maritime enthusiast it gives me great pleasure to detail these important government initiatives aimed at protecting what we all hold dear. They are balanced initiatives, yet initiatives with foresight. I commend the statement to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I take it that the maritime interests referred to by the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) include his yacht moored down at Pittwater, the one that is so famous that Kay Cottee often refers to it as the one that bumped into her boat one day.
