Perhaps it might be better described as a public menace. I appreciate what the minister has said and I think those of us—
—It shows how little you know about Kay Cottee and me.
—She tells me that the minister rammed her yacht, and indeed I read in the paper one day that he claimed that she ran into his. We will no doubt never know the truth of it.
—You obviously know nothing about these circumstances.

—I certainly know enough from what I have heard from Kay Cottee to know that Laurie Brereton, at the helm of his yacht, is a public menace. At any rate, I will not go any further into the matter. In fact, a lot of people would suggest that Laurie Brereton at the helm of anything was a public menace.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl)—Order! The member for Gilmore will refer to the minister by his correct title.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you very much, Mr Deputy Speaker, for your guidance. There is no doubt that, for those of us who have had an interest in this issue, this does advance the cause of protecting the Great Barrier Reef. A number of people in the chamber today would have heard debates going back over the last few years; there has been a great deal of concern and interest from both sides of the House.

PARA.TAB: Indeed, I was going through my own speeches from the last few years and I noticed that, on 28 November 1988, I said in this House:

SPEECH.PARA: Talk of damage to the Great Barrier Reef is of great concern to Australia, not just from a recreation and aesthetic point of view, but also from the economic and employment point of view.

In May 1991, we had the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Amendment Bill introduced into the House, and it introduced compulsory pilotage. Unfortunately for the those of us who wanted to debate the issue, the guillotine was applied and only the minister's speech was allowed to be heard in the House at the time. Certainly, on that occasion the opposition supported the compulsory pilotage that was put forward at the time.

PARA.TAB: There have been a number of issues in recent times. We have had bills about oil pollution at sea. The honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) has spoken, I think, on virtually all of these. In relation to the Transport Legislation Amendment Bill 1991, I said:

SPEECH.PARA: I personally support the amendments that relate to the prevention of pollution from ships.

Another was the Protection of Sea (Shipping Levy) Amendment Bill 1993. I refer to a speech I made when I represented the opposition on that matter. We supported attempts, at that time, to investigate alternative routes outside the reef.

PARA.TAB: Indeed, it is an interesting point. The minister might like to consider the fact that, at the time, Caltex offered an $80,000 sponsorship to assist in studies on alternative routes outside the reef. I was listening to the minister's speech today, and there was no mention of that. I wonder whether that sponsorship was ever taken up. Perhaps, if it were, it would be a nice thing to thank Caltex in the process. Many people think that our shipping companies are not as environmentally responsible as people would like to think, yet there have been instances, as is the case with Caltex, where not only have they tried to be responsible but also they have put their money where their mouths are.

Indeed, Shell is another example. Shell's oil tankers have been travelling outside the reef now for quite some time, in an attempt made by Shell to ensure that it creates minimal risk of damage to the Great Barrier Reef.

So, there have been a number of shipping companies and oil companies doing their very best to assist in ensuring that we do not have any accidents on the reef. Of course, there have been many others who have not, but at least it is worth noting those who have been helping.

Throughout all of this, from the opposition's point of view and, indeed, from the government's point of view, we have been very keen to do the utmost to protect the reef. The reason the minister is bringing this into the House today is that, whilst it would seem logical to have all ships go outside the reef, other than those ships which have to call in to ports along the reef, there have been concerns that the shipping lanes outside, to the east of, the reef have not been adequately charted.

Many old salts will tell you that the original charting that was done many years ago was done very poorly; some, apparently, was not done at all. A lot of the navigational aids are very old and not up to the task today. Of course, that has been a concern, because, if you do not have properly charted waters so that you can be confident that ships can plough through those waters without running into anything, it is probably safer to have ships going inside the reef where there are proper charts. With proper navigational aids and compulsory pilotage, that was probably safer than going outside the reef, at the time.

There is no doubt that the initiatives announced today by the minister will ensure that, over time, channels outside the reef will become a lot safer, with the addition of proper charting and more navigational aids. That is something that I think will advance a cause that both sides of this House would support: making sure that our Great Barrier Reef is protected as much as it can be.

The compulsory DGPS through the Torres Strait is really an essential element. I have actually taken a boat, many years ago now, through the Torres Strait, and at that point you get the Indian and Pacific oceans meeting. You get currents that clash at that point—they go in different directions—you get whirlpools; it is really quite dramatic if you go through that part of the world in a boat. It is a very dangerous waterway. The channels are very narrow, those channels are quite shallow as well, and there is quite a lot of shipping that goes through. So it is really vital that, if we are to advance the cause that all of us in this House support, we get that international agreement, if you like, with compulsory DGPSs for ships going through that part of the world. It is something that we should promote as quickly as possible.

As the minister has pointed out, computer based charting is something that will further enhance our attempts to protect the Great Barrier Reef and it should be seen as a great priority. I hope I am quoting the minister correctly where he talks of the time span for these things over the next few years, and I would hope that we could be more definite. Rather than just saying `over the next few years', we should actually set ourselves a particular schedule that we could work to so that this gives people the impetus to get on with the job, because when you say, `We are going to do it over the next few years,' you can never be confident that all the bureaucrats and diplomats that are involved in achieving these things are working at maximum speed.

Many of us, as I said earlier, have taken a long and deep interest in this issue. I have visited the oil spill centre in Geelong. For anybody who has an interest in this matter and who has not visited that centre, I think it is a very worthwhile thing to do. It is sponsored by the oil companies. It is one of our front-line defences if we do have an oil spill. That reminds me of the Auditor-General's report No. 9 of 1994-95, which was tabled some time ago now. That report looked into our ability to respond to a major oil spill, and in the process identified the Great Barrier Reef as a high risk area. I quote from the report's conclusion:

SPEECH.PARA: The ANAO considers that with the technology currently available there is no certainty that a major oil spill can be dispersed before it impacts on the shoreline.

This is something that we need to be looking at also, that we must have the equipment necessary to ensure that we can deal with a major oil spill in this part of the world. The downside to travelling outside the reef is that, if you do have an oil spill occurring at that point, the winds and the currents along that coastline are such that you actually will drive the oil, or whatever chemical spills out of the ship, across the entire width of the reef, whereas, as happened in the past, where you come up through the middle of the reef you run the risk of putting oil over only half of the reef, if you like. That is a simple analogy, but it is roughly right.

PARA.TAB: By going outside the reef we do increase the area potentially affected by an oil spill, so it is important that we also do what we can to ensure that we have got oil spill recovery facilities to ensure that if something does go wrong we can do our very best to mop it up. The one thing that we all worry about, apart from the ecological damage, is the television news reports around the world that would display our Great Barrier Reef in a very poor light, and it would do our tourism industry a great deal of harm. We all have memories of the Exxon Valdez going down in Prince William Sound and the oil spill that was portrayed for weeks after that on the television. It promoted a bad image. We all remember the Kirki, and we were very fortunate that that did not do much damage in the long term because the oil broke up and evaporated. So we really need to make sure that whatever oil spill response we have is adequate to the task ahead of us, and from the Auditor-General's view there is some doubt that we have adequate equipment to meet that task.

I have got a book somewhere in my shelves which I acquired from the seamen's union; when I went on board the Trans-Tasman trader from Brisbane to Auckland some years ago they kindly gave me a book, a history of their union. I must admit it took me an hour and a half of getting my ear bashed in order to be awarded it. Rather diplomatically, I might add, I came second in the darts competition, allowing the leading trade unionist on board the vessel to actually win the darts competition. So I won this book.

At any rate, there is a chart in the book which highlights the number of known wrecks there have been over the years along the coastline of Australia. It is amazing to see the number: hundreds, in fact, and many of them on the Great Barrier Reef. It is worth making the point that, just because there is an accident at sea with an oil spill, it does not necessarily mean the end of the world: the oil can evaporate and break up, and the reef can recover. There has been a tremendous amount of oil spilt on the reef, particularly during the Second World War, so all of these things need to be taken into account.

The opposition supports these sensible moves—as it has done over the past several years—to ensure that we are doing everything that we can, through this parliament, to protect the Great Barrier Reef, the jewel in our national tourism crown. This is something that I am pleased to see that the Australia shipowners and the various oil companies support. With a sensible approach, we can be doing our best to enhance the safety of the Great Barrier Reef. I can assure the Minister for Transport and the House that the opposition will again be supporting the government initiative on this issue.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: New Directions in Australia's Overseas Aid Program

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bilney The Hon G.N.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BILNEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—In my last annual report to parliament on the aid program, which I tabled at the end of 1993, I set out the government's approach to poverty alleviation through its aid program. In that report, I emphasised the importance of sustainable economic growth and social development proceeding in tandem. The report I am tabling today highlights significant new directions in Australia's aid program in the social sector and in the area of humanitarian relief. The report also covers the major achievements of the aid program over the past 12 months, and I shall begin my comments by outlining some of the most important of these achievements.

PARA.TAB: Despite the need for continued budgetary restraint in order to consolidate the economic recovery in Australia, the government demonstrated its commitment to international development by increasing Australia's aid program by 3.6 per cent in real terms. This meant that we were one of only four of the 21 OECD donors who increased their aid programs in the last year. As a result, Australia continues to remain above the average for donors in terms of the aid to GNP ratio. Aid volume apart, there have been significant changes in our region, not least in Indochina and the South Pacific. Further afield, the transition to democracy in South Africa will change the nature of economic relationships throughout southern Africa.

I draw attention now to significant developments in Australia's relationship with the South Pacific. During the run-up to the South Pacific Forum—which was held in Brisbane in August last year—I gave a speech to the Foreign Correspondents Association, highlighting the need for policy reforms in the region. The overriding theme of my address was the need for the region's governments to develop improved national policies to encourage sustainable social and economic growth. I am pleased to say that this theme was taken on board by regional leaders and, as a result, the forum generated an unprecedented level of commitment to improve economic and environmental policies, particularly in forestry.

Just recently, a code of conduct on logging was agreed by officials from forum island countries, and only last week a meeting of the region's finance ministers took place in Suva, at which crucial policy issues were discussed, including fiscal, forestry and civil aviation matters which have been identified as priorities by island leaders. In Papua New Guinea, we have agreed on a radical transformation of the aid program. By the end of the decade, the program will have completely moved from budget support to jointly programmed project activities.

In Indochina—one of the poorest regions of the world, where annual incomes per head are less than $400—our aid program is expanding rapidly. In May 1994, we announced a four-year, $350 million package, targeted at the high priority areas of health, infrastructure, education, human rights and the strengthening of legal institutions.

One of the most visible examples of the effectiveness of our development assistance is the Mekong River Friendship Bridge. It is the first road link between Laos and Thailand and will yield substantial economic benefits to both countries. Moreover, as one of the highest profile aid projects undertaken by Australia in recent years—and incidentally, a project completed ahead of schedule and under budget—the bridge is an invaluable showcase for Australian capabilities in major infrastructure design and technology transfer.

I wish to draw members' attention to the government's response to the tragedy of Rwanda. The government has so far contributed $35 million to support the relief effort there, a contribution matched by an extraordinary public response of over $30 million. Australia's response was one of the earliest and, from my observations, one of the most effectively targeted of all donors. At the same time, and despite our limited resources, we have begun an increased program to support the peaceful transition to majority rule in South Africa by providing assistance of $30 million over three years. This program has been designed to meet the objectives of the Government of National Unity's reconstruction and development program, including through building up capacity in areas such as planning, economic policy and the media.

There have also been important developments in the sector focus of Australia's aid program. In particular, we have continued to expand environmental assistance, and in this financial year, we will spend around $120 million on these activities. Amongst other things, this funding will cover the establishment of what we are calling `Green DIFF', part of the highly successful development import finance facility which has been the catalyst for many Australian companies to become involved in the region. Green DIFF will help to finance environmental projects in areas such as pollution control and energy efficiency, gaining wider exposure for Australia's environmental expertise. The last budget also heralded an Australian contribution of nearly $43 million to replenish the global environment facility, as well as an increase in support for the Montreal Protocol on Substances that Deplete the Ozone Layer.

A vibrant private sector is an essential part of the development process. Initiatives such as the private sector linkages program, which last year saw its budget allocation double to $10 million, are targeted at this sector. In addition, the informal sector is now recognised as a fundamental resource for social and economic development. Australia's aid program is reflecting this with an increased allocation of funds to micro-enterprise development, with a two-year $1.3 million package for development in the South Pacific and South-East Asia.

The change in the role of the private sector in development is just one example of the way that the aid program has adapted to remain relevant and effective. Another excellent example is provided by this year's launch of the policy document Towards a sustainable future: ecologically sustainable development through Australia's development cooperation program. I am sure that the shadow minister at the table, the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer), would agree that this is a catchy title. Australia's policy in this area fully takes into account the UN Conference on Environment and Development in Rio by defining the importance of integrating the economic, ecological and social dimensions of development.

The past year has also seen the government continue to pursue policies on human rights and good governance through the aid program. On human rights, Australia's policy is to maintain a consistent and principled stand against abuses, while stressing the importance of continued engagement through dialogue and institution building. On good governance,

SPEECH.PARA: Australia's policy encourages the effective management of social and economic resources in developing countries in a manner that is open, transparent, accountable and equitable.

PARA.TAB: As you can see, over the past year we have continued a process of review and adaptation which will ensure that Australia's aid program continues to be of the highest quality, responsive to the needs of developing countries and appropriate to Australia's place in the world.

I would now like to turn to new developments in our overseas assistance in the social sector. The government's policy framework for poverty reduction has three components: firstly, encouraging sustainable economic growth; secondly, investment in human resources through education, health, capacity building and social sector development; and thirdly, provision of safety nets and poverty targeting, including humanitarian relief.

The social sector provides a crucial contribution to sustainable social and economic development. Recent World Bank reports have highlighted the major role that government commitment to social sector development, particularly in education, has played in the rapid growth of many Asian economies. Reflecting this importance, the past two budgets have seen a significant upgrading of the already high priority given to the social sector in the aid program through the introduction of major population and health initiatives.

In the 1993-94 budget, we trebled expenditure on the population sector with a four-year, $130 million initiative. To ensure the effectiveness of this initiative, the government commissioned an independent inquiry into the links between population and development. This was one of the most comprehensive surveys of population and development issues ever undertaken, and its conclusions have been vital in highlighting the complex links between population and development.

The results of this inquiry have helped AIDAB to develop a range of principles which now guide our aid program's population activities. Among the most important of these principles is that access to safe and effective family planning services is a fundamental right, and that women should have access to a wide range of reproductive health services and should participate fully in defining the services they need. Above all—and I want to emphasise this as much as I can—coercion has no place in the Australian aid program's family planning activities.

The priority which the aid program gives to population issues was reflected in the major role that Australia played at the International Conference on Population and Development, held in Cairo in September 1994, at which I was present. Helped by our efforts, the conference adopted a groundbreaking program of action for the empowerment of women and called for major increases in global resources for family planning and health activities.

I would also like to refer to the significant developments in the nature of our assistance to the health sector. Funding for health was given a major boost in the 1994-95 aid budget, with the introduction of a four-year initiative targeting four priority areas: malaria, polio, neonatal tetanus and HIV-AIDS. This initiative involves additional funding of $110 million over the next four years, which nearly doubles Australia's current spending on health under the aid program.

As with our assistance to the population activities, AIDAB has developed a set of principles which will guide this new funding. These principles state that improvements in health are best achieved through an integrated approach which tackles the causes of poverty and improves the status and wellbeing of vulnerable groups, particularly women and children.

Changes are also afoot in Australia's program of assistance to education and training. It is true that assistance to the education sector has always been a large part of the aid program. At present, the sector receives an allocation of a little under 20 per cent of the total budget. The majority of that funding goes towards assistance at the tertiary level. We are now reviewing our assistance in this sector with a view to diversifying the kinds of assistance to include increased support for basic, technical and vocational education.

There is no doubt of the social, economic, health and population gains that are derived from basic education. At the same time, the primary responsibility for the provision of basic education lies with the recipient government—aid should not substitute for that responsibility. That means that our assistance to the education sector must be carefully targeted to assist and strengthen, rather than replace or duplicate, the efforts of national governments.

Finally, I would like to talk about developments in the humanitarian relief program. One of the most tragic features of the past few years has been the continued increase in the frequency and the impact of international emergencies. In the past five years, over 300 million people have been affected by natural disasters and civil strife. Over the past 20 years, the number of refugees has risen from an estimated three million to 23 million, half of whom are children and most of whom are from developing countries.

That is a huge cost in human terms. It is also a huge financial cost. Just to give two examples: the annual expenditure of the UN High Commissioner for Refugees has risen from $US450 million in the mid-1980s to $US1.1 billion in 1993, and the cost of UN peacekeeping operations has risen from under $US1 billion in 1991 to over $US4 billion in 1993. And it is tragic that this trend shows no sign of slowing.

The forces which drive this situation are highly complex and demand an equally complex international response. Factors such as the link between poverty and vulnerability, the increase in political volatility since the end of the Cold War and the proliferation of humanitarian relief agencies have to be taken into account in providing a coordinated response. It was against this backdrop of increasing complexity and growing demand for assistance that early last year AIDAB undertook an extensive review of its refugee and relief program.

The results of this review are helping the government to update Australia's response to international humanitarian emergencies. The review found that Australia's spending on humanitarian relief had not followed the rapid increases of other donors. This relative decline in funding for humanitarian emergencies is in stark contrast to the clear wishes of the Australian public, which has repeatedly demonstrated that it wants our government to respond generously to such humanitarian tragedies as those witnessed in Rwanda. AIDAB is already responding to the recommendations of the review and is also exploring opportunities for increasing funds for humanitarian relief.

As Australia improves its aid response to international humanitarian emergencies, we also share a responsibility with the international community to do more to prevent disasters and complex emergencies from happening in the first place. This is a priority that requires a range of strategies addressing the underlying causes of dispute and conflict. We require improvements in prevention and response strategy through arrangements which minimise threats to security, promote confidence and trust, and create frameworks for dialogue and cooperation. We must also develop peace-building activities to ensure that conflict does not arise in the first place or, if it does, to ensure that it does not recur. That involves strategies which encourage economic and social development, environmental protection, human rights and good governance. Australia will be doing as much as possible through the aid program to support these activities.

In the years ahead, I am confident that Australia will continue to deliver a compassionate and effective aid program that has a real impact on the lives of millions of people throughout the developing world. As I have said before, Australia's future, and the Australian people, demand nothing less.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl)—Before I call the honourable member for Mayo, Minister, in your second paragraph you made reference to a report to be tabled today. Do you actually intend to table something or were you referring to the statement you just made?

TALK.START.PARA: —And here it is. Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. Your attention to detail demands commendation. For the information of honourable members, I present the following paper:

PARA.TAB: New directions in Australia's overseas aid program.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I welcome the opportunity to say a few words on the issue of overseas aid. As I think the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs (Mr Bilney) would be aware, on this side of the House we believe that the purpose of foreign aid is to provide for basic needs in two respects: first, in terms of humanitarian assistance; and, secondly, in terms of assisting with sustainable economic growth.

PARA.TAB: It is important, though, in the context of this debate to outline what aid should not be. It should not be some kind of high level bribery or foreign policy instrument which is cynically used to advance a political interest rather than to advance those basic needs that I spoke of earlier. Secondly, aid should not be used as a way of circumventing GATT rules on international trade and subsidising exports. That is not what our aid program is supposed to be about, and in too many countries around the world aid programs are used for those objectives rather than the fundamental objective of the provision of basic needs.

We on this side of the House have for many years emphasised the need for community based project aid and have expressed in general terms our reservations about what often become big, white elephant, so-called infrastructure projects. Some of them are fine, but we have expressed reservations about there being too much emphasis in our aid program on those sorts of projects.

I wish to address three or four of the issues that arose from the minister's statement. The most controversial issue involves how much aid the government provides. In his statement, the minister claimed that the government demonstrated its commitment to international development by increasing Australia's aid program. That statement is completely disingenuous and the minister knows that it is.

That statement can be measured against three sets of standards: firstly, the standards which the Australian Labor Party set itself before the last election; secondly, world standards; and, thirdly—and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) likes to do this in relation to the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard)—the standards of the previous government. During the 1993 election campaign the Labor Party promised to achieve an aid target of 0.4 per cent of GDP by 1995.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is your policy?

—Forget our policy. Do you remember your own policy, Minister? Do you remember going out there and promising that you would reach the 0.4 per cent target? Of course the minister remembers it, and of course the Prime Minister remembers it. How has the Labor Party measured up to its own standards? According to the Australian Council for Overseas Aid, the Labor government's pre-election pledge to achieve 0.4 per cent of GNP by 1995 was broken only six months after the election.

PARA.TAB: So the government set a standard, recklessly and deceptively, knowing that it would never achieve it. What it has achieved is 0.34 per cent—from my recollection of last year's budget, that was the figure. It would just about crack 0.33 per cent, in fact. That is well short of what the Labor Party promised Australians at the last election. So, according to its own standards, the Australian Labor Party has failed in this area.

The government did something that it should not have done: it said one thing to the Australian people and, on being re-elected, went off and did another thing. If the government intended to reduce aid as a proportion of GNP, why did it not tell the people? Why did it tell them something else? Why did it try to get the votes of the aid groups in the community and of all those Australians who are interested in aid—which is quite a lot of people—by telling them one thing and doing another? You can get away with it once, but you will not get away with it twice.

What about the government's performance against the standards of the rest of the world? Interestingly enough, it was AIDAB which gave me these very good charts. Here is one which deals pretty effectively with the minister's claim that somehow Australia has performed well by OECD standards. This chart shows movements in aid to GNP ratios, conveniently from 1982-83 to 1993—over the life of the Labor government. Of all the countries on the OECD Development Assistance Committee, Australia comes second last. Only the United States has a worse record than Australia in that period. That information was given to me yesterday by AIDAB.
Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek leave to table the chart so that the House has the opportunity to peruse the work of AIDAB and the record of this government: a record which does not match its rhetoric.
Leave not granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The shame of it. I will make sure that this is circulated to the offices of all Labor members because I think they should read it. The government should not say one thing and turn around and do another. The minister claimed in his speech that Australia is above the average for donors in terms of aid to GNP ratios. That is funny. The information from AIDAB shows the unweighted average and the weighted average in 1983. Obviously, the unweighted average should be used. In 1983, Australia was not far above the average, but we were above it. Today, according to AIDAB, we are there and the average is there. It is way below.

PARA.TAB: Here we have the mystique of the weighted average where just about the whole of the weighting is taken up by the United States and Japan; it is under the falsest of all ways of trying to measure your generosity in terms of aid. You know the unweighted average is the only intellectually honest average to use. You are trying to tell the aid community that we have a target of 0.4 per cent. When an election comes you abandon it. You are saying that we are being very generous and that we are above the OECD average because we have worked out some sort of construction of a weighted average which, if I may say so, is the most fanciful piece of actuarial work that I have seen in a very long time. On the basis of the unweighted average, we are way down.

But the most crippling piece of evidence for the Labor Party is that, according to AIDAB itself, our record was the second worst in the OECD over the last dozen years—that is, while Labor has been in office. Against the standards of the previous government, I do not really need to elaborate, except to say that in 1982-83, when we were above the OECD weighted and unweighted averages, Australia's aid was 0.5 per cent of GNP. During the life of the Fraser government, we had a record that has never been closely matched by the Hawke and, of course, now Keating governments.

If I could turn to some of the program issues and make a few points about them, first of all, given that the Jackson report was many years ago, there should be a full and independent review of Australia's cooperation development program. I do not know whether the minister and the government are planning to do that in the near future, but it would be a constructive initiative. If it does not do it within the next year, we will do it during 1996.

The Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs can look forward to reading about it. In your particular case, you will be lucky to know anything about what we are doing in government unless you read the newspapers because you will not be a member here. Kingston is a seat that we look forward very much to taking.

TALK.START.PARA: —Promises.

—We have certainly nearly won it on several occasions, and we have been creeping up at every election. It got very close last time. The second point, though, is in relation to educational assistance and development. The government and the minister claim that nearly 20 per cent of the total aid budget is spent on education. That sounds quite good when you put it that way. But, as the minister pointed out, the vast majority is in fact spent on scholarship assistance at the tertiary level.

PARA.TAB: To be fair—and I always am fair—the minister's own statement of the need to review assistance in the educational sector, to use his words, `with a view to diversifying the kinds of assistance to include increased support for basic technical and vocational education' is a good statement and is very much in line with coalition policy. The more you read our statements and start to implement them, the more support you will get from us. There will be no hypocrisy from us.

My third point relates to Australian sponsored training scholarships. In the ASTS scheme, the recipient government nominates students, who are usually officials in key positions in that country's public sector, to study in Australian tertiary institutions. The minister concedes the point that, with so much weight given to that program, our contribution in terms of education is not as effective as it could be. I was glad to read what the minister had to say on that count in his speech.

As far as health is concerned, the Australian Council for Overseas Aid says that only 3.6 per cent of bilateral aid is spent on health. I do not know whether the government agrees with that figure. Over the years, health has been a seriously neglected aspect of our aid programs, so we would welcome the greater focus on that issue. There are things that are good and there are things that are less good in what the government has been doing here.

I turn to the issue of aid and human rights. The link between aid and human rights must be reviewed very carefully. Obviously, we have to avoid hurting people who are the innocent victims of regimes which show no respect for human rights. That is a very important point to make. The answer I suppose is to decrease the reliance of government to government aid in those circumstances and to increase aid delivery to the community level through AIDAB and non-government organisations.

This government basically rejects the link between aid donations and human rights. That has been the rhetoric of the government and, on many occasions, certainly the activity of the government. However, the government has suspended aid to Burma until the SLORC makes clear-cut reforms. Is the government, in rejecting any link between aid and human rights, turning around and saying that it has a different policy in relation to Burma? Or is it conceding that there is a role for human rights and decisions about aid volumes and directions? The government cannot have it both ways. I think the government needs to make its position on that issue much clearer than it is at the moment.

The government has shown a great deal of enthusiasm for increasing aid to Vietnam. When the Prime Minister visited Vietnam, he announced a very substantial increase in aid. That country, which is now by far the largest recipient of Australian aid in Indochina, does not have a great record on human rights. Vietnam's record on human rights has not been of much concern to the government. But, quite rightly, the government has been concerned with Burma's record on human rights. The government needs to think through—as I think it does generally with its foreign policy—a lot more carefully where human rights fit into its aid policy so as to articulate a clear and coherent policy. Then those opposite can escape from charges of hypocrisy as everybody will know where they stand. The problem with so much of this debate about aid is that the rhetoric comes out to suit the moment, but the principles underlying the policy are never clear. I think we have established that matter pretty clearly in the course of this debate.

I would like to raise many other matters but, to be fair to the other honourable members, time does not permit. In summary, the coalition welcomes the fact that this statement has been made. It provides an opportunity for some discussion on this crucial issue. We urge greater focus on basic health, education and other community level developments in our aid program. We have been concerned about some of the massive infrastructure projects, of which I spoke earlier. We have to be very careful about the way in which those things are handled. We need to be particularly cautious about the downstream economic benefits that might flow to the recipient country.

We need to review the trade subsidy levels as a percentage of the aid budget. Those levels look high—although I understand the economic arguments. I think a great deal more thought needs to be given to that matter. We need to clarify and implement human rights principles in our aid program that are coherent and consistent. As I said earlier, we also need a comprehensive review of a development cooperation program in this country. It is well overdue now, as many years have past since the last independent review was carried out.

We need further debate in Australia about the nature of our aid, its direction and its underlying principles rather than just one question being asked of the amount of aid provided. Obviously, you cannot be trusted in relation to the amount of aid provided. It does not matter what you say before the next election because, in the unlikely event of your getting re-elected, what you actually do will be totally at variance with what you say. Forget making any promises on that front, because nobody will believe them. If you address some of those other issues, I think the aid program might start to come together a little more coherently.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with standing order 28A, on behalf of the Committee of Members' Interests, I present the report on the operations of the committee for 1994.

—On behalf of the parliamentary Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities, I present the committee's advisory report on the First Corporate Law Simplification Bill 1994, together with the minutes of proceedings and evidence received by the committee.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—The First Corporate Law Simplification Bill 1994 was referred to the committee by the House on 8 February 1995 for consideration and report to the House by 27 February 1995. On 27 February, the House agreed that the time for presentation of the committee's report be extended to today.

PARA.TAB: The bill amends the Corporations Law and is the first bill under the corporate law simplification program. The bill deals with share buybacks, proprietary companies and registers. A feature of the bill is its plain English style and language. Following its referral by the House, the committee examined the bill, having particular regard to matters raised during the debate on the bill in the House on 8 February.

The committee referred matters raised in debate in the House to the corporations law simplification task force and other interested bodies for their response. On Wednesday 22 February, the committee conducted a public hearing on the bill in Melbourne. The witnesses who appeared before the committee included representatives of accounting bodies, the Law Council of Australia, the Australian Finance Conference and the simplification task force.

On Tuesday 28 February, the committee held further discussions with the simplification task force and with Mr Leigh Hall, chair of the Corporations Law Simplification Consultative Group. The committee acknowledges the considerable effort of all those who have participated in the task force's consultative process and those who have provided the committee with submissions or who appeared before the committee at its public hearing. The committee notes that an extensive consultative process has been undertaken during the preparation and drafting of the bill. The bill has received general support from the investment, professional and user groups interested in the bill.

The starting point of the committee's report is that, subject to specific matters mentioned in its report, the committee considers the bill should be passed by the parliament. Having said that, in relation to a number of concerns raised with or by the committee, where strong or different views were firmly held by individual members of the committee, the committee endeavoured to be of most assistance to the House by seeking to find as much common ground as possible and openly make on-balance judgments and leave some issues for consideration by the Attorney-General and debate in the parliament.

I deal in turn with some principal issues raised about the bill which the committee has examined in some detail. The first concern was whether the division of proprietary companies into small and large companies as proposed by the bill be adopted, or whether a reporting entity test proposed by the accounting bodies be adopted. The committee found this a difficult matter to resolve.

The committee concluded on balance that the test proposed by the bill should be adopted, as the reporting entity test does not provide a test of sufficient certainty to allow an objective assessment to be made of whether a company falls within the reporting entity test when compared with the small-large distinction provided in the bill. Particularly in view of the Australian Securities Commission submission that the test in the bill provides a simple and objective test which, from a regulator's and a company's view point will not lead to any uncertainty about whether the requirement to lodge accounts applies, the committee concluded that the small-large test be supported over the reporting entity test. By way of aside, I should make the point that on this issue Senator McGauran has provided the House with a dissenting report.

The second concern was whether the criteria proposed in the bill for distinguishing between small and large proprietary companies be adopted in whole or in part. The test proposes that a company would move from a small to a large proprietary company when it had two out of the following three criteria: more than 50 employees, a gross operating revenue of more than $10 million, and assets of more than $5 million.

The simplification task force indicated that the effect of using a one out of three test would cause more companies than desirable to fall within the large company category. The practical effect of setting up a one out of three test would negate the intended effect of the scheme, namely, to reduce the unnecessary regulatory burden on small business. The task force also indicated that the effect of setting up a three out of three test would be to impose an unnecessarily restrictive test which would undesirably limit the number of large companies that would be obliged to prepare accounts.

The committee has found the resolution of questions about an appropriate test for defining a small or large proprietary company extremely difficult. The committee believes that, of the three criteria provided in the bill, the tests of assets and turnover are far and away the most important. The committee believes these two tests must be included in criteria for distinguishing small from large proprietary companies.

The committee was much less convinced that a necessary test for distinguishing a small company was whether a company has more than 50 employees. The committee was unable to reach an unqualified view on the test, and believes that the Attorney-General should give serious consideration to two options, namely, that the 50 employees criterion should remain, or that the test of more than 50 employees be deleted from the bill and the test for a small-large proprietary company be on the proposed assets and turnover criteria.

The third concern was whether a register of debenture holders as provided in the bill should be public. The committee considered that convertible debentures should be treated in the same manner as shares and options and that the bill not be changed so far as it relates to convertible debentures. However, there seems to be insufficient reason to automatically treat other debentures in the same manner. The committee recommends that a register be kept of debentures, other than convertible debentures, but that access to the register should be subject to the same Australian Securities Commission power of exemption as at present, together with the privacy regime implemented by the bill.

A range of other issues were considered in some detail by the committee. One was the number of shareholders and directors in a proprietary company. In relation to the creation of single member proprietary company, as proposed by the bill, the committee has accepted that there should be single member companies. This change will particularly do away with the perennial problem of two-person companies where a company has two directors, with one director an `active' director, and another director—often a spouse or partner—a `silent' director.

The silent director has usually taken no actual role in the running of such companies. The situation which has arisen all too often is that a company fails, due to no fault of the silent director. The resulting financial problems for a silent director, who is usually jointly liable for the failed company's liabilities, is often referred to in the case of spouses as `sexually transmitted debt'.

The bill proposes the incorporation of a small business guide in the body of the Corporations Law. Some members of the committee had significant reservations about this method of drafting, believing, as a matter of principle, that material not forming part of the law should not be included in legislation. The committee believes the inclusion of the guide in the Corporations Law is an innovative measure, and considers that any risk it poses is outweighed by the benefits it promises. The committee has, however, recommended that inclusion of the guide in the act itself be subject to review by the Attorney-General after it has been in operation for a reasonable time.

In relation to provisions governing the audit of accounts of proprietary companies, the committee would be concerned at any watering down of prescriptions as to who can audit the financial records of a registered company. The committee does not consider that the matters raised by the accounting bodies requires an amendment to the bill, but expects that the problem highlighted by the accounting bodies in their submission and evidence will be addressed by the audit and accounting working party set up under the simplification process.

The Corporations Law confers considerable discretion on the ASC in its power to require preparation of financial reports, and in many other areas. The ASC already publishes policy statements indicating the way in which it will administer the Corporations Law, practice notes for the guidance of practitioners on reporting and compliance matters, and class orders modifying the law in relation to classes or persons. However, the committee does not believe that a broad examination of the use by the ASC of its discretionary powers is appropriate in the context of this bill.

Given that the ASC intends publishing its guidelines in respect of requiring small proprietary companies to prepare accounts, the committee considers that the bill should be passed in its present form in this respect. The committee, however, also believes that the ASC should prepare a quarterly report to the Attorney-General stating the reasons it has given in the relevant quarter for requiring small proprietary companies to prepare accounts, and that the report provided to the Attorney-General be tabled in parliament.

I wish to make some concluding comments about the simplification process itself. As part of its statutory duties to monitor the national scheme laws, the committee has monitored the establishment and progress of the simplification process and the consultative process which that has involved. The committee is conscious that, due to its extensive nature, the consultative process will occasionally give rise to provisions that do not meet the approval of all groups in the process. The inquiry has shown the committee a number of examples of such a situation.

However, in the light of recent discussions with the task force and during the inquiry into this bill, the committee is satisfied with the effectiveness of the task force's consultative process. Indeed, the committee is strongly of the view that the process followed by the task force is a great improvement on past practice and supports its continuation. The committee will continue to monitor the simplification and consultative process as part of its role of scrutiny of the administration and development of the national corporate law scheme.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Mrs B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I came to the Joint Statutory Committee on Corporations and Securities as a newly appointed member after the First Corporate Law Simplification Bill had been introduced into the House. My initial concern, as I said at the time, was that one of the intended consequences of the bill could well have been that the Labor Party would have the opportunity of no longer filing accounts for its operative companies which deal with its money, finance its elections and deal with its property. I set those concerns out in my speech in the second reading debate.

PARA.TAB: When I came onto the committee and started to look at the bill in totality, I saw that there were some matters of quite considerable concern that needed to be investigated to a greater extent. The report as it is being presented today, recommending that the legislation be passed, has dealt with some of the concerns in a satisfactory way, but some remarks need to be made to indicate that there are ongoing concerns which may have to be dealt with in the future.

Clearly, the most contentious issue was the decision to introduce a new test for which proprietary companies should be required to lodge their accounts and returns with the Australian Securities Commission and which companies should not. This is not a novel proposition in that the situation already exists where companies are broken into those required to file and those not required to file. The old test was the exempt and non-exempt test—a complicated test. The simplification process should be commended, but there are some examples in the bill where, in an attempt to simplify, we are perhaps slipping into some shoddy practices. The member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner) may address some of those in his remarks, as he made the point quite well during the committee hearing. There are one or two others as well.

To turn to the most contentious issue: the introduction of the new test of when you shall be required to file accounts and when you shall not be required to file accounts is now known as the small-large test. That means that, under the current bill, if you are a company and you meet two out of three criteria set down in the bill, you will be excused from filing your accounts. I asked: why were these three criteria chosen? What sort of evidence was presented to the consultative group or, indeed, to us as members of the committee that said that this is a good way to proceed? Or did somebody just wake up one day and say, `This looks like a good idea'?

The answer seems to be that there was a paper prepared for the consultative group. In evidence the chairman of that group—and he spoke with the committee—said that there is such a test in operation in the United Kingdom and New Zealand and he thought in Canada but he could not remember.

Upon further inquiry it became apparent that the United Kingdom had the two out of three test, but New Zealand, which has more recently introduced a test for large and small, has a two out of two test. The chairman of the committee has already addressed the fact that we had a large number of submissions dealing with a different form of test altogether. But once the committee had decided that it was interested in recommending the large-small test, the question of what criteria should be met became a focus.

It is important to say that what became apparent is that the system we are introducing has been lifted from the United Kingdom system. When I asked the following question of one of the members of the task force: `Was our system just like the United Kingdom system?', he said, `It's very close, but we had to make some adjustments on money.' I will go into that in a minute.

When it came to the New Zealand question, we had no evidence at all. We do not know why New Zealand chose two out of two instead of two out of three. We do not know whether or not the test in the United Kingdom works well or works badly. We saw no evidence. None was brought to the committee. On this very point, I feel that perhaps we should have been in a position to do a more thorough job.
I will go to the three criteria that are listed in the bill. They state:

SPEECH.PARA: A proprietary company is a small proprietary company for a financial year if it satisfies at least 2 of the following paragraphs:
(a)the consolidated gross operating revenue for the financial year of the company and the entities it controls (if any) is less than $10 million
(b)the value of the gross consolidated assets at the end of a financial year of the company and the entities it controls (if any) is less than $5 million
(c)the company and the entities it controls (if any) have fewer than 50 employees at the end of the financial year.

If your company complies with two out of the three criteria, you are excused. That is the position in the United Kingdom. The New Zealanders have said that, if you have consolidated operating revenue for the financial year of a set sum of dollars, around $10 million, or if the value of your gross consolidated assets at the end of the year is less than a certain figure—we say $5 million; they have a figure of their own—then you are excused from filing. If it is greater than those two figures, you must file.

PARA.TAB: In this country, if you are a large company which has a gross operating revenue of $12 million a year—so you are above the test—and gross consolidated assets at the end of the financial year of $10 million, above the $5 million, and if in the month of May you have 60 employees on your books, you would be caught. You would have to file. But if you decided to fire 15 employees or of the 60 people you had working for you only 45 were employees, the rest were casual, contract labour or the like, you could drop one of the really substantive tests and say, `We have got fewer than 50 employees, so we are excused. We do not have to disclose what our returns are.'

I think that is a test which militates against employment and against allowing sunshine onto the accounts and the affairs of corporations. When we said that we could not form an unqualified view, that is a perfectly accurate statement. It certainly was an unqualified view. We have asked that the Attorney-General look further into this matter.

In fairness, it would be very sensible if the Attorney-General could take a very good look at the New Zealanders' experience and assess why they rejected the United Kingdom test which we have adopted and how well or how badly it works for them. There was some confusion even in the mind of the chairman of the consultative group. When I said, `If you meet three out of three, more people would be caught,' he expressed a contrary view. That was cleared up later. But the bottom line is that it remained a matter of some confusion as to why it was the right or the wrong decision.

A couple of other things were quite important. There was an effort originally to show that the professions that were affected by this legislation were all gung-ho and in favour of it. That is not true either. The Law Council of Australia was split. The insolvency committee said:

SPEECH.PARA: To suggest to people in business that certain advantages are available only while their companies remain "small" is short sighted and counter-productive.

However, the corporate committee of the Law Council of Australia thought it was a great test. So there is confusion in the ranks. The Institute of Chartered Accountants and the CPAs said they did not like the test and wanted another test. There is still a lot of debate out in the community.

PARA.TAB: The other thing it is important to say is that, whilst we are introducing simplified legislation, let us do what we say. We are moving to have legislation that says when Fred Smith, businessman, or Joanna Smith, businesswoman, picks up a piece of legislation, he or she can see what it really means. But, still, in the body of the drafting we have definitions by implication. We have a list that we have defined within the body of the legislation as to who can be a proprietary company, who is eligible to be subject to the large-small test and who is not. A public company cannot be a proprietary company; but we do not say what it is to be a public company.

A note to me this morning from the corporations law simplification program said that there will be another bill coming in. I look forward to that. By implication, the bill defines what you have to be to be a proprietary company. If you do not fit that, you are a public company. But then there is an additional definition saying that a company which is limited by both shares and guarantee may not be a proprietary company. That is new, but it makes it clear. I think it would have been sensible to add that a company that is limited by guarantee alone is also a public company. Somebody who picks up the legislation could then clearly read it rather than having it implied from the new section 116 which, by implication, defines a public company.

This bill is a good start and the work of the committee of this House is going to be more important as we proceed. One of the implicit difficulties with moving to plain English in an attempt to simplify the law is that you can create uncertainty instead of certainty. By moving away from certain set legal phrases which have defined meanings we could move to new phrases which have undefined meanings; and uncertainty can result. That is why I felt very sympathetic to Mr Tanner who has concerns about putting the small business guide into the act.

This is a beginning. I commend the idea of making law readily available to people because I have a fundamental problem with the concept that the law shall be the law by which we are bound but ordinary folk find it incomprehensible. For the same reason, I hope to goodness that one day we will move to some sensible simplification in the area of tax law. But at least in this area we have begun, with the requirement that the Australian Securities Commission will now flag its guidelines as to when it will require additional proprietary companies to file. We are starting to see some accountability return in that area as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I, too, applaud the work of the corporations law simplification task force and also the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) in heading down this path to simplification of the Corporations Law. I will make a couple of comments on some of the matters raised by the honourable member for Mackellar (Mrs Bishop). With respect to the absence of any reference in our report to the company being limited by guarantee, we have a difference about that. In my view the position is perfectly clear elsewhere in the legislation, in section 116, which she referred to. It was unnecessary for us to make reference to that. This issue, to the extent that it will be dealt with in any way by simplification processes, will be dealt with in a subsequent bill. It should be noted that this is the First Corporate Law Simplification Bill 1994 and deals only with certain sections of the law.

PARA.TAB: I would also like to refer to the question of the so-called small-large test and, in particular, the limb with respect to 50 employees. I disagree with the suggestion of the member for Mackellar that that militates against employment. I think it is beyond comprehension that any company will be so motivated to avoid the need to report or to file returns that it would dismiss employees or go through all sorts of convoluted arrangements in order to bring itself below the 50 employees. I do not agree with that concern.

However, it is fair to say, as the committee reported, that this particular limb of the test is clearly of lesser importance than the other two limbs. That is, in my view, primarily because it is actually less certain when you consider factors like having full-time and casual employees who may work only every now and then—every few weeks or every few months. Clearly, it is less certain than the other tests with respect to assets and turnover. For that reason, the committee has reported that the Attorney-General should give consideration to the merits of this particular limb of the test.

However, the broader point that does prevail on this issue is: where do you draw the line? At one end of the spectrum, we have large proprietary companies that should be filing accounts and reporting. That is obviously in the community's interest. At the other end of the spectrum, we have very small companies for which filing accounts and reporting is an onerous obligation and one that really does not serve any great community or public purpose, but puts the people who are running those companies into expense and difficulty. What we are seeking to do here is to meet two ultimately competing imperatives, and in the middle there are companies in a borderline situation where it would be difficult to have an obvious answer as to whether or not they should report.

The trick is to develop a test that is certain. The reason that we ultimately supported the simplification task force's test, rather than the so-called reporting entity test as proposed by the chartered accountants, was the greater certainty of the simplification task force's proposed test. A test should also have companies falling on the right side of the line, depending on whether it is in the public interest that they report or not report.

The ironic thing about the view expressed by the honourable member for Mackellar is that—given that she has, in the past, put herself forward as a strong defender of the rights of small business—if it were actually enacted, it would lead to at least some small businesses who, under the task force's regime, would not have to report actually being included and having to report. They would then be faced with the problem of additional expense, paperwork and a bigger bureaucracy. The intention of this legislation is to relieve that burden. Although I do not question the motives of the honourable member for Mackellar, I think an unfortunate consequence of her position—or one that may well be—is that people in small business are actually exposed to a greater obligation of unnecessary, at least in some instances, reporting and providing accounts.

The final comment I make is with respect to a matter that the honourable member for Mackellar gave me glowing praise for, which, no doubt, I will find difficult to live down—that is, the issue of the small business guide and its inclusion within the legislation. It is fair to say that this is something of an unusual or innovative step in that a document which purports to be advice about the content of legislation and about what it means—a user's guide—is actually being incorporated as part of the act of parliament.

At first blush that offended my notion of what an act of parliament is about. In my view, it is there to create obligations, rights and laws that apply to all of the community; it is not to advise the community about what the law actually is. There are some inherent dangers in that with respect to both judicial interpretation of the law and the rights and obligations of professionals who are advising users of the law. A blurring of the distinction between an act of parliament and advice about an act of parliament is a worry.

However, in the spirit of cooperation, I have been prepared to give this the benefit of the doubt. Therefore, I feel that the committee's recommendation that the Attorney-General review the operation of this section of the legislation, at a subsequent point, is worth while. I would like to place on record that, if this type of approach to the process of legislation is to spread to other areas, I may not be quite so generous.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—First, I would like to re-emphasise a point that has been made by a number of speakers. Simplification of laws should not make law unintelligible or difficult to identify. It worries me that we have identified in this advisory report of the Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities on the First Corporate Law Simplification Bill the share buyback provisions, for example, more on the number of words than on the degree to which they are understandable. Not only is simplification something that is needed but also it is a matter of consolidating the law.

PARA.TAB: I have long been concerned that, as in this instance, we are adding another bill to the heap instead of consolidating the law and making the law understandable by reference to one bill alone. I would hope that, at the end of this review process, one piece of legislation is introduced which incorporates all the amendments, thereby making it a lot easier for those who need to turn to the law to know what the law is.

I would also like to compliment the members of the Corporations Law Simplification Consultative Group, particularly Mr Leigh Hall, and the members of the simplification task force. It is essential that, if law is to be changed, those who are practitioners in the field are consulted so that it is not just a matter of modification within the Public Service in Canberra. In that sense the reference to the committee was valuable, although it is very difficult with the sort of inquiry that we made to take account of the views of those who operate proprietary companies, as they are now formed in the exempt category, and to be sure that the new requirements meet the bill.

In some respects I am still unhappy with the version we have reached on the definitions of `small' and `large'. Earlier speakers have made some reference to the three criteria. I am one of those who believe that the number of employees really should be excluded because I cannot see how it adds to the system.

New Zealand has moved far further than Australia in modification of their corporations law. It seems to have learned from the American practice rather than relying peculiarly on our British heritage. I am interested to see that the present Australian government, which seeks to set aside its British connection in so many respects, prefers it in this area.

For my part, I would have preferred to follow the New Zealand practice and thereby have only two obligatory criteria. The criteria are the gross operating revenue and the assets of the company, and the number of employees should be excluded. In the report itself we have left the conclusion on that point a little ambivalent. For my part, I am not at all ambivalent; I think it would be far better if we excluded that criterion relating to the number of employees and maintained the requirement that all companies who exceed the gross operating revenue and the assets test figures that are set in the bill to file their accounts.

There are several other aspects of the bill which I want to address. The first one that is mentioned in the report is the number of directors. I am concerned that the conclusion has been reached that only one director will be sufficient for a proprietary company under this new category of a small company.

I believe that the recommendations of the insolvency committee of the Law Council of Australia, which suggested there was still an advantage in retaining two directors, should have been followed. In part, this is because I have always felt that it is necessary to distinguish a company from an individual and, to the degree to which you make a company identical, I think there is a disadvantage. For all that we refer to sexually transmitted debt in the text of the report, it is my view that having two directors places a greater obligation on an individual running a corporation. I think it would have been preferable to have taken the view of the insolvency committee of the Law Council in that respect.

A number of aspects of auditing and accounting standards have been mentioned briefly. However, there is another inquiry now being conducted by the task force and the consultative group into those aspects. I look forward to the bill that will return in due course for us to consider whether or not those aspects should be included. I hope that we will be able to look at that report through the same committee structure. There are a number of aspects of accounting standards and audit requirements which I think could well be included in the legislation, and I hope they shall be in the future, once again, to make the legislation a little more understandable by both members of the accounting profession and their clients.

The other two matters in the report to which I referred were, first, there is a capacity within the ASC to require that accounts should be tabled even though the company might be excluded by the criteria prescribed. The committee has concluded that it would be advisable for the ASC to table reasons, through the minister, by reporting on three-monthly intervals the reasons for those requirements.

I was very pleased to see that the ASC intends to publish the reporting requirements and, generally, the ways in which it intends to administer the changes to the legislation. But it would be helpful if there were to be tabled by the minister on three-monthly intervals the practice intended to be followed by the ASC—and there is reference to that in paragraphs 283 and 284 of this report.

The other matter that I wanted briefly to refer to, as I understand the matter is not to be debated in the Senate, is the fact that my colleague Senator Julian McGauran has filed a dissenting report. There was considerable debate in the committee about the reporting entity test which was favoured by the Society of Certified Practising Accountants, the Institute of Chartered Accountants and by others who gave evidence to the committee. Mr Leigh Hall, the chairman of the consultative group, suggested that he at one stage had also been in favour of that reporting entity test to distinguish between small and large companies.

My own view is that it becomes too confusing, and it was on that basis that I accepted the alternative. While I wanted to mention that dissenting report, the majority of the committee certainly felt that the reporting entity test was too confusing and, therefore, should not have been followed. At the same time, I repeat my assertion that the legislation would have been far better if only two of the three requirements now included in the present bill before the House were required. They are that the asset and turnover tests should be appropriate, as in New Zealand, instead of providing the opportunity for the number of employees also to be taken into account.

It is important that we simplify legislation. At the same time, when there are changes as fundamental as these and when concerns have been expressed, as they have been, I would hope that the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) does not feel that the legislation is necessarily written in stone. It is legislation that needs to be reconsidered from time to time. I hope that when the subsequent reports from the consultative group are before this chamber, we might have an opportunity to perhaps review some of the matters and their practice in the report that is now being adopted into the First Corporate Law Simplification Bill and that, ultimately, we might have a consolidated piece of legislation which would be of far more use to the practising public.
Debated resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I commend the people who have taken part in the report from the parliamentary Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities. When the NCSC bill was introduced, it ran for three days with two speakers; when the ASC bill was introduced by Lionel Bowen, it went for four days with two speakers; and the First Corporate Law Simplification Bill has gone for half an hour with four speakers. The knowledge and interest in company law is quite astonishing—it must be one of the few growth industries left.

PARA.TAB: Along the lines of the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), I purely want to add my caution to some of the developments that have come out of the report. Simplification is a very desirable path. Those who work in company law or in taxation law will know that in the last few years it has become an absolute nightmare to try to get to some concrete decisions and finally know where you stand. It is even more so in tax and company law. These movements are in the right direction and are full of good intent but, like all matters of good intent, they are paved with a lot of uncertainty.

One of the problems with small business is management. The failure of small business in the main, while it is always blamed on something else, in very large measure is a question of management. The best tool of management is proper accounts, and proper accounts will be kept only if there is a compulsory requirement to report on them.

The proposal here brings forward the concept of one director. That is a very fine concept. But a lot of people in business would ask, `Why do you need this?' In terms of accountability and responsibility, in recent times there has been a lot of talk about wayward creditors. We have heard about the big ones in the newspapers, but there are thousands of small ones who walk away from bankruptcy petitions under circumstances of loose accounts, no accounts at all or with pure cash situations.

Therefore I would like the committee to take into consideration the creditors' and debtors' positions—it is not only the income tax commissioner's particular problem—as they relate to ordinary commerce and the desirability of going to one director rather than having two. The honourable member for Mackellar (Mrs Bishop) referred to some matters earlier. I think she would have drawn attention to the case of a proprietary company involved in a family law action where, if it is run by one company director and a residual partner, there would be no access to those accounts so they would not necessarily know what was going on. Therefore in a normal family business it would be prudent, I would have thought, to look to those matters.

Finally, on the question of audit, when the committee refers this to the expert committee involved I hope that genuine consideration will be given to finding a way to ensure that proper accounts are kept, even on the say-so of the auditor who could state that he has lodged a taxation return based on the corporate accounts. This may be beneficial towards keeping some form of management tool alive and well in small business.
Debated resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Henzell Ms M.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not had an opportunity to read the Hansard of yesterday's debate on the Tobacco Advertising Prohibition Amendment Bill 1995, but I suspect we will find an interesting coalescence of points of view from all sides of the House and some strange bedfellows in the debate. But that is all to the good, and I am sure that the majority of people in the House will definitely support the government's record.

PARA.TAB: This amendment bill is aimed to clarify the scope of the Tobacco Advertising Prohibition Act 1992, and is part of a positive program by the government. We have a very proud record on legislation in this area; in fact, the World Health Organisation sees us as a world leader on this matter. An article by Adrian Bradley in the Australian on 31 May 1994 stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The nation's anti-tobacco legislation remains at the forefront of international moves to ban cigarette advertising, providing the World Health Organisation with a blueprint for moves to persuade Western Pacific countries to introduce similar measures.

Why is this important? It is important because the World Health Organisation estimates that three million people die each year from smoking related illnesses and it expects this to increase to 10 million a year by the year 2020. In Australia about 3.5 million Australians smoke, representing 28 per cent of people over the age of 18 years. This is falling, with 32 per cent of men and 24.7 per cent of women smoking.

PARA.TAB: Part of that change has been the move away from the availability of advertising. I suspect that, like me, Mr Deputy Speaker Scott will remember the Peter Stuyvesant advertisements—London, Paris, New York—at the Saturday afternoon flicks, which is where we used to go in the world before television.
