Mr Deputy Speaker may not remember that; he may be too young. But, in those days, overseas travel and all the sophistication that involved was a great model for those of us who aspired to that. Part and parcel of that was cigarette smoking. We have seen a major change due to government policy and a rearguard action from some of the national cigarette companies, culminating in a High Court challenge to some of our legislation.

I wish to draw to the attention of the House the need for members in this place to observe the very proper and appropriate rulings of the Speaker and the President in relation to smoking in the precincts of the parliament. There are rules that all employees of the parliament must adhere to, and it concerns me greatly that certain members in this place feel that it is quite appropriate for them to inflict passive smoking on the rest of us. I urge all of my colleagues to walk outside if they must smoke. We will try to get away from that cigarette smoke in the garden areas.

It is very important that all adults act as effective role models. As we curtail opportunities to promote cigarette messages, one of the important issues we have to address is young people taking up smoking. In her article by the Drug Education Journal of Australia entitled `Peter Jackson, you're lying: education or advertising—which message is more convincing?' Margaret Powell outlines the importance of the communicated message. She states:

SPEECH.PARA: In our consumer-oriented society, there is another force operating in children's lives. Independence and adulthood are seen to be manifested through appealing images which are used skilfully by advertising agencies to sell products, to sell cigarettes. Despite the wide public acceptance of detrimental effects of smoking among children and their peers, smoking cigarettes is seen to respect independence, maturity, vitality, popularity and success.

We find that young people, particularly those in puberty and perhaps even from grade 7, see smoking as an important rite of passage. This is something we have to address not only by removing those public images but also by sending very positive anti-smoking messages and providing children with assertiveness training. It is absolutely essential that cigarette manufacturers not be allowed to sponsor sport or cultural activities. I believe that, as we have continued to curtail this activity, other companies have taken up the slack and are now sponsoring major sporting events. I believe that, when cigarette manufacturers are banned from sponsoring sporting events, the current consumer acquiescence to sponsorship of sport will also change.

PARA.TAB: The other issue we have to address is the way cigarette companies are using value adding programs to entice young people to smoke. It is certainly something we will have to address because, often, the people targeted are those who are most likely to be affected by smoking. For instance, in the Australian of 3 February 1995, a reference is made to a Senate submission in relation to a Northern Territory individual. The article mentions a promotion being offered to stores in Top End Aboriginal communities. The promotion involves a free T-shirt with the community name on the back and a `big country' and `Malboro' advertising slogan on the front. All these initiatives are encouraging young people to smoke and are trying to get around our advertising bans. I look forward to continuing my comments after question time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 3.00 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with standing order 101A. The debate may be resumed at a later hour and the member for Capricornia will have leave to continue speaking when the debate is resumed.

PARA.TAB: Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Last August when the current account deficit grew to $1.8 billion for the month, you dismissed it by saying `It is after all only one month's figures' and that what we were `seeing this time is a limitation in the rise'—I repeat, a limitation in the rise—in the current account deficit. Given that since then the current account deficit has risen to the highest monthly and three-monthly levels ever recorded, and given that six of the last seven monthly results have been above $2 billion, do you seriously still suggest that we are seeing a limitation in the rise, to use your own words? Will you continue to dismiss each new record as just one month's figures?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought the Treasurer made the government's position about this very clear when he announced the mid-year review and said what we thought the influences on the current account would be. I think that quoting some number after the Treasurer has actually given a considered view by the Treasury forecasters and has made it public in the mid-year review answers the point. The underlying point is that the current account deficit is up in part because of the very strong rise in the capital goods components.
—So it is a good thing, is it?
—Order!
—Just listen for a second. You might learn something.
—Are you pleased about it?
—Once you get past Dollar Sweets and a few simple nostrums about master-servant relationships—

—Order! The Prime Minister might wait for a moment. Question time will not degenerate into an opportunity for people to constantly interject. The Prime Minister has been asked a question by the Leader of the Opposition, who I think is trying to listen to the answer.

—Capital goods are up 23 per cent in the first seven months of the year. A primary requirement for this economy is to be able to produce goods and services. We do not have huge capital goods, producer goods, industries. All of these, whether they be mainframe computers or digitally operated machine tools, come from the large industrial economies where the economies of scale can see the development of these industries.
—It shows you are spending money you do not have.
—Order! I warn the member for Ryan!

—But we need them to add to our capital stock to be able to produce more goods and services. Also in that month exports were up four per cent and imports were down three. While growth in exports has slowed in recent months, manufacturing exports have performed particularly well. An interesting number here is that, for the year to the September quarter, exports of elaborately transformed goods were up 19 per cent. How different it is that manufactured and elaborately transformed exports have been growing so strongly—and again in this month by over 19 per cent—compared with the old decaying industrial archaeology that this government inherited.

PARA.TAB: But an even more important point is our ability to fund the deficit. Akin to this question is a mortgage and one's capacity to pay and meet the mortgage obligations. What are they here? We have a strong capital goods base, which is growing. We are making inroads into new markets with manufacturing and production. Our debt servicing ratio—that is, the proportion of our exports which is going to servicing our debt—has fallen from just on 21 per cent in the late 1980s to 11 per cent today at last count. That is, the proportion of the country's exports which are actually committed to servicing our debt has fallen by over half since the late 1980s—that is, from 21 per cent to 11 per cent.

The other underlying strong point is that we are now 40 per cent more competitive than a decade ago. If you add up that continuing competitiveness—that is, the low inflation and the high productivity, the very large real depreciation of the exchange rate over the last six or eight years, the growth in manufacturing and manufactured exports, the growth in exports as a proportion of GDP from 14 to 21 per cent and the decline in the debt service component from 21 to 11 per cent—you can see that they are unambiguously bald points about Australia's capacity to service its debt.

Another point worth making can be found in the latest bulletin of the Australian Bureau of Statistics, Measuring Australia. It looks at our net debt, which it shows as being about $160 billion, but it also shows something which we never hear from the opposition: that is, Australian investment abroad is $120 billion. Of that $120 billion—

TALK.START.PARA: —But we are losing out—
—Order! The member for Mitchell!
—Let me just explain this for those who do not understand.
—A deficit dalek.
—Deficits, deficits!
—The Deputy Leader of the Opposition!
—Every dollar that has been invested abroad by Australians—
—For debt, debt, debt; understand?
—Nyet? Nyet? Nyet?
—The Deputy Leader of the Opposition will cease interjecting.

—Every dollar that has been invested abroad by Australians has been borrowed on the current account. If we take from that $120 billion of Australian assets abroad, the Reserve Bank's official assets abroad, about $80 billion of private investment abroad has occurred since this government removed exchange controls in 1983-84. There was no investment abroad before 1983-84. It has risen from virtually nothing to $80 billion by the current year.
—It is less.
—The member for Goldstein!

—Let me give them the simple numbers. If that $80 billion had not been invested offshore, it would have had a huge impact on the net debt—maybe not from $160 to $80 billion but certainly of that order. Why do Australian firms invest abroad? Why is Boral the largest brick and tile manufacturer in the United States?
—Because they cannot make a dollar here.
—I warn the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. I again remind those on my left who are interjecting of standing order 55.
—The statistician says, `Australia's investment in foreign countries for a variety of'—
—It is you who has got rich.
—I warn the member for Mackellar about her constant interjecting as well.
—The statistician has this to say:

ANSWER.PARA: Australians invest in foreign countries for a variety of reasons, including the securing and maintenance of market share, sales promotion, effective marketing, avoidance of tariffs and import restrictions, securing a raw material to take advantage of cheaper inputs or higher rates of return on investments in order to spread their risk.

In other words, this government removed exchange controls, unlike the former Treasurer with people in the Reserve Bank ticking little bits of paper about whether an Australian company could invest abroad. When Boral decided to become the largest brick and tile manufacturer in the United States, when the likes of CSR, Pacific Dunlop—or name them—the breweries, or the transport companies like TNT and Mayne Nickless decided similarly, they did so because they believe in the long run it is in the interests of their business to get behind these tariff barriers and get into these markets when they come to their market share in Australia.

PARA.TAB: What the coalition would have us say to Australian business leaders is, `Don't you invest abroad so you can reduce the foreign debt.' In other words, `How dare you put $80 billion worth of assets offshore and give us $160 billion of net debt? Why didn't you keep all your investments at home and give us only $80 billion of net debt?' Let us have a bit of honesty from honest John over there—
Opposition members—Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —about Australian investment abroad.
—Order! The House will come to order!

—Just so that the Leader of the Opposition cannot peddle his nonsense and say, `I never realised that point,' when he goes around doing his stint on the radio, I will leave him this copy which very graphically shows Australian investment abroad rising steadily, as the statistician says, to $120 billion, and Australian private equity abroad to $80 billion against net debt of $160 billion. I believe that if it came to the key question of whether the government would say to Australian business, `You shall not invest abroad because we don't want any covering of that investment on the current account,' the answer to that is that the government has made the right decision and removed exchange controls and let that happen. Compare that, Mr Speaker, with the cloistered, closeted, frightened little economy that John Howard left them; all locked up with their market share up to optimums. They could not sell any more beer in Australia. They could not go offshore and sell beer in Europe or Japan because he would not let them. Now they have gone off and done it and he says, `Isn't it pretty. You have got all this net debt.'
—Mr Speaker—
—Oh, you are going to add to our sum total of knowledge, are you?
—I tell you what, mate; it wouldn't take much to add to your sum total of knowledge.
—The member for Flinders on a point of order.

—Yes, I rise to a point of order. Mr Speaker, I draw your attention to rulings by previous Speakers which have required ministers to be relatively concise in their answers. The Prime Minister has been speaking for 11 minutes. He has well and truly moved off the substance of the question. You ought to exercise the authority in your office to require ministers to at least contain their answers to a reasonable length.

—Order! The honourable member for Flinders knows that the chair does not have the capacity to limit answers. I will not refer the honourable member to comments that have been made. The Prime Minister has been entirely relevant to the question that was asked. I would invite him to wind up.

—Normally they do not ask me the questions because they do not like the answers. Let me give this to Mr Howard. Have a little look. Have a little gander at that one and see what you reckon about that for a bit of successful Australian investing abroad. Next time you are talking to the Business Council of Australia tell them that you think you have got very grave reservations about their investments abroad, and tell them—
—There you are. Have it back. Look at this.
—Order! Resume your seat. The Prime Minister has the call.

—I have answered that. When the Leader of the Opposition goes to the Business Council of Australia next time he should tell them that he thinks they should not invest abroad because they are adding to our national debt—our stock of national debt—and he thinks it is a bad thing. If he does not take that view, let him at least include Australian assets abroad when he looks at net debt abroad.
—I invite the Prime Minister to table the notes he is quoting from and I would seek leave to table this foreign debt chart showing the true position on the matter.
—Was the Prime Minister quoting from private notes?
—They are but, if it will bring Tim up the learning curve, he is welcome to them.

PARA.TAB: Leave not granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer. Is the Treasurer aware of claims made yesterday after the release of the January housing approval figures that the housing industry has been closed down? Is this an accurate reflection of the current state of the housing industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to the honourable member for Paterson, I can say that I am aware of some statements made yesterday by the Shadow Treasurer. When speaking on ABC radio about the housing sector he said, `And basically it has been closed down in terms of activity.' What he was talking about was the release of the January approvals figures which showed a decline of some 9.7 per cent seasonally adjusted in that month. What we see with those figures is that there is quite a bit of fluctuation month by month, even though they are seasonally adjusted, and that particularly comes about because of the fact that we have included in them not just houses but also medium density dwelling units in Sydney and Melbourne in particular, but also in most capital cities.
—Oh, people don't live in them, eh?
—Order! I warn the honourable member for O'Connor about constantly interjecting.

—Approvals for those housing units have been strongly increasing. Of course, they happen in a lumpy way. When they come in, they push the units up for that month. When they are not there, there is a big drop. If we look at South Australia, in the month of January there was a 35 per cent increase in private dwelling approvals because of the approval of one large medium-density project in the city of Adelaide. So I think that shows you about the monthly variability, Mr Speaker.

PARA.TAB: But it is also important to note that if we look at the figures for private sector housing—not medium-density units but ordinary housing—approvals for ordinary housing fell by half a per cent. Of course, that is a much different picture. In fact, looking at that picture, Mr Silberberg, of the Housing Industry Association—who is not known normally for his support of the government in any way—said:

ANSWER.PARA: The small fall in the more interest rate sensitive private house approvals suggests home buyers may be coming to grips with higher interest rates, and reduces earlier concerns of a free fall in housing activity.

So the industry is saying, `Well, these figures actually give us some comfort,' whilst the shadow Treasurer, in normal ultra beat-up mode, is saying that the industry is being closed down by what is happening in the economy.

PARA.TAB: Mr Speaker, that is obviously an absurd overstatement, to put it at the least. In fact, one has to have some regard, in looking at the downturn in housing which has certainly occurred in recent times, to the levels at which it has been. Of course, it has been at record levels. The housing industry has been doing better, until recent times, than it has ever done in the history of the country.

In this upturn we have built 480,000 additional dwelling units. That is more than in any other upturn in Australia's history. So, since the economy got on the upswing again, from 1991 to 1994, 480,000 dwelling units have been built, more than any previous recovery. It is housing that essentially led the economy back onto a growth path.

You cannot, of course, expect the industry to keep on belting away with substantial increases in activity year by year, particularly when it has generally been seen as running ahead of the underlying level of demand given by the rate of formation of family units in this country. Therefore, at some stage, it had to slow, and that is what we have been witnessing in recent times, albeit assisted by some increases in interest rates.

Nevertheless, let us get it clearly understood that 1994 was an enormously good year for housing. Total approvals were 189,000 units, the highest level on record—absolutely the highest level on record. The Indicative Planning Council for the Housing Industry is saying that for this financial year, 1994-95, it will be 160,000. So there is some downturn—we are seeing that in the figures for approvals and commencements—but that is a downturn from exceedingly high levels of activity.

In fact, the level of approvals in January, at 13,200, is still above the average for the last 10 years. So we are still at above average levels of activity, going back for a decade, in approvals, and with commencements we see a similar sort of picture.

Mr Speaker, it is just the most ridiculous statement—typical of the opposition's attitude of massive doomsaying about the Australian economy to the point where there is just no credibility in anything that it says—for the shadow Treasurer to say that the industry had been basically closed down. All that is happening is that it is tailoring off from the highest levels of activity that have occurred in the history of this country to levels which are still well above average compared with those of the last decade or so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, my question is directed to the Prime Minister. Since the Treasurer is so concerned about up-beat statements, I remind you, Prime Minister, in 1993 you said that exports were about to go `gangbusters'. In August last year you said, `We have been exporting our heads off for years.' How can this be so in the light of yesterday's balance of payments figures showing trend exports have been flat for one and a half years?

—You should lift your game. You know he told you all that you should lift your game. You know he called the ministry together and told you all to improve your game. You've got to save your job, Brian!
—Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition! Come to your question or resume your seat.

—How can this be so when, if you rank OECD countries by the export of services to GDP, we are 21 out of 22, and our export to GDP ratio lags at less than 18 per cent compared with an average 30 per cent for the OECD and 30 per cent for New Zealand?

—He has been having too many cream cakes at Claridges, Mr Speaker. He is just not quite across the stuff. The reason why I have been saying that we have been exporting our heads off for years is that we have. Please excuse me for repeating that fact and that truth! I mean, pardon me! Exports have gone from 13 per cent of GDP to 22 per cent of GDP in the last decade. Just get those numbers again: exports have gone from 13 per cent of GDP to 22 per cent of GDP.
—The member for Mayo knows better.
—It is in this magazine here, Mr Speaker.
—The member for Mayo! Don't push it.

—Poor silly fellow! The member for Mayo is more to be pitied than despised. When the former Treasurer was in office we had exports to GDP so low in the OECD league table, the developed league table, you would think he would hang his head in shame. As I have said before, he presided over the industrial archaeology he called the industrial landscape of Australia—the graveyard. Is it any wonder that we were right at the bottom of the pile in the OECD?

PARA.TAB: As a consequence of the massive improvement in competitiveness introduced by this government in opening Australia up, in lifting our competitiveness and in lifting productivity, not only have exports gone from 13 per cent to 22 per cent of GDP, well up in the OECD league table, but as well the fastest growing component of those exports was elaborately transformed manufactures.

TALK.START.PARA: —What were the cost figures?
—I warn the member for Mayo.
—How the deputy leader, talking about one month's number, can talk about exports—
—Eighteen months!

—Or even 18 months. When you look over the period of the last 10 years, a constant period of growth in exports, you would not have known what to do with the place. You quit absolutely bereft of any ideas. You scurried out of office in 1982-83 leaving behind this rotting hulk you called industrial Australia.

PARA.TAB: One of the compliments I was paid in the last year or so was by Bert Evans from the metal trades who said, `I'm a member of the 180-degree club. That is the people who change their mind completely about industrial protection and tariffs.' He changed his mind because of the turnaround in Australian industry and its success.

It will take more than a reference to a month or 18 months on the part of the deputy leader to try to dull the point, to diminish the achievement, of Australian business, Australian industry and Australian workers to actually lift our exports to be right up in the league table of the OECD at 22 per cent of GDP and rising.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Prime Minister advise whether it is the intention of the government to ensure that living standards of Australian workers will continue to be protected under the Industrial Relations Act?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The government believes that in a civilised and successful country there must be genuine minimum safety net conditions for Australian workers. We have introduced those provisions and we will maintain them. These will continue to include the guaranteed provision of minimum wage rates, maternity leave, paid public holidays, annual leave, sick leave, overtime and annual leave loadings. I think that gives us cause for some genuine comparison with the opposition.
—Are you going to subsidise Bill's airline?
—The member for O'Connor has been warned. I am not sure whether you are on an early plane, but you will be.

—The shadow industrial relations spokesman was out there a week or so ago with a smokescreen saying that theirs will be now an evolutionary policy. `Incrementalism' was a word he used. In other words, `Don't be alarmed. We're not going to bang you over the head like we promised with Jobsback; we're just going to have a nice soft, cuddly incremental policy.'

PARA.TAB: But when Dr Hewson tendered his resignation to the House the other day, the Leader of the Opposition said in response that there had been changes of substance in Australia, and he pointed to tariffs, protection and financial deregulation, but he said, `The other great reform left undone is the labour market.'

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear! There is nothing wrong with his statement.

—In other words, two days ago the great reform left undone is the labour market; the week earlier it is going to be creeping incrementalism and it is going to be evolutionary changes. It used to be the wolf in wolf's clothing; now it is the wolf in sheep's clothing—same policy, different camouflage.

PARA.TAB: Let me make these points about the comparison between the government and the opposition. The Howard-Reith policy removes as a minimum, at least, overtime and annual leave loadings. We know this because the member for Flinders told us on Meet the Press recently, `Jobsback is the thrust of coalition policy'. He also said this in a speech to the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry last week. He said, `Our jobsback policy remains intact.' Let us get this on the record. `Our jobsback policy,' he said `remains intact.' So nothing has changed except the camouflage. So the opposition refused to acknowledge that the area of great exposure to Australian workers is the turnover in the labour market.

In the year ending February 1994, for example, 1.6 million people changed jobs or employers—that is in a labour market of eight million. That is 20 per cent of the labour force in one year—130,000 new positions a month or 4,000 a day. In other words, that constant change in the labour market would mean that those people who line up to protect their minimums or to maintain, for instance, their annual leave loading or their overtime, would find that they were unable to secure it.

Let me give you an example. A new typical part-time nurse working 20 hours each weekend would have her pay lowered by $114.80 per weekend. A new transport worker or driver on 12 hours overtime each week would have his pay lowered by $113.35 a week. When asked about this, Mr Howard said on radio 3LO, `I don't disguise the fact that under our policy the question of whether you get any improvement becomes a matter of negotiation.' In other words, `I am, as always, being virtuous; I am not going to hide the fact that you are going to take a big pay cut here, but I am not going to say it explicitly.' He just says, `I am not going to hide the fact that whether you get an improvement becomes a matter of negotiation.' At the National Press Club in February 1993—

TALK.START.PARA: —Heavens. Let's slaughter all babies under 12 months.
—Order!
—We are just pinning you down trying to put a shoofty over us—a sneaky one over us. At the National Press Club in February 1993—
—Why not make a statement? You are losing the plot!
—Order! The member for Mitchell!
—Mr Speaker—
—A point of order!
—The Prime Minister might resume his seat for a moment.

—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I accept your ruling that ministers are allowed to contrast government and opposition policy, but all the Prime Minister has done so far for five minutes is talk about the opposition. Surely that is irrelevant.
—Yes, you are irrelevant.
—Order! Those on my right. The Prime Minister is talking directly to the question that was asked of him.
—In February 1993 at the press club the leader said:

ANSWER.PARA: The loss of loadings and penalties might be a factor workers would have to take into consideration before changing jobs.

In other words, there is a sudden death. If you lose your job and you take a new one, you lose the option of being able to secure these under-minimums, you are back to individual wage contract, master and servant provisions of the common law, and then you are left in the position that formally the overtime or the annual leave loading you are paid goes.

PARA.TAB: We often hear the Leader of the Opposition talking about families. Doesn't he think that these 1.7 million people who change their jobs at the risk of losing these sorts of sums—$100 to $120 per week—in overtime and annual leave loadings are members of Australian families? Doesn't he think those reductions in their incomes are real? Doesn't he believe that, as he said, the labour market reform is exactly as he described it under Jobsback, as agreed by the member for Flinders, and that the notion of incrementalism or gradualism or evolution is really just a camouflage for the old policy the opposition has always had of making sure it whacks the 1.6 or 1.7 million people who jump out of their existing job and cannot protect themselves? That is his policy. Let me say what ours is: it is a set of genuine safety net provisions, a set of genuine minimums—
Opposition members—Hooray! At last!

TALK.START.PARA: —You know what our policy is because we have been running it for years. The $8 a week safety net is coming through now and there is protection for things like overtime and annual leave loadings—and these other issues of minimums. Let us note the point that when the Leader of the Opposition said in response to Dr Hewson's departure the other day that the labour market, as he put it, was still the area of great reform, what he and the member for Flinders mean is whacking people on low incomes and knocking $100 to $120 per week off them. That is what it means. At least we can cut through all the hocus-pocus, the fuzz, all the warm inner glow and all the fluffiness. It is the same old Fightback-Jobsback policy which the member for Flinders recorded it was on Meet the Press last week.

PARA.TAB: Again, there is a stark difference. This group opposite never learn anything. As if the profit share in the economy is not high enough, as if the proportion of national income going to profits is not high enough, without trying to increase it at the expense of the low and middle income earners of this country. That is what the member for Bennelong is now committed to, as always. I wanted to use this opportunity to expose exactly what he seeks to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, is that what it is all about? It was supposed to be a question without notice.
—So what?

—My question without notice is addressed to the Prime Minister. Given his record when Treasurer of holding down official interest rates until after state elections, and given the statement by Senator Gareth Evans to the Senate yesterday that interest rates will not require any further adjustment for the foreseeable future, does the foreseeable future referred to by Senator Gareth Evans expire the day after the New South Wales election, namely 26 March?
—You know they will.
—The member for Gippsland will cease interjecting.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are running out of puff faster than your curly-headed young mate behind you. You are running out of puff in a couple of weeks; it took him at least a couple of months. If that is the sort of question—

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Prime Minister has the call.

—This claim was made by the former Leader of the Opposition, John Hewson. It has been made at other times by the member for Bennelong. The then Governor of the Reserve Bank, Bob Johnston, said in his departing speech:

ANSWER.PARA: Relations between this government and the bank have been entirely proper.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Those on my left will cease interjecting.
—I will quote him verbatim. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: But only an insider can know that this was not always so.

Can I also say that during a discussion which I was party to on one of the changes in the financial market up came the member for Bennelong, all jaunty, jostling around the financial community, still trying to polish up his credentials there. He went up to Bob Johnston who told him in no uncertain terms that he did not appreciate these lies being spread about him.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a lie.
—It is not a lie; it is dead right. He put you down.
—Let's not get into that again.
—He put you right down. And I am glad he did.
—Will he withdraw?
—No, he did not—the Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat. The Prime Minister will also be careful.
—Are you going to ask him to withdraw it?
—Resume your seat. Let us not get into that. The Prime Minister did not call you specifically. Resume your seat.
—Are you going to withdraw?
—I did not call you anything.
—Yes, you did.
—He did not say anything to you. He did not call you anything. Now let it drop.

—As I recall it, Mr Johnston gave a speech called something like `departing thoughts', which he gave to the financial community in Australia. It is a matter of record. The parliamentary library will have it. Just go and look at the text and see what he says. He said that `relations between this government and the bank have always been entirely proper, but only an insider could tell that this was not always so'. This was during the period you allude to when you say that I, as Treasurer, sat on interest rates during a period of a state government election. I never did, and the Governor corroborated the proper operation of monetary policy between the government and him, but he admonished you for your remarks.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Can the minister confirm that workers on awards will continue to receive safety net wage increases? Is it the intention of the government not to update award wages of pay for workers who cannot benefit from enterprise bargaining?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brereton The Hon L.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the cornerstones of the Industrial Relations Reform Act is the maintenance and the strengthening of the award safety net. The act requires the commission to ensure that the award system provides a secure, relevant and consistent minimum set of wages and conditions. Of course, it is backed up by accord mark 7, which has provided safety net adjustments for low paid workers in each of the last three years—the last being the current $8 adjustment.

PARA.TAB: In contrast with this, the coalition's industrial relations policy contains no safety net—none whatsoever—other than four miserly conditions that are set out in Jobsback. Earlier today in question time, the Prime Minister illustrated what would happen to people looking for a job under the Liberal's Jobsback.

It is worth asking the question: what will happen to the 45 per cent of workers who remain in their jobs for five years or more? For those people who choose to remain on their award, assuming that they are allowed to, of course, under Jobsback, the future is bleak indeed. That is because Jobsback has absolutely no mechanism to update the award. Awards will, under Jobsback, be frozen in time. The member for Bennelong said on Melbourne radio on 12 February 1993 in response to a caller who asked him, if she stayed on her award, would she be stuck on the same wage indefinitely:

ANSWER.PARA: Look, I don't disguise the fact that under our policy, if you disagree, you are guaranteed your current award conditions and the question of whether you get any improvement on those becomes a matter of negotiation.
He then conceded on that program:
The lady's question is correctly based.

That is what he said. It is worth looking at one of the many examples of what could happen to a worker under Jobsback. Take the case of a textile worker in a factory and on an award rate of $349.40 per week. That textile worker, under a coalition government, if you assume that inflation was running at 3 per cent—I believe that is pretty generous to the opposition, because the last time the member for Bennelong held the fiscal reins inflation was running at 11.4 per cent—would see his or her award eroded over a three-year period, in real terms, by $31.40—a decrease of 8.3 per cent for that worker.

PARA.TAB: Pity the family of that textile worker. So much for the opposition's commitment to families. Think about the family of that textile worker. Make no mistake, Jobsback is still the policy of the coalition. As recently as 18 April 1994, the member for Bennelong said on radio station 2GB:

ANSWER.PARA: Jobsback is not gone. Jobsback remains the policy of the coalition. There is absolutely no suggestion that Jobsback has gone. Jobsback was not part of Fightback.

Of course, that has been borne out by none other than the member for Flinders—Mr GST himself—on the recent Meet the Press program. Mr Speaker, have no doubt: Australian workers will have little difficulty in remembering that Jobsback is pure code for reducing pay and conditions.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. I direct the Prime Minister to the interview with New South Wales Labor leader Bob Carr on the Sunday program and specifically to the question put to Mr Carr that he did not agree with the Keating policy on industrial relations. I remind the Prime Minister of Mr Carr's exact answer:

QUESTION.PARA: I happen to believe that that provision (the so-called unfair dismissal provision) in the federal act is a disincentive to take on labour.
Is Bob Carr right? Is he trying to con the people of New South Wales with this comment or are you, the Prime Minister, trying to con the rest of Australia? In fact, is Bob Carr not dead right?

TALK.START.PARA: —In this country we have seen record rates of employment growth which give people opportunities to take up jobs—I mean, some disincentive! We have seen 4.6 per cent productivity growth over the course of the last year, two to three per cent inflation, a 40 per cent increase in competitiveness under these policies in the last decade—what more need I say about the government's industrial relations policies?—and the continuing growth of enterprise bargaining in the system so that we have within sector flexibility, award restructuring and the removal of the leap-frogging that used to go on with comparative wage justice, so-called, in the 1970s and 1980s. They are the reforms that matter, and that was well managed.

PARA.TAB: As the Minister for Industrial Relations has made clear, 55 per cent of all employees covered by federal awards are now signed up under enterprise agreements. In New South Wales, that figure is 13 or 14 per cent. In other words, the industrial relations policy of the Fahey government has been a failure, as has all of its other policies.

Mr Carr repeated my point that nothing happens in New South Wales. When asked by Mr Oakes, Mr Fahey said, `Look at the railway out to Mascot, the one we are going to build out there, and the toll road.' These are all things that he promises on the state government's budget. But how many industrial projects of substance are going on in New South Wales? The answer is that there is nothing to speak of. New South Wales is a state which is stone dead. It is absolutely dead in the water. The businesses are going to Queensland because nothing happens in New South Wales.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Andrews

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order under 145. The quote from Bob Carr which the Prime Minister was asked about was:

INTERJECT.PARA: I happen to believe that that provision (the so-called unfair dismissal provision) in the federal act is a disincentive to take on labour.
The Prime Minister is off at a tangent on matters which are unrelated to the question. He has not even attempted to answer it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understood that the preamble from the Leader of the National Party went to economic circumstances and, to that extent, the Prime Minister is in order.
—Further to the point of order, if I could read the preamble to you—

PARA.TAB: Government members—No! No!

TALK.START.PARA: —It is about industrial relations—
—No, I have just ruled. Resume your seat. The Prime Minister has the call.

—The truth is that nothing happens in New South Wales. The government is absolutely dead on its feet. That is why we have seen so many ministers leave it. They have either left it voluntarily or they have had to leave it as the victims of scandals, in a scandalised fashion. It is a government which has been scandalised and where ministers have had to leave. As I said the other day, the quicker Bob Carr can take this dead on its feet Fahey government and put it in the tumbrel, the better for all of us.

—I refer the Prime Minister to the proposal to refer the practice of `push polling' to the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters. Can the Prime Minister advise the House of the matters which the joint committee has been invited to examine?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I told the House on Monday that the government would refer this push polling, or negative polling, as an issue to the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters. I can now advise the House of the detailed terms of reference that have been transmitted by the Minister for Administrative Services to the Chairman of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, and I table the reference.

PARA.TAB: I agree with an editorial in the Australian newspaper today which said:
The Prime Minister . . . is right to describe the apparent use of American-style negative polling in the federal seat of Canberra, as sinister. This practice—

ANSWER.PARA: so that push-polling is explicitly defined—and outlawed.
In the Age, in an editorial opinion, it says:

PARA.TAB: Until Mr Howard unequivocally and publicly denounces the way the ACT polling was conducted or denies that it was meant to change votes, his party remains open to the charge that its leaders knew and condoned what was done.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Those on my right and those on my left.

—Mr Speaker, I can only endorse this because the member for Bennelong has been whispering around the press gallery corridors that he did not really approve of this. But he will not come and say that he did not condone it, did not know about it, or does not approve of it.

PARA.TAB: This comes at the same time as Mr Robb, his federal secretary, is circulating a cash and prizes sweepstake in Western Australia that the Western Australian Office of Racing and Gaming says in this morning's Australian has broken the law. In this morning's Adelaide Advertiser we see that a defunct company, Catch Tim Ltd, was the largest single donor to the Liberal Party's campaign fund of 1993 of $100,000—and the Liberal Party executive in charge of that campaign was Mr Morris who now directs Mr Howard's office.

Here we are: Mr Howard is saying yes, he would run the country in an honest and upright way. How could he convince people that he would run the country in an honest and upright way when Mr Morris, Mr Textor—the person associated with the push polling—and Mr Robb behave in the unprincipled way they do? And they are all around him: running the office, running the federal secretariat—

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, no! Come on!
—Order! The member for Hindmarsh has caught the disease as well.

—and working from his office. Just as he could not see the criminal avoidance of the tax system in the 1970s, he was wandering along, going around with a big ear like Mr Midnight but not hearing as he went through the accountancy businesses of Sydney and Melbourne, wandering around silly but civil—ignorance is bliss—and he cannot hear this rumbling in his office. He cannot hear all this going on in his office. So let him come out and say that he denounces this sort of activity and that he does not believe in these sorts of policies. As the Age says, unless he does that, its leaders will not know where he stands other than that he has `condoned what was done'. I can only concur with the editorials in the Age and in the Australian.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address a question to the Prime Minister which, in a sense, is supplementary to the question that was just asked of him. In view of his recent moralising about electoral practices, I ask: is he aware that in the recent ACT elections the Labor Party targeted unsuspecting voters by issuing its own how-to-vote cards for independents? Is he also aware that the ALP issued instructions to booth captains that ALP workers handing out these cards should not wear any identifiable badges? I quote from the instructions:
—It is routine for—
—It's routine when you do it, isn't it? Yes, it's routine when you do it! And that's your trouble.
—Order! The House will come to order.
—Mr Speaker—
—The Leader of the House will resume his seat. All right, we have had a bit of fun. The Leader of the Opposition will get back to his question.
—Stop smiling, Michael, that was a real boo-boo, wasn't it? And I quote:

QUESTION.PARA: The person handing out the preference—
how to vote should not be wearing any ALP identifiers i.e. badge, stickers, t-shirts, or hat.

Does he approve the technique used by the ALP when it used Labor booth workers without identification who were instructed to target voters and to deceive them into believing that they were supporting independents by distributing a how-to-vote card where the words, `voting independent' clearly swamped the ALP logo in this fine print? Why were Labor's dummy independents instructed to continue to issue these bogus how-to-vote cards even if challenged by booth officials? Will the Prime Minister assure the House that during the ACT by-election for the seat of Canberra, the ALP will not repeat this deliberate deception of voters? Will he refer these incidents to the inquiry referred to in the previous answer?

TALK.START.PARA: —My colleague the Minister for Communications and the Arts—
—What about the Terry Metherall affair?

PARA.TAB: Mr Price interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Chifley! Just relax!
—Remember him! He did it.
—As members on this side of the House make clear, Mr Metherall apparently pioneered this technique in the Liberal Party. The fact is that I know of none of these matters.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members—Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —The House will come to order! The Prime Minister has the call.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members—Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

PARA.TAB: Opposition members—Hypocrite!

TALK.START.PARA: —Unlike the Leader of the Opposition, I do not condone it and I say I do not condone it.
—Order! The House will come to order! The Prime Minister has the call.
—Oh, let him go.
—Unlike the Leader—
—Come on; you don't condone it, but—
—Order! The honourable member for Mayo!
—Unlike the Leader of the Opposition, who has trucked around the press gallery—
—Oh, yes. Ha, ha!
—Resume your seat!
—Yeah! Yeah!
—Resume your seat!
—Name him, Mr Speaker.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Leader of the Opposition knows that with the position comes a little latitude. You are using it up.
—You are right, but you know that—
—Resume your seat. The Prime Minister has the call. He will be heard in silence.

—In New South Wales this technique was apparently conducted with taxpayers' dollars. I know of no circumstances when this has been applied by the ALP in the ACT. But, were it to be, I would not condone it; I would condemn it, unlike little smartypants here, who runs around the press gallery telling people that he does not condone it. Meanwhile, in his office sit three people, and in the federal secretariat, who are into this appalling push-polling. This push-polling was an appalling process. He has not told the House whether he knew about it or whether he condones it.

PARA.TAB: So the difference between me and him is that up front, straightaway, I say, `I don't condone it. I wouldn't have a bar of any of these techniques.' This compares with the snide, putrid, underhand polling technique of push-polling where somebody is actually criminally defamed, which is the game you have been in, and then you walk around saying, `I am little honest John.' We know how honest you are, don't we? We all know, don't we—like you were honest in the 1970s, wandering through while the tax commissioner wrote you all those letters—the telephone book—`Please, Treasurer, help us beat the criminal avoidance of tax industry'. There were pleas from a public servant to an uncaring, unlistening, smug, slick Treasurer. We know how honest you were then. We know that's how you got the ironic title of honest John. That honesty is no less apparent in terms of its irony than is the Leader of the Opposition's preparedness not to dissociate himself from push-polling, sweepstake things in Western Australia or dummy companies in South Australia. They are the things. The difference is that the people who manage these are on his staff—this day—and running his federal secretariat.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have lost it.
—Order! The honourable member for Ballarat!
—So let us see some honest behaviour from honest John. Let him tip these people out and say he does not condone these activities.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport. Is the minister aware of reported comments by Dr Bob Ratner, who is one of the world's leading aviation experts, on the current operations at Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport? What is the government's response to those comments? Are any proposals being put forward which conflict with those of Dr Ratner?

PARA.TAB: Opposition members—We can't hear him!

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brereton The Hon L.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I can confirm—

—The minister will wait. On a couple of occasions, I have mentioned—in fact, I have issued a general warning to some people in this place—the level of interjection. I now issue a general warning. I suggest that all members consider their position.

—I have seen Dr Ratner's comments in today's Australian and Financial Review. I think it is fair to say that his views are particularly relevant because he is one of the world's leading experts on aviation safety. In 1992 he carried out a review of the Australian air traffic services system. That review included a number of criticisms of the way the Civil Aviation Authority was then operating Sydney airport.

PARA.TAB: However, in a report in the Australian today, Dr Ratner endorsed the way the CAA is operating Sydney airport and warned against the reopening of the east-west runway. He did so on the grounds that reopening the runway would cut safety margins by reintroducing simultaneous operations on crossing runways—that is, the SIMOPS system—for a doubtful gain in capacity. He was quite adamant in his support of the current operations. In today's Financial Review, he said:
Any way you strike it in terms of throughput or in terms of safety, the parallel runway operation is the way to go.

ANSWER.PARA: That is what Dr Ratner had to say. Of course, those views totally go against those of that other self-appointed air space management expert, the Leader of the Opposition, whose announced policy is to reopen the east-west runway. To be fair, Dr Ratner acknowledges that SIMOPS is employed at a number of airports around the world and that it was employed at Kingsford Smith airport until recently. In today's Australian, he says that SIMOPS operates at those airports which:
. . . are willing to take on a requirement for a much higher degree of vigilance—and the possibility of incidents and . . . accidents—in order to move the traffic.
That is his view. He went on to say:
You've made another step up the safety ladder.

PARA.TAB: We have been able to do that with the . . . third runway, let's not go back.

ANSWER.PARA: Dr Ratner yesterday referred to an incident in 1991, when SIMOPS almost led to a disaster at Sydney airport. That incident involved a Thai Airways DC10, carrying 167 passengers; an Ansett A320, carrying 101 passengers; and a Qantas B747, which had 353 passengers on board. All up, that is 621 people. As the BASI investigation—which was the official investigation of that incident—reports, those 621 people were 11 metres from disaster. You can see the depiction of the cross-runway configuration on the BASI official report, which was available from 12 August 1991.

PARA.TAB: Yet now opposition members are happy to reject the overwhelming expert advice, and they propose the reintroduction of a mode of airport operations in our largest airport—the airport that services our largest city—which is less safe than the present mode of operations. They do it all for no gain in capacity. The obvious question to put to honest John is this: why are they advocating this? What is behind it? It certainly cannot be for noise.

TALK.START.PARA: —His seat. His seat.

—I will come to that. It certainly cannot be for noise because the official figures show that, in total, 58,000 people fewer are seriously or moderately affected by aircraft noise as a result of the parallel runway configuration. It certainly cannot be for safety reasons. As Dr Ratner points out, it certainly cannot be for capacity reasons. I think it is fair to record that opposition members have shamelessly tried to claim that the current operations—operations that were decided in 1989 and confirmed in 1991—have been introduced to benefit my electorate. That has been their claim.

PARA.TAB: Yet in 1995 we have the Leader of the Opposition proposing a policy that goes against all the expert advice but which will benefit his electorate. If he were so honest, he should come out and admit his cynicism or come clean with whatever expert advice he has to support his policy. The world's aviation community will be very interested to read it.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. On 4 June 1992, in answer to a question from me concerning dead-end jobs, you said you were no longer content to consign our children to low paid, uninteresting jobs. In this context can you explain what is interesting, highly paid, challenging and value added about trucking the unemployed out to Melbourne airport to meet and greet overseas visitors, as is proposed by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training? Does the Prime Minister believe that hotel touts, map sellers and bus stop bag carriers who eke out a living in airports in Third World countries are anything other than a sign that their governments have failed to solve unemployment? Finally, on what date does your department predict that the unemployed in the north-west and west of Melbourne will be fully trained and, therefore, that lack of skill will no longer be an explanation for unemployment?

—There are two steps here. The first is getting aggregate rates of employment up in this country that would take the new entrants to the labour market, including those who are graduating from school and institutions. The second is training and placing people.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member would know that the government has now committed $1.1 billion to the Australian National Training Authority to vocationally train young Australians. He will know that in the white paper we have made it a policy to case manage young people under 18 years of age who drop out of the education system to either get them back into mainstream education or give them a job subsidy and get them a job.

The commitment to young Australians by this government is very clear for everybody to see. I am happy to say that the proof of the pudding is in the eating, with employment amongst young people picking up its share of the growth in jobs, which has been just on 500,000 since the election. This government, as no other government before it, has done things to lift participation rates in schools. When the last coalition government left office, only three kids in 10 completed secondary school. It is now up to eight in 10—a revolution in participation.

There has also been a mighty change in the participation of young women in schools and their passage through secondary school and into tertiary institutions. In fact, there were more entrants into tertiary institutions this year amongst young women than amongst young men. As a consequence of that tertiary growth, where we have added the equivalent of about 16 universities of the size of Sydney and Melbourne universities to the system since 1985-86, and now the commitment of $1.1 billion to the National Training Authority, it is manifestly obvious where the government's heart lies—with young Australians. I do not think there is any problem about working in the tourism—

TALK.START.PARA: —So you are sending them out to the airport. Do you like that idea?

—Tourism is an important and significant growing industry. It is an industry which is highly labour intensive and these are jobs, I am sure, young Australians appreciate getting. If he is trying to make some sort of point about data processing, where before there were lots of unskilled jobs, clerical jobs and labouring jobs, many of those jobs with machine tools and data processing have disappeared. That is our point.

PARA.TAB: We are trying to train young Australians for new jobs, and I would say that we are training them successfully. We are not just training them; we are committed to them. We will not let them drop out under the age of 18 without case managing them back into school or into training and work. Tell me of any other Commonwealth government that ever made that commitment. I am sure you cannot, and I am happy to say you share our view about this. That is why the tenor and tone of the question should have been more supportive than they were.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question—
—Leo, why didn't you ask this?
—Order! Those on my left had better heed the warning.
—My question is directed to the Prime Minister.
—Which the Prime Minister wrote five minutes ago.

—Order! The member for Gippsland obviously cannot help himself. He heard me give a general warning before but he continues to interject. Under standing order 304A, he is therefore asked to remove himself for one hour.

TAB.EMPHASIS: The honourable member for Gippsland thereupon withdrew from the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Prime Minister a further question to that of the Leader of the Opposition on polling practice in the ACT. Is it not a fact that the Leader of the Opposition has misrepresented instructions on how-to-vote practice of the ACT Labor Party? Can the Prime Minister confirm that the Leader of the Opposition has misled the House?
—Mr Speaker—
—Order! I will be listening very carefully to the response.
—The Leader of the Opposition wilfully misled the House.
—If the Prime Minister wishes to proceed with a charge of that nature, there are provisions in the standing orders that must be invoked.
—Mr Speaker, let me make a further point.
—Mr Speaker, on a point of order—
—Yes, do it properly.
—Order! Just one moment.
—Sit him down.
—I have already said to the Prime Minister that a charge of that nature is very serious and that he must be able to substantiate that charge—
—By motion.
—by motion under the provisions of the parliament.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Mr Keating) agreed to:

That so much of the standing and sessional orders be suspended as would prevent the Prime Minister moving forthwith that the Leader of the Opposition has grievously and wilfully mislead this House and should be censured.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Leader of the Opposition has grievously and wilfully mislead this House and should be censured.

SPEECH.PARA: I was asked a question by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), who has been embarrassed by the fact that he has not sought to make clear his position and, as such, has condoned the grievous and putrid tactics of push polling of the Liberal Party. He sought to introduce into the House a question about which he knew the imputations to be false. At the time, I was unaware of the matters and I made that very clear.

PARA.TAB: As I made that clear, honest John guffawed and laughed. He gave his instructions to the frontbench and they all laughed and went on when I said, `I did not know about it.' I did not know about it. I said, if it was as he described it in New South Wales, I would not condone it. I have since been given the material, and what the Leader of the Opposition said was a complete misrepresentation. The material states:

SPEECH.PARA: Voting 1 Independent? . . . don't get Liberal/Alliance chaos in Government by mistake. Give your preferences to the Australian Labor Party.
It numbers the ticket and says:
Make your preferences count . . .
It has the Australian Labor Party logo and it then says:
Put the Liberals last!
It is authorised by Doug Thompson, Australian Labor Party, Belconnen.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, on a point of order: given the fact that electoral officials challenged the how-to-vote card, I put it to the House that the Prime Minister—
—Resume your seat. I warn the Leader of the National Party about taking points of order in that way.
—This is a censure, Mr Speaker. Name him! Name him!
—I call the Prime Minister.

—Honest John deceitfully and wilfully got up and misled this House—just as he deceitfully and wilfully walked through public comment in the seventies and eighties about the criminal disrepair of the tax system. He was all hearing but no knowing. Today he is trying to deflect attention from himself in respect of matters such as the federal secretary of his party being up to his neck in push polling—one of the grubbiest, most sinister techniques ever employed in the electoral history of this country. In his office is Mr Morris, who we find today in the advisers box, who has been talking about the executive who was in charge of the South Australian Liberals big donor scheme, which is called `Catch Tim Ltd', which we found donated $100,000 to the Liberal Party. Then we find Mr Textor, who has been up to his dirty tricks, working on his staff—the three of them are on his staff. The Age states:

SPEECH.PARA: Until Mr Howard unequivocally and publicly denounces the way ACT polling was conducted or denies it was meant to change votes, his party remains open to the charge that its leaders knew and condoned what was done.

That is what I read to him. To deflect that, he then makes the charge, with imputations in the question that he knows to be false and to be misleading to the House, and then guffaws along with his front bench. When I said I was not aware of it, I was not aware of it because it did not happen; it did not exist. The technique that he ascribes to the Labor Party did not exist. The how-to-vote card, which is around here, says `Vote 1 Independent' and then a question mark and `Don't get the Liberal alliance chaos in government by mistake. Give your preferences to the Australian Labor Party'. It does not look like a subterfuge to me. It does not look like an independent's how-to-vote to me. It does not look as if the people holding that out are representing themselves as independents when it has the ALP logo on it and it is authorised by the Australian Labor Party. As my colleague made clear, this was not what the Liberal Party did in 1988 in New South Wales.

TALK.START.PARA: —In 1988 in New South Wales, this was not—
—The honourable member for Mackellar has already been warned.

—That was a completely different thing. It was to that technique that the Leader of the Opposition is alluding. Mr Speaker, glib, dishonest behaviour of this kind, which the Leader of the Opposition has specialised in for years, will not advance his interests or his party's interests, particularly when he so grievously misleads—and goes out of his way to contemptuously mislead—the parliament.

PARA.TAB: I would have thought that the Leader of the Opposition, getting a second chance—the second go round—would at least clean his act up and make sure that whenever something like this comes out he would nail his colours to the mast and say, `I do not believe in push-polling. I think it is un-Australian. I am sorry my party did it. I apologise for them. We will have no more of it.' Everyone would have said, `Well, at least that is the decent thing that we expect and we thank him for saying that.' But no! He went in and told his party room—I will find the quote—that it derogated in some minor way from their—

TALK.START.PARA: —A hiccup.

—It was only a hiccup. It was so much of a hiccup that two national newspapers have editorialised about it. Today, when not unreasonably I referred to the matter after reference from my colleague the Minister for Administrative Services, he then decides to deflect parliamentary attention from it by essentially trafficking in a lie. The Leader of the Opposition can grin. You can grin with that sort of shameful, embarrassed little grin, but we all know what lies behind it. It is just like he has been around like a spin doctor, running round the gallery saying, `Oh, we have turned over a new leaf on Aboriginal policies.'

PARA.TAB: Yes, we know how much of a new leaf he has turned over. He left all of the corrupting amendments to the bill in the House. He brought it over here and, if the government was weak enough to say, `Oh well, look, any bill, any land fund bill, is better than no bill at all—'

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to a point of order. Standing order 81 says that no member may digress from the subject matter. The Prime Minister is clearly talking about allegations other than the specific allegation that he raised in his motion. He should be brought back to the particular matter.
—It is a censure.
—On a matter such as this the Prime Minister—and I am sure the Leader of the Opposition, anticipating what he is going to say—is quite in order.

—If the government had said, `Oh well, any land fund bill, even one which derogates from the purpose of a bill like this, is better than no bill; we will pass it'—if we weakly and meekly had agreed to that, the Aboriginal community in this country would be denied a land fund bill which is cogent and workable. Instead of that, the government said, `No, we will not cop a substandard piece of legislation from the Senate.' If John Howard wanted to show that he had turned over a new leaf for Aboriginal people he would have knocked those amendments out and said, `Look, I am the leader; Downer is not the leader. I am not having these sleights of hand. They are out.'

PARA.TAB: Instead of that, up comes the Downer bill, back into the House of Representatives, where the government says, `No, we won't have it. We'll have a principal bill which does not derogate from the capacity of the fund to actually help Aboriginal people.' Then the Leader of the Opposition runs around the press gallery saying, `I'm not following the Downer-Hewson tactic. I'm actually in the game. I'm passing the bill.' But he is only passing the bill after the government has said, `We'll take you to a double dissolution. We'll have the technique there if we wish to exercise it, and we'll pass this bill at a joint sitting of both houses.'
So after all his puffery over the polls, and the preening he has been going on with lately, when the Leader of the Opposition was faced

SPEECH.PARA: with a bit of hard tack, out he was in a second. He gave in. `I will pass the bill,' he said. Thank you, John—and thank you from the Aboriginal community of this country, who are entitled to a decent piece of law and not to be had by paltry, miserable coalition politics.

PARA.TAB: The government's strength on a matter of principle—not copping the Senate's view or the coalition's view on the land fund, just as it did not cop them on the native title legislation—means that justice will be done for Aboriginal people. It proves this point: the nation moves ahead on principle and victories, not shabby compromises. As a consequence, the Leader of the Opposition was exposed.

This how-to-vote card was challenged by the Liberal Party but cleared by the Electoral Commissioner, Mr Green. The Leader of the Opposition introduced this matter, knowing that his party has actually challenged it and was overruled by the Electoral Commissioner for the ACT. That only compounds the misleading nature of the question which the member for Bennelong proposed.

Mr Speaker, the problem the member for Bennelong has is that he has been here too long and in opposition too long. He has had it. He has no ideas. He has run out of principles. He is in here playing the same shabby debating games and ploys that were played through the 1970s and 1980s. He does not realise that the whole country has moved on and is looking for value, looking for change, looking for substance. Here he is, trying to ask the Prime Minister of the day whether I condone a polling technique—which his party first used in 1988—when he knew that the technique employed had nothing whatsoever to do with that dishonourable, disreputable technique. Rather, it was something employed by the Australian Labor Party in the ACT after this particular how-to-vote card was cleared by the Electoral Commissioner.

Then he went on about how people were dressed, as if people have got to go around decked in blue and white with rosettes. It is as though if you are not out there with your rosettes and blue and white on, doing a jig at the polls, you are not legitimate, that you cannot go out and say, `Don't vote for the Independents' dressed in a pair of jeans and a T-shirt. So what?

Mr Speaker, compare that to saying that a woman believes in the termination of pregnancy after nine months—you hypocrites, you shabby hypocrites—ascribing to her a whole lot of social views which would demean her in the eyes of the public, trying to besmirch her reputation and then, having created that climate, going to the polls a couple of months later. This is where the Liberal Party is.

The fact is you are completely hollow as a party. You have no substance as an organisation. You are a party of convenience, not conviction. You have no substance. You have no policies. Your front bench is not worth a tinker's cuss. You have no strength in your back bench. Your party organisation is hollow. You keep playing this sort of carousel with leaders, thinking you are going to hit the jackpot. You are pulling the fruit machine of Australian politics, giving the handle a go to see whether something will roll into the slot, knowing that every symbol on the wheel is empty.

The fact is that Australian politics deserves better than the federal Liberal and National parties, much better—and it has got it on this side of the House. You can see it today in another milestone change for this society with the impending passage of the Aboriginal land fund bill. As a consequence of that, because of principle, articulation, enunciation, understanding, cooperation and consultation with people, a good social deed is going to be done. That is what government is about; it is not about shabby, hollow tricks, nasty tricks or dirty tricks.

Look at John Hewson. He walked out of here the other day. He came in as a relatively young man, was not here for many years, got to be the shadow treasurer for his party, became the opposition leader, lost an election, was denied the right to serve in the portfolios that he was interested in and walked away. What residual feeling is there going to be with him for the Liberal Party?
Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, Mr Morris is briefing him. John, while Mr Morris is briefing you, tell us about the `catch Tim' cheque donation scheme that he was managing in South Australia. Perhaps he can tell us about that in the briefing.

PARA.TAB: Does anybody believe that John Hewson is going to walk away, after a long association, with warm memories, depth, comradeship and commitment to the Liberal Party? Basically, you are like some sort of auxiliary business organisation that bands together to win an election. You have no sense of commitment, social cohesion or touch with the broader Australian community; you are just a bunch of individuals who sign the party ticket, line up while your careers are on the line and walk away as though it never happened.

Whereas we on this side might be sentimental about the Labor Party in or out of office, because we believe it in it, we are a party of conviction. We believe in things. We have feelings about the country. We have depth and we have association with the community. We are not a hollow party without any organisational strength, any philosophic understandings or any sense of touch with the broader Australian community.

There is no progression. John Howard's political growth is stunted because he comes from nothing. He is in here after all these years in parliament—20 years in parliament—trying to trick the Prime Minister into a question about a piece of polling data which he knows to be wrong. I am supposed to say, `Oh, a big change in the opposition. A new leader. A fresh start. A man of principle. Honest John.' I was the guy who got the Treasury job after you. I know what the tax office has said about you. I know what they said to me about the criminal avoidance in the tax system. I know what job I had to do to try to put it all back into place and build the law to stop that sort of thing happening in the past. I understand these things.

When people say to me, `Honest John,' I say, `Oh, sure.' I was the bunny who had five or six years wearing it on my back for his honesty in the tax system or his incapacity to deal with the 16 per cent wages growth. Sure, he is a great little guy! When he comes back and people say, `I bet you'll be afraid of Howard,' I say, `Oh, yeah!' We have seen it all before. And now the House has seen it all again.

You do not have to read the subtext. Someone in the Sunday Age said a couple of weeks ago, `We were shown these things, these savings options,' as I said in the caucus, `by Liberal people as if they were dirty postcards—a profit.' They said, `Here they are, but don't say they came from us.' But the journalist had enough integrity to write it. Instead of taking it on the chin and saying that is how slick Parliament House is these days, he said, `Hang on, I do not think it is slick. I ought to say, "Hang on, you've offered me this. I'll say it came from you."' But they said, `Oh, you cannot say it came from us.'

The following week I went on the Paul Lyneham program and I was asked about it. I pointed to the member for Bennelong and his attempts to undermine the budgetary process, running around with these savings options. One shot across the trench—gone—dropped it like a hot scone. A day later he said, `Oh, we'll pass any reasonable spending proposals that come on.'

We have seen in a very short time how unprincipled John Howard is. It is one thing trying to score off me; it is another misleading this parliament. Misleading this parliament is a grievous offence. The Leader of the Opposition wilfully misled the parliament this afternoon and he should be truly censured for it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The former Prime Minister, whenever he thought that he had been given an opportunity to say something unexpectedly, used to throw his hands up in the air and say, `There is a God.' I have to say that—

PARA.TAB: Mr Lee interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—I am absolutely delighted at the opportunity that the Prime Minister has unexpectedly given me to deal with a number of matters, including some of the allegations that have been flying around regarding electoral conduct by the two parties—

PARA.TAB: Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Those on my right.

—I think the altar boy should keep quiet. Just keep quiet. Little Sir Echo will get his turn later on. I really do welcome the opportunity very warmly, and the fact that the Prime Minister spent almost three-quarters of his speech talking about taxation matters, the Aboriginal Land Fund Bill, what I did 15 or 20 years ago—

PARA.TAB: Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Those on my right.

—Now that he is talking about what I did 15 or 20 years ago, I am going to talk about something he did 25 years ago. This is a serious motion and, inevitably, through the weight of numbers, there will be a censure motion carried against me. I accept the way this place operates. I have to say that I thought the Prime Minister would try a slightly more subtle attack. There is nothing particularly subtle about a government using its numbers to say that the opposition leader ought to be censured. How incredibly sophisticated and erudite a tactic. It must have come from that master of erudite interjection, Kim Beazley, who said that inviting your booth workers to mislead the voters was perfectly normal practice—
—I said it was routine Liberal practice, and so it is.
—Resume your seat.

—Let us go back a moment to the substance. The Prime Minister tried to allege that I had asked a question that was based upon incorrect information. Let me just go through the question again and point out how, in the process of drafting the motion, the Prime Minister himself shifted his ground and ended up writing out a motion that was different from the one that he had already moved.The House should pay very careful attention to what I actually asked. You are interested in standards. Come on! You want to have a proper political debate—

PARA.TAB: Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I am going to quieten them down.
—Just let them shout.

—If you would keep your voice down, I will tell them to be quiet, which is what I was going to do. Those on my right! The Prime Minister was heard in relative silence as will the Leader of the Opposition.

—This is how my question read. In view of Labor's recent moralising about election practices, I ask the Prime Minister: is he aware that in the recent ACT elections the Labor Party targeted unsuspecting voters by issuing its own how-to-vote cards for independents? That was completely true.
—It's not true.
—The Prime Minister has had his go. He will resume his seat.
—I will go on. I said:

SPEECH.PARA: Is he also aware that the ALP issued instructions to booth captains that ALP workers handing out these cards should not wear any identifiable badges? I quote from the instructions: The person handing out the preference how-to-vote card should not be wearing ALP identifiers.
Does he approve the technique used by the ALP when it used Labor booth workers without identification who were instructed to target voters—

TALK.START.PARA: —It has got the ALP logo on it.
—I warn the member for Paterson.
—and to deceive them into believing that they were supporting independents by distributing a how-to-vote card where the words, `voting independent' clearly swamped the ALP logo.

SPEECH.PARA: I never suggested there was no ALP logo. Every single thing that I said in that question was true. Despite that, Pinocchio over there will use his weight of numbers and think that is being very clever and very smart. All I can say is that I thought that a politician who has been in the national parliament for 25 years and who has something of a reputation as being a skilled political operator would have done a little better than to be so unsophisticated and so unsubtle.
