PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister did not bother, when he was making his speech, to refer to the ALP instructions. He said, `The person handing out the preference how-to-vote should attempt to get the last position in the queue.' That is fair enough. He continued, `. . . not forgetting that there is a minimum distance of six metres.' Here is a sheet that says, `Booth captains preference how-to-vote green slips.' Listen to this, Mr Speaker. It says, `For those booths which have preference how-to-vote cards, please don't have ALP identifiable badges.'

Here is the interesting thing. It says, `We want to distinguish between those giving out ALP how-to-votes and those giving out preference how-to-votes. In other words the instructions are saying, `We want to disguise the fact that we are trying to dupe the voters.' That was the gravamen of my question. It was true and correct in every particular. I accept that, notwithstanding, those opposite will use their weight of numbers but I take the opportunity, as the Prime Minister did, to say a number of general things about electoral matters. Sheer self-indulgence prevents me from suppressing a natural desire to go back into a bit of history.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, resume your seat. The Leader of the House will come next.
—I know that I should not do it but there was a book written by Anthea Carew—listen to this beautiful quote—who said:

SPEECH.PARA: Tension mounted. The right wanted the challenge votes counted; the left did not. The only way out of the impasse that had developed was to call the general returning officer, Lindsay North, who had the power to intervene.

TALK.START.PARA: —What year?
—It continues:

SPEECH.PARA: There was no telephone in the scout hall and Laurie Brereton roared off into the night on his motor cycle to call North. The returning officer had just got to bed after counting a preselection ballot in another seat and he refused to come out again. Brereton decided to go straight to the top—
that is direct action, Laurie—
and he rang Gough Whitlam, then leader of the ALP, at his home in Cabramatta. Whitlam remembers the call.
Of course he does. It continues:

He was unwilling to become involved in a preselection dispute, having always distanced himself from machine business. Time dragged on. Abuse flew between the opposing sides. Around 1 a.m. North arrived with all his pyjamas visible under his clothes and declaring the votes to be in dispute, he confiscated the boxes.

But more is to come. The most interesting part of this great saga about the preselection ballot of the Prime Minister of Australia was the report into it by the then Federal President of the ALP, who is now the Deputy Premier of Queensland in the Goss Labor government—hardly a Liberal Party stooge. He is hardly on the staff of the federal secretariat of the Liberal Party, is he? This is what it said under `Preselection':

Blaxland. The preselection ballot was held on 26 October. There were six candidates. On the evening of the count, Juner polled 88 votes, Keating 81 votes and 63 went to the other candidates. When those preferences were allocated, the vote was Juner 124, Keating 108 and 49 went unchallenged. These included 30 from Condal Park, two from Central Bankstown, 14 from Bass Hill and five others. The general returning officer completed the ballot on 1 November and—
listen to this, miraculously enough, amazing—
the final ballot figures were Keating 146, Juner 125.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members—Fraud! Fraud!

TALK.START.PARA: —But listen to this. I am horrified to say that it gets worse. This is Tom Burns, not John Howard. It continues:

SPEECH.PARA: The action of the New South Wales executive secured the result by allowing supporters who would join the party outside of the express party rules to participate. Twenty-seven supporters of Mr Keating who were allowed to vote were admitted into Central Bankstown branch, yet they not only lived in the Condal Park area but in joining Central Bankstown branch were outside their state electorate and their federal electoral divisions.
It then goes on to condemn him in quite explicit terms. It goes on to say about the Prime Minister:

The obvious stacking of branches and the sacking of branches appears to have been carried out deliberately, intending to ensure certain people gained selection. As some of these people are now federal members of parliament, these actions must assume importance in the eyes of the federal executive. I strongly disapprove of the actions of the New South Wales officers in these preselection ballots.

They are not the words of a Labor majority. They are not the words of the Liberal Party stooge. They are the words of Paul Keating. I will just conclude by saying this: this country is now led by a man who rorted his preselection in order to gain entry into parliament. He is the last person who has any moral authority—either here or anywhere in Australia—to lecture anybody about honesty.

PARA.TAB: As one of my colleagues said to me, he is in need of an honesty transplant but cannot find a donor on the front bench. When it comes to dirty tricks, when it comes to rorting preselection ballots, when it comes to misleading the public, when it comes to lying to the Australian people, there is no person better at rorting a preselection than the Prime Minister. There is no person better at telling a l-i-e than the Prime Minister. There is no person better at deceiving the Australian people than the Prime Minister. There is no person who has been more consistently up to his armpits in lying and deceiving of the Australian public than the Prime Minister.

All I can say to the Prime Minister is that if he wants to fight the next election campaign on the question of honesty and integrity—oh, I could be so lucky. That is all I can say—oh, I could be so lucky. Prime Minister, please will you fight the election campaign on the issue of honesty and integrity? I would be delighted. I know they say that you do not like me, but actually I think deep down you might. Why don't you do me a real favour and fight the election campaign on the question of honesty and integrity?

I will put my honesty and integrity on the line any day against yours. I could not be more delighted. I hope that you do this again. I hope that you do it every week, because it affords us a tremendous opportunity to point out what a deceiving, dishonest, lying politician you really are.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Fifteen minutes, and not one word about push polling; 15 minutes, and one minute was in defence of himself on this question; 15 minutes, and not one statement about Mr Robb's shenanigans in his national office last week and this week; 15 minutes, and all of it the product of one book handed over to him by Grahame Morris, whose activities have been the subject of very considerable questioning in the media today; 15 minutes solely on a product that had been handed out, retailed, a piece of literature which has been around for donkeys years.

PARA.TAB: What we have not got with John Howard is this: you are allowed to talk about 1969; you are allowed to talk about 1995; but what you are not allowed to talk about is 1977 to 1983. You are allowed to talk about 1929; you are allowed to talk about 1946; but, for God's sake, don't mention the war. Whatever you do, don't mention the war. Also, `Do not for one minute mention how I got my name honest John.'

If ever there was a lucky politician in Australia it has to be the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), because the population in general would now believe that the nickname honest John came from a reputation for public integrity during the time he was a minister. In fact, the nickname honest John was coined at one decisive point: it was coined in 1978 after the 1978 budget in which the Hobart Mercury—the most extreme in terms of its presentation, and with the rest of the Australian provincial dailies all with the same theme—carried on the front page the words `lies, lies, lies' in huge bold type. They carried those words `lies, lies, lies' because John Howard had brought down a budget and in that budget was a direct repudiation of all the election promises he had put forward in 1977. So, from that day on until quite recently, honest was accompanied by quotation marks. That is where the title came from. This is a useful opportunity for us to provide the House with a reminder of that point.

Generally speaking, in these censure debates the Liberals actually have the courage to stay in the chamber but they have all gone. They went straight out the door, except the poor chap at the table, the member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly), who has to sit here and carry the can for his leader because somebody has to sit on the opposition front bench. The member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall), who has covered himself in glory in recent days by his efforts inside the Liberal Party to deal with the issue of push polling, is also sitting here and half of the Independents are sitting here.

The others have retreated to lick their wounds because this is a censure debate that they invited upon themselves. We did not start off with the intention of censuring them for this; we merely started off with the intention of pointing out a few facts. But members of the opposition said, `Oh, please, get up and censure us' and so we did. We are obliging fellows and so we got up and censured them. When we did, there was not a single word of reply from the opposition leader to the gravamen of the point.

I show to the House the how-to-vote card. I will go through it again because I think it is necessary to debate the point of the censure and argue the toss as to what that point means. If you have got evidentiary documents associated with it, then you might as well table them and go through it. Any person receiving this piece of paper could in no way be misled about where it came from because it has the Australian Labor Party logo sitting there. It has written across the bottom of the page, `Authorised by Doug Thompson, Australian Labor Party'. It does not carry on top of it a No. 1 preference because it is handed out in the assumption that the person receiving it is going to vote Independent No. 1. It simply carries on down the list from that point onwards.

So it is not a bogus how-to-vote card in itself. A bogus how-to-vote card, indeed, might have carried the number `1' upon it. The opposition failed to point out that this was taken up with the Electoral Commissioner for the ACT who, at the end of the day, approved it. I wonder, however, whether he approved this little document from the same election. This little document says:

SPEECH.PARA: Ratepayers revolt. Vote 1 Lucinda Spier column B on ballot.

It is authorised by P. Jansen of 12 Dampier Crescent, Forrest. Is there a sign on it that says `Liberal Party candidate'? Is there a sign on this which has the logo of the Liberal Party in Canberra? Is it anywhere on this document?

PARA.TAB: Who is Lucinda Spier? Lucinda Spier is a Liberal Party candidate but there is a bogus how-to-vote card put out for her called `Ratepayers revolt'. I am afraid, old son, when you start to sling the muck in this particular show, you never know where it is going to stick—and it is sticking very solidly on you lot when it comes to the performance of the ACT branch.

Mr Howard was very keen to spend a very long time quoting from a book by Edna Carew, a book which has now been in circulation for the best part of a decade, as though anybody in politics has not yet read it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I haven't!

—The Prime Minister hasn't. Many others, nevertheless, will have. But we have more recent preselections to discuss than that preselection; we have the one of immediate interest to us. The Canberra branch of the Liberal Party is a pack of classics when it comes to dealing with the issues of an election. It also put out bogus how-to-vote cards with no clarity at all about the origins of those how-to-vote cards. One great thing in politics that you learn very early on is projection: when somebody comes at you, there is a 90 per cent chance that he is coming at you with a problem for himself. And if you get in behind it, you might well find something very interesting as you spend your time going through.

PARA.TAB: My father is a bit of a right-winger in Labor Party affairs. He used to always say to me, which I thought was unduly fair on his behalf, `I'm afraid to say, Kim, in a union ballot when they scream commo, you scream auditors.' Nevertheless, this is obviously a very similar case that we have here on our hands: we ought to scream Electoral Commission, having had this particular accusation levelled at us.

I have here an interesting report from today's newspaper the Canberra Times. It says `Top Liberal candidates miss out'. There was an awful lot talked about by the Leader of the Opposition in his 12-minute readings from past literature and his three-minute defence of himself, and that was about people who get ballots and do not actually win elections. The report states:
The Liberal candidate for the Canberra by-election did not top the poll of party members for the preselection, according to party informants.

Others say the leading candidates who lost, on the Left and the Centre of the party, were subjected to a right-wing disinformation campaign that fitted the pattern, if not the depths, of the push-polling campaign against Labor's candidate, Sue Robinson.

SPEECH.PARA: If you go on and read the rest of this very sorry little report, you will find the statement by the Liberals, `We don't really care what Liberal Party members feel in this area. There is a little closed purple circle and we will hear the opinion of the members but we will appoint whom we like at the end of the day. We'll put them through a poll. It doesn't matter what votes they get in that poll, rorted or otherwise, we are going to select exactly whom we desire. And our own party members that we would otherwise have thought in good standing, we will subject them to the sort of campaign that Sue Robinson has been subject to in this situation.' The Liberal Party is very fast off the mark in accusations over here on the subject of honesty.

PARA.TAB: I raised the issue in this parliament yesterday, in, I thought, a fairly light-hearted sort of way, because I do not really want to see Andrew Robb in gaol for six months; nor do I want to see him fined $2,500. I have lower ambitions. I merely wish his leader to repudiate him. That is all. I do not want to see him in gaol. I do not want to see him in any way, shape or form fined. But I would not mind seeing his leader give him a bit of repudiation every now and then.

But what did we find? I mentioned it in a fairly unheavy fashion because I did not know whether the Liberal Party had cleared with the Western Australian lottery commission the particular raffle book that it sent to George Gear's family. I could not have told from that document—unlike this document which the Liberals could tell was a Labor Party circulated document—whether it had been cleared with the Western Australian gaming commission because it contained only reference to Northern Territory and Australian Capital Territory licences. So I left it hanging as to whether anything untoward had happened.

What happened? The old push pollers of the Liberal Party—they are no longer spin doctors—including the leader, were up around the gallery saying, `Beazley's overstepped himself. He's finally caught himself out.' Paul Bongiorno, who runs the evening claquer service for the Liberal Party, made a statement saying, `The government has clearly overstepped itself as far as this issue is concerned.'

I was prepared to let it rest at that and to leave as an open question whether anything had happened. But one of the journalists, Lenore Taylor, actually had the presence of mind to ring the Western Australian gaming commission. What did Lenore Taylor find when examining the words of the honest push pollers, the honest Leader of the Opposition, the epitome of honesty in his office? Her article reads:

SPEECH.PARA: However, a spokesman for the WA Office of Racing and Gaming told The Australian that the Liberal Party had broken the law by failing to include the number of its WA permit on the tickets and said that the tickets had never been seen by the gaming office.

PARA.TAB: "(The Liberal Party) made the mistake and we will issue them a warning letter but take no further action than that,". . .

SPEECH.PARA: As I said before, I do not particularly want any action to be taken on the matter. But I am quite enjoying the fact that the Liberals' spin doctoring has been revealed for the tissue of lies that it is, as is the case with most of their other activities.

PARA.TAB: But I do take exception to the sorts of things that Sue Robinson has been subjected to in Canberra. I take very grave exception to those. As pointed out by the Prime Minister, the Leader of the Opposition has not repudiated those. The reason we have the censure motion in this place is the pathetic effort by the Leader of the Opposition to mislead this House, in coming forward with a ticket, properly marked by the Labor Party, and alleging that there was something wrong with it—when in fact it had been cleared. The reason he has done that is that he wants to crawfish out of the consequences of his failing to repudiate the people on his staff and the people in the federal office for the various shenanigans that they have got up to, including that most heinous of shenanigans associated with push polling.

I am pleased to say that so far there have been three or four editorials on this matter. It has been considered of sufficient weight, dealing with the integrity and honesty in the Australian electoral system. It has not been brushed off by them as a slight matter of no moment. There have been editorials by three or four of our major daily papers saying that this form of activity, this form of defamation, this suggesting that a particular candidate has written books inviting people to go and burn down the houses of the burghers of Canberra—which is what was suggested by the Liberals—and that the candidate endorsed a proposition that people should be entitled to legal terminations of pregnancy at nine months, and a whole plethora of slanderous lies that were incorporated in that push polling technique, should be banned.

All of those newspapers had the opportunity, and have taken it, to repudiate this activity. The only person who still thinks it is a pretty good idea—or, if he does not think it is a good idea, he has taken the view that he will just let it flick past and if the old boss cocky of the Liberal Party decides to pursue it at some point in time he will let that pass too—has been honest John, trying to cover himself with a piece of work that is purely contemptible, but a piece of work which stands in such dramatic contrast with the Liberals' behaviour.

There is no doubt that, in the course of political campaigns in which there is a plethora of political parties, political parties will try to take advantage of that situation. But here the Labor Party presents an honest statement. The Labor Party says, `Put the Liberals last. Authorised by Doug Thompson, Australian Labor Party. If you vote Independent and you want your preference to go to the ALP, this is how you do it.' The Labor Party tells people what it is doing but the `Ratepayers revolt' put things out with no Liberal Party identification. There is no indication whatsoever where they come from. If you are in the independent minded ratepayers revolt group, just rock on out there and vote Liberal. That is the proposition put forward by the Liberal Party.

The Leader of the Opposition invited his personal censure. He gave us no reason why he should not be censured. There is no doubt that, after we have heard from the next Liberal Party speaker, this House is going to take advantage of that opportunity. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Labor Party opposite never learns and it never changes. Any sensible analysis of the political activities of the Labor Party—especially in New South Wales since the 1970s—demonstrates beyond any reasonable doubt that you never learn and you never change.

PARA.TAB: This censure motion today is to complain that the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) misled the House with his allegations about how-to-vote arrangements in the ACT. These were not allegations; these were facts. The basis of the facts is none other than the documentation, which was circulated to ALP branch workers at the ACT elections and which I hold in my hand. The evidence contained in these documents shows beyond all reasonable doubt that the claims made by the opposition are absolutely correct. The important thing is that neither the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) nor the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) makes any serious attempt to explain the unexplainable. Why is it so? It is because in the ACT election we merely saw a continuation of a long line of cheating, cajolery and activities of this dubious nature that you and your party in virtually every state of Australia—whether it be Queensland, New South Wales or Victoria—have perpetrated for far too long.

Let me start with Queensland. There was a by-election in the seat of Mirani. There was a Confederate Action Party candidate. This particular candidate claimed to give his second preferences to the National Party. But was the Labor Party to be outdone on this? Was there any risk to be taken? Of course not. The Labor Party put out its own how-to-vote card, which said, `Make your voice heard in the government by voting for the Confederate Action Party,' but then it said—we are told this is the Labor Party technique—`Don't support Borbidge's bickering coalition. Give your second preference to your Wayne Goss Labor candidate Graeme Hall and do not waste your vote.' Any reasonable person reading that document would say that it had been put out by the Confederate Action Party.

Let me now move to what happened in Victoria. The general secretary, Peter Bachelor, issued a bogus how-to-vote card in the Nunawading by-election in the 1980s. Labor denied it but, eventually, you admitted your fault. You admitted that you were cheating. There is two out of two.

Now I will move to the ACT, which is the subject of this particular debate. I suggest that in this particular case one can only conclude that the motive was deception. It was deception in its most vile form. For the benefit of those members opposite who may not want to believe what some of their colleagues get up to when they get the opportunity, this is what a preference how-to-vote card looks like a la ALP. Booth captains at the ACT election were told that booths that have preference how-to-vote cards will not have ALP identifiable badges, et cetera.

I am a reasonable man. I am sure all my colleagues here are reasonable people. When they are facing a situation like that, they have to turn to that fundamental word `motive'. If the motive of the Labor Party booth captains was to encourage their booth workers to deliberately disseminate information which they knew to be inaccurate, it is deception. There is no other way to describe it.

Further, this document states, `We want to distinguish between those giving out ALP how-to-votes and those giving out preference how-to-votes.' The key word is `distinguish'. What was the Labor Party trying to distinguish? Was it trying to distinguish Liberal votes from Labor votes? Was it trying to distinguish Independent votes from Labor votes, or Independent votes from Liberal votes? You do not have to be more than a halfwit to work out that the Labor Party in Canberra and its booth workers knew precisely what they were trying to distinguish, because they have told us. They were trying to distinguish between those giving out ALP how-to-votes and those giving out preference how-to-votes.

Why were they trying to do that? They were doing that with a deliberate intention to deceive the electors of Canberra and to make them believe they were voting independent. There it is. They are not my words; it is your document. They are not my thoughts, your intentions. They are not my desires, your deceit. There is no doubt about it.

The next document has instructions for handing out preference how-to-vote cards—euphemistically and very appropriately called green slips. The first instruction is: the person handing out the preference how-to-votes should attempt to get the last position in the queue—that is, the position closest to the polling booth—not forgetting that there is a minimum distance of six metres. It was very generous of them to tell us that. Why were they doing that? They were positioning their people deliberately so that, as the electors went into the booth, the last piece of paper they would receive would be this dubious piece of bumf—this dubious piece of paper—telling them that if they voted Independent not to give the Liberal/Alliance—

TALK.START.PARA: —What's it say on the bottom?

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—Order! The honourable member for Page!

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been here for long enough to learn one interesting lesson: those who shout the loudest are always those who have the most to protect themselves from. If they wanted the facts, they would listen.
—That's my line.

—Even you and I can agree on something. The second instruction gives the line to use when handing out the how-to-votes, and this is part of the real substance of the deception. It says that the line used should be something like `Voting Independent?' Do not forget, we are dealing with people who have no badges on, no distinguishing ALP characteristics at all. Why? Because they were told by the Labor Party to take them off. If that is not deception, would you please tell us what is.

PARA.TAB: People going to the polling booth took this piece of paper, believing that they had the opportunity to exercise their democratic right and vote Independent because it had the word `Independent' along the top of it. Voters in the ACT did not know the truth; they had no reason to doubt this. They are learning what millions of Australians have learnt in recent days, and it is quite simple: you cannot trust Labor with anything. You really cannot. When you look back on its record, you find that it never learns and it never changes. I have demonstrated in this debate that—
Dr Theophanous interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister is not helping.

—I have demonstrated in this debate that, whether you are talking about by-elections in Queensland or in Nunawading, Victoria, whether you are talking about the rorting of preselections—such as Mr Keating's own preselection in New South Wales in 1970 or so—nothing changes. This mob cannot lie straight in bed.

PARA.TAB: When the Leader of the House made his great contribution, he complained that my colleagues were not here to listen to him. They had much more sensible things to do. He made one most interesting comment. He talked about presenting an honest statement! The evidence is so blatant. You forgot that the word `honesty' has a little `dis' in front of it. It is called dishonesty, and there is a heck of a difference between the two words. A growing number of people in this country have had enough; they want a bit of honesty in government. They want to see the situation improved. They will not see that from a Labor Party which, time after time, has demonstrated so clearly its utter inability to properly improve the situation. I turn now to branch stacking. Back in 1970 a certain gentleman who is now the Deputy Premier of Queensland—
Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Both sides will come to order. The member for Bradfield has the call.

—Thank you, Mr Speaker. A report was brought down on the New South Wales ALP. It was a report by the then federal president, Mr Tom Burns, into the administration of the New South Wales branch of the party. He spoke about the preselection for the seat of Blaxland. Keating won that preselection because the central office made jolly sure that he did. His friend Laurie Brereton even had his motorbike there to prove it.

PARA.TAB: The important thing is that, from the beginning to the end of this whole sorry situation, time and again this Labor Party is simply incapable of having an honest situation where it sees any prospect whatsoever of getting a benefit.
Much has been said by both the Prime Minister and the Leader of the House about the fact that the Leader of the Opposition has not had anything to say about push polling.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's right.
—I am very glad you said that. I draw your attention to the transcript of a public interview on the public record on 2 March. This is what he said:

SPEECH.PARA: I'm in favour of orthodox benchmark research. I'm not in favour of what you call push-polling.

PARA.TAB: Mr Snowdon interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I warn the honourable member for the Northern Territory.
—He made further observations:

SPEECH.PARA: I've made it clear, and I make it clear to you publicly that so-called push-polling is not something that I support.

That is on the record, and that is our position. But that is not the issue of this particular motion. The motion we are discussing today concerns the how-to-vote arrangements of the ACT. I will finish my observations by referring once again to the instructions, the important part of which states:

If the polling booth official questions the validity of the preference how to vote, you should continue to hand out the how to votes and refer the official to ALP Headquarters, preferably to Richard Webb or Doug Thompson.
It further states:
The person handing out the preference how to vote should not be wearing any ALP identifiers ie Badge, Stickers, T-shirts or Hat.

Deceit! Deceit! Deceit! That is your badge. That is the badge that you have worn for the last 13 years. It is a badge that will lead you into infamy in the political history of this country. The people of Australia deserve better. Their elections have to be above board. They expect the government of the day to honour the integrity of the political and electoral system of Australia. You have brought shame upon yourselves and distrust upon our system. (Time expired)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Higher Education Funding Act—Determinations Nos. T1-95, T2-95, T3-95, T4-95.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins) took the chair at 10.00 a.m.

DEBATE.SUB2.TITLE: Report on violence in Australian schools

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 7 December 1994, on motion by Mr Beazley:
That the House take note of the paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to have the opportunity to make the first response to the government's response to a report by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training entitled Sticks and stones, which was a report on violence in Australian schools. It is interesting when debating in this chamber that, unlike the major chamber of the House of Representatives, the enemy faces each other eyeball to eyeball across the chamber. This report of the committee, which is an all-party committee of this House, was a unanimous report.

PARA.TAB: I learned a number of major things in participating in this inquiry. The first thing that I learned which was most significant is that teachers believe that those who commit physical violence generally lack self-esteem. The second thing that I learned which I believe is of significance is that over the past two decades, as a permissive society has developed, we have increasingly given children their rights, but, in the absence of parental discipline and the structures of dos and don'ts, children have been left to flounder, without direction and experience in how to take responsibility for their own actions and deal responsibly with their peers and with the broader community. That is a substantive problem.

The third major thing that I learned during the inquiry was that there are models of school practice which generally exhibit strong leadership and a whole school approach, creating a culture of caring that negates both violence and bullying. In that respect, I discussed the experiences of Mayfield Primary School in Launceston. The Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Mr Free) has largely accepted the findings of our report.

I would now like to deal with some of the more major recommendations. The minister has said in his report that he believes that a series of forums on violence in schools held in each state and territory would be a very useful process for compiling the good practice that is occurring in schools around Australia.

I have no major philosophical disagreement with the minister about holding forums, but it seems to me, in a practical sense, that we would be doing an awful lot of spinning wheels, bringing together a lot of people for lots of discussions, which would simply parallel other meetings and other discussions. The committee mentality and structure carries on.

I would have much preferred that the minister had accepted our recommendations in principle and then an expert go out and do some fact finding. Let us fund an expert to do some fact finding and report on the primary schools of Australia: to report on good practice, particularly where their practice has acted to almost totally eliminate the concept of bullying; to report on practices which have been successful in integrating strong approaches at dealing with problems of illiteracy, particularly in the early years of primary school; and to disseminate that information widely to primary and secondary schools throughout Australia.

An expert charged with this responsibility could call for submissions from schools that had demonstrated exemplary practice. That person could then collate the information and make it available. This would be more useful than holding a series of talkfests.

The minister dealt firstly with our recommendation that the ministers of the Commonwealth, states and territories fund the evaluation of successful approaches adopted by schools. It was his response to hold a series of forums, which I have dealt with. However, he did go on in his recommendation and canvass the possibility that the Commonwealth would investigate establishing, in cooperation with the state and territory governments, a best practice award for schools that display leadership in this field. I commend the minister for that response; I think that will be really useful.

One of the things that we have learned through this committee, in travelling around the country, is that the apprenticeship awards—the awards that deal with excellence in the international skills olympics—have been a tremendous boost to TAFE colleges and to the apprenticeship systems around the country. Many of those young people who have participated in the international skills olympics have gone on to find rewarding, responsible and satisfying jobs very early in their careers. No doubt their participation in those skills olympics has enhanced their career prospects. They provide an example for their peers who are studying in the skills field. I compliment the minister on his suggestion for a best practice award and would suggest that that is appropriate.

We recommended that the minister, in consultation with the states, finance the development of a national school violence data collection system. The minister has in total agreed with us. I thank the minister. The minister said that the Commonwealth will refer this recommendation to the School Statistics Taskforce of the Ministerial Council on Education, Employment, Training and Youth Affairs and that he would ask the task force to examine how more extensive national data on the issue can be obtained and how the data could be used for the development of performance indicators on school violence. That is a very good initiative.

There is no way the Commonwealth could now impose its will or the committee's will on the states, and nor should it. This is a complex area and involves issues such as: the definition of violence—and levels of violence; the issue of bullying and where it fits in those definitions; and how we report on those issues. It does need to be decided by consensus. All the states need to agree finally on a formula of definition so that the data collection can recommence throughout the country in an identical manner, so at the end of the day we have some numbers that are of use to us.

This committee was told anecdotally that physical violence was on the wane and that there was less physical violence in schools in Australia today than 30 or 40 years ago. That is a very positive outcome, but we are not sure if that is true. The problem is there is no data to back up the observations. We really need a comprehensive but simple data collection system that will give us some numbers and allow people to take actions based on the findings. For example, if some mechanisms in some states are working and producing outcomes which are better than the models in other states, certainly it would behove the states who are having poor results to take cognisance of the fact that they have colleagues in other places who seem to be doing it better, and perhaps they should shift their practices. This data collection issue is really quite important.

Another of our recommendations was that the minister discuss with the state and territory ministers the need for early intervention strategies to address violent and anti-social behaviour in students. In part, the minister's response said that the Commonwealth government endorses the committee's finding that preventative action in the early years of schooling is far more likely to prove effective than any piecemeal or remedial solutions focused on students in older age groups. I thank the minister for that. We are convinced that is right.

If we get it right early, the chances are that behaviour will be vastly improved in the later years of schooling as well. However, we did receive some evidence that some young people who demonstrate no tendencies to violence or bullying in primary school seem to go a bit haywire under some peer pressure or community or social mores when they reach their teens, and there have to be different mechanisms to deal with that.

The minister talked about the gender and violence project, developing a video on violence for use in primary schools, but this issue is not just a gender issue. It is not just that little boys beat up on little girls or big boys beat up on big girls; in fact there was some anecdotal evidence that young girls are increasingly resorting to verbal bullying themselves, and that is quite worrying for many of our educators. I am not sure that this is totally a gender issue. Certainly, the physical violence occurs largely between young males—or young males physically violating young girls—but the bullying aspect seems to be more evenly balanced and the fact that there seems to be some increasing physical violence amongst young girls was worrying to the committee.

One of our recommendations was an examination of the effects of television, video, film and video games on the learning outcomes and behaviour of Australian children. The minister agrees with our concern that media and entertainment may have an effect on violence and behaviour of children, not only in the school setting but in the broader community. The minister says that the communications and the arts portfolio already makes a significant contribution to safeguarding the wellbeing of children in relation to media content. I think I would have to question the minister's statement. I am not totally convinced that our classification mechanisms do work.

When I turn on my television, which is rare I must admit, there certainly are days when no matter what channel I switch to there is nothing but violence on show. I am not convinced that that is for the betterment of our young people. I note that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has recently called for the examination of the possibility of a fourth free to air television channel, largely dedicated to families and children. I suppose that is worth exploring, although I am not sure that there is enough market and I think that market research would have to be done. I can tell you that many families would support a reduction in the amount of violence that we see on free to air television in Australia. Perhaps pay TV will help solve part of this problem. One can only hope, but we will never know until we get there and unfortunately we are a bit slow in that regard.

But, in discussing our recommendation on the International Year of the Family, the minister went on to compliment the government for supporting the parents' role in school education by providing $555,000 to the parents association over three years, and that is in rather dramatic conflict with the donation of the Minister for Health (Dr Lawrence) of a quarter of million dollars in one shot to the December issue of Cleo, which goes out, unfortunately, to 13- to 18-year-old females, which I believe was inappropriate in all the circumstances, dealing with the issues that we are dealing with here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Henzell Ms M.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to have the opportunity to speak on the government's response to the report Sticks and stones, a report on violence in Australian schools by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training. I acknowledge the contribution by the chair of that committee, the member for Forde (Ms Crawford), and the previous speaker, the member for La Trobe (Mr Charles), who was the deputy chair of that committee.

PARA.TAB: This is an issue of very considerable concern to parents. In my previous professional experience I had some involvement in counselling victims of violence in schools, and also as a parent, as I charted my own daughter's journey through primary and secondary education, I have been a concerned consumer in this area. It is very pleasing to note the general support of the government for the committee's report and a number of initiatives that the government is taking on board in response to this report. The response has actually been presented very quickly, in my view.

I want to make some comments about the general area. I certainly think there is a need for further research but also, as the government indicates, it is prepared to participate in the collection of data and the dissemination of that data to schools, particularly on the incidence as well as benchmarks and best practice options that the committee was able to pick up during the course of its inquiry.

One area that I have some concern about is the evidence on the causal relationship between violence and self-esteem of the perpetrators and the victims. I believe there does need to be much more research into what determines why some children choose to bully. However, I acknowledge that it is not simply an individual psychological problem but that we have to look at a number of factors that cause violence in schools. I note the committee's comments on page 11, paragraph 2.3:

SPEECH.PARA: This committee agrees with the view that violence does not arise from a single cause.
In this, it agrees with the national committee on violence. It says:
Evidence suggested the following influences in the school context: the family; cultural factors, especially social and economic inequality; media influences; and aspects of the school environment.

I believe that not only a whole of school approach is required to combat violence but a whole of community approach, and it does mean getting parents involved and out of school factors as well as media, and in particular the social structure of the school system.

PARA.TAB: One of the initiatives that I as a parent was involved with in the primary school that my children attended was the development of a human relationships education program. This whole issue had a very long gestation and parents fought for it in the dark days of conservative rule in Queensland. When the green light was given for the development of human relationships education, a great deal was done by the Queensland education department to foster community involvement.

There were a number of participants in my small mining community. What was interesting, I have to say, was that a minority group which represented—if one would describe it as such—a `fundamentalist Christian' position had a very narrow view of what should constitute a human relationships education. I would have to summarise it as a `God, queen, country and the Bible' type of approach, with very limited opportunities to present the plurality of society. However, the consultation, with the support of the Queensland Department of Education, went ahead, and we developed a very positive program for our school community.

One of the issues that I believe is very important is the recognition of the power structures within a school. That very much involves having the adults in the school system be aware of the sort of power that they have, and of when the system can get into the abuse of power. It has been my experience, in observing children, that they have a very strong sense of social justice and are very aware when teachers override what could be seen as fair play or a fair and reasonable outcome. It is very important that teachers be aware of that when they use their power as adults: their power to be more articulate and more analytical, and to put students down. So, when we look at the structures that need to be in place to provide a really caring school, based on mutual respect, all relationships need to be taken into consideration.
One of the very important findings of the committee is in relation to the importance of early intervention. I quote from page 8 of the introduction. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: The majority of evidence suggests that inappropriate behaviours are identifiably in children as early as pre-school and kindergarten. Changing a child's behaviour patterns after the age of eight requires significantly more resourcing, with reduced changes of success, than if the problem was addressed in the earliest schooling years.

Indeed, I can remember observing a number of children who went right through kindergarten, preschool and grades one and two with my daughters. It was very clear that they had already embarked upon a career that would ultimately isolate them and nominate them as troublemakers and difficult children. I then saw the responses that were used—being, at that time, very traditional school discipline responses—having absolutely no success at all.

PARA.TAB: At that stage, I was not practising professionally, but I was bringing my professional eye to my observations. Living in a small community, I could also see the complementary family problems that were contributing to the way these children would present at school. I was feeling very concerned to know that this would be the ultimate outcome for these children. So I fully endorse the recommendation of the committee about the need for early intervention strategies, and I endorse the response from the government in this area.

The other very important area that I think we should spend a couple of minutes on is the types of violence. If one looks at the media representations, one tends to see the more overt type of bullying. But, as the previous speaker said, actual, overt physical violence—the `putting kids' heads down the toilets' type of harassment, which still happens—is less rare than other forms of bullying.
However, the other forms of bullying are particularly destructive to the developing self-esteem of young people. I quote from page 7. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee was told that one of the biggest unrecognised aspects of violence in schools was gender harassment. As a component of violence, it was widespread in schools and was largely unrecognised as a violent act. One survey found that, as part of their day to day routine, girls in co-educational classrooms and school yards suffered sex-based harassment from boys and sometimes teachers. The Committee was also advised that physical violence amongst girls was more likely to occur than it was in the past.
That was mentioned by the previous speaker. It goes on to say:
Harassment and violence is also directed towards gay, lesbian and bisexual students.

On that point, I want to quote from an article headed `Homophobia starts at school, let's stop it here' in the Australian of 1 March—just yesterday, in fact—which gives an account of a high school assembly on 1 August last year where it was suggested that an absent student was gay. When this student attempted to have redress for this accusation, and the resulting hostility and isolation, he got no support at all. I gather this case is now subject to some further investigation.

PARA.TAB: This is one of the newer types of harassment—attempting to pigeonhole all the students in terms of their gender orientation. But it is absolutely inappropriate, whether it be in grade two or in grade eight or nine, where I believe it reaches its zenith. It is a way of isolating and imposing a power differential. Often that involves a peer group—there is an in-group and an out-group, whether it is the cool group and the not-so-cool group or some other group. But to raise suggestions that someone is not in the mainstream of heterosexual orientation is very distressing to many students who, of course, have not really developed a clear sexual orientation. It is very important that those kinds of issues are addressed and students learn to understand the type of process in which they are all unconsciously involved. I have certainly seen this operating in schools in my electorate.

Racism and talking about different ethnic backgrounds is very important. The other issue that is part of this is where students are different and I suspect this is what the previous speaker was mentioning. Gender harassment is not all about violence from one sex to the other, although the evidence indicates that it is males who primarily are the perpetrators. However, it is about students who are different, and one of the things that all schools must address is the importance of allowing people to be themselves. Not everybody is going to be the best cricketer, the best netball player, the most beautiful, most Elle look-alike girl in the school, or the person who looks like whoever the male role models are at the moment—probably Shane Warne or someone.

TALK.START.PARA: —The member for Brisbane!

—Well, if it is the Parliamentary Secretary, I do not mind. But the important thing is that, across the spectrum, children are as individual as, dare I say, my colleagues in this parliament—and most of us would not make it onto the big screen. I believe it is a very important part of the whole school approach to allow boys to be more feminine and more interested in quieter pursuits, to allow girls to be more assertive and interested in sport and computers, to allow variation and to help students and teachers value that individual difference in people. Teaching students assertive techniques and to be constructively assertive, rather than aggressive, is very important. But clarifying communication is also very important.

PARA.TAB: To return to the gender violence issue, the other part of that that we have to address is the structural inequality in many schools. As the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training said on page 14 of its report on violence in Australian schools:

SPEECH.PARA: The committee understands that while eighty per cent of teachers in primary schools are women, only twenty to thirty per cent are principals.
So already there are a number of power differentials that provide role models for the students. We have to get away from what constitutes masculinity and femininity.

PARA.TAB: I believe it is an excellent report and I certainly applaud the government's response. That response mentions many of the government's current initiatives that will assist the provision of a much more effective, whole of school approach. For example, on page 13, the Commonwealth reminds us that:

SPEECH.PARA: Funding totalled about $3 billion in 1993: $1.29 billion supported government schools; $1.59 billion supported non-government schools and $64 million was provided jointly in the two sectors.

Programs like the national domestic violence education program, the national prevention strategy for child abuse and neglect, which is very important, and the task force on gender equity are all being supported by the Commonwealth. Obviously, once again, cooperation from state governments will be required. Issues such as literacy have been responded to.

PARA.TAB: The committee has made a very positive contribution and I am delighted to see that the government is responding very significantly. Might I say in the last few seconds available to me that my own daughter has won an award to present a film which will go to the issue of violence in families, so I am hoping that her role will make a small contribution.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ronaldson Mr M.J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the comments made by the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles). Having heard the honourable member for Capricornia (Ms Henzell), I am sure there are a lot of people on both sides of the chamber who have dealt with school violence and its results. The member for Capricornia, of course, is a former social worker. I am sure that she has seen that for herself.

PARA.TAB: I will not take much time from the comments I am just about to make but—with all due respect to you, Mr Deputy Speaker—I find it quite extraordinary that we are addressing a report on violence in Australian schools which is of the utmost importance to parents right throughout Australia in what I consider the Clayton's chamber. My views on the necessity for this chamber are well known. I think it is a disgrace that we are not debating this downstairs. Again, I hasten to add, that is said with no disrespect intended to you, Mr Deputy Speaker.

I am grateful for the opportunity to say a few words before the Main Committee as we take note of the government response to the report by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, Sticks and stones, on the issue of violence in Australian schools. The issue of school violence is justifiably of great concern to many in the community. As a parent, I do not think it is too much to expect my children to feel safe and secure when I leave them at school in the morning. I would also expect that my children would learn both respect and responsibility for their fellow students. I think this is an expectation shared by all parents but, regrettably, for some it is not a reality.

A recent MBF survey conducted in New South Wales found that a vast majority of primary school children starting high school feared initiation ceremonies and bullying by older students. This fear is real; this fear is genuine. Ms Victoria King, an education consultant from Victoria, states quite correctly that students had limited—what she called—coping skills to deal with being put down or to deal with conflict and bullying. It is these limited coping abilities which result in violence in schools having such a detrimental effect on the victims.

Research conducted in the ACT suggested that nearly a quarter of children were likely to be physically or verbally harassed. However, as bullying rarely occurs in front of an adult witness, it is quite possible that this figure could be higher. I am pleased to say that many states and territories have already recognised the seriousness of this problem and are putting in place strategies to combat it. For example, the ACT education department will move this year to implement an across-the-board policy on school bullying and similar moves are under way in other states.

In Queensland, the government has instigated a school based program called `Enough's enough'. It is based on the findings of a study which found boys verbally attacked girls on the basis of their sex and boys also suffered similar attacks from other boys if they were seen as too feminine. Indeed, the member for Capricornia has raised an issue that has come to light in the last week.

We all know how cruel children can be. Unfortunately, what is now called abuse will possibly always be a part of growing up. But what starts out as children acting as children always have, and possibly always will, can become very serious and a cause of great concern for both the children themselves and their parents.

I recently received a letter from a constituent which really brought home to me what we are talking about in this chamber today. I would like to read a section of this letter because I believe that it provides us with an opportunity to focus on the real life consequences of bullying. The names, of course, have been changed. The letter reads:

SPEECH.PARA: I am writing on behalf of my daughter Jane . . . My daughter was descending the stairs during her practical cooking class to do an assignment outside. She was accompanied by Lucy also in that class. The other girls had gone ahead a bit earlier. Lucy was on Jane's right and just after starting down the stairs Lucy put her leg out and tripped Jane. Jane fell between 4-8 stairs before stopping. Lucy stopped for a few seconds, saw a graze on Jane's right wrist then sniggered and continued on down the stairs and out to the other girls. As Jane fell she twisted around catching and ripping a hole in her top from a piece of wire sticking out from the banister. She hit her head, right shoulder, right elbow, left knee and landed on the back of her right hand, not the palm . . . We went to the hospital for a bone scan. There is `uptake' to the right hand and wrist and we were informed that she needed extensive physiotherapy and must see an Orthopaedic Surgeon for follow up treatment and another bone scan. While waiting at the bus stop to go to the hospital Jane was harassed by other students at the college who called her a `snob' sarcastically mocking her injury and how it occurred. We took Jane to the College to take back the homework she had managed to do, when one of the girls at the College advised Jane not to walk down any dark alleys as, in her words, she might get `egged'. We are a low income family and we cannot meet the expenses for the physiotherapist or Orthopaedic Surgeon. I realise that this appears to be a silly scrabble between teenagers but my daughter has been injured.

It may come as a surprise to many in this chamber that this incident occurred between 17-year-old girls, people on the verge of being treated as adults. Action following the Sticks and stones report should aim to give hope to the Janes across Australia, and to not allow such incidents to occur.

PARA.TAB: I believe the main report makes a valuable contribution to a debate that involves schools, parents, teachers and state education departments throughout the country. The coalition enthusiastically embraces the view of the committee that Australia's schools must provide a safe environment where teachers and students alike can learn, work, play and interact free from fear and abuse. The coalition also supports the committee's finding that it is the right combination of action at the school level that can have the most effective impact on addressing violence in our schools.

What the committee's findings show is that strong leadership provided by the principal combined with the teachers working together on the basis of a whole school approach in addressing school violence have proven to be the most effective way of achieving changes in student behaviour. Critical in ensuring such positive changes in student behaviour is maximum involvement by parents and students. Such programs are already successfully operating across Australia, and I commend the report for acknowledging the role they play.

While this report has my support, some comment needs to be made about certain aspects of the government's response, which again shows the extent to which this government has become glass jawed. Lately it seems that when faced with the slightest bit of criticism about its performance the government reels back and resorts to half truths and distortion of the facts. The government and the minister have clearly been stung by the report's findings and this is clearly evidenced by the contents of the response which is before the chamber today.

The first 12 pages of the response are the standard reply that the coalition and the community have come to expect: nothing new, just your typical Labor rhetoric which will result in little or no action. The only proviso I place on that statement is that with an election due the government may act—or, more likely, appear to act—for the most cynical of purposes and that is its re-election.

The remaining 21 pages of the document are committed to the government indulging itself in self-glorification. No matter how long the bow is drawn it has fallen over itself to explain ways in which it has allegedly supported or addressed issues raised by the Sticks and stones report. And no stone is left unturned. All this, however, is a rather pathetic attempt to deflect some of the criticisms and conclusions which the committee has drawn. Labor falsely prides itself on being able to lead the country. Leadership is about being able to take on board criticism and learn from it; it is not about indulging in an orgy of self-glorification every time someone suggests ways in which issues could be better handled.

The committee reached a very understandable conclusion, and that is that school violence is the end result of a number of factors. The committee has identified family breakdown, illiteracy, violent movies and television as just three of many factors which contribute to violence in schools. I read with interest in the government's response that it claims:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . more details about the funding arrangements for improving government services to families are given in section 4.

But nowhere in section 4 do we find details of Labor's true commitment—or, more truthfully put, its lack of commitment—to families. The promised tax cuts, which were to be l-a-w, turned out to be a l-i-e. Or what about the taxation and family payments system, which is biased against families, giving too little recognition to the expense of bringing up children?

PARA.TAB: Perhaps the government could have mentioned that over 800,000 dependants are in families where no parent has a job, or the widening gap between rich and poor with 78 per cent of those in poverty being family members and 64 per cent of these being in families with children. Again, the government failed to mention the derailed child-care system which in September 1993 saw 214,000 women claiming that the absence of child-care options was the main reason they were not actively looking for work, with 26 per cent of women identifying lack of child-care options as their major career barrier.

Mr Deputy Speaker, it might seem to be drawing a long bow to discuss these matters, but when you look at the government's response you will see the long bow that the government has drawn to justify its lack of action. Perhaps the government could have finally mentioned how it has relied on interest rates to squeeze families financially, by constantly lifting home mortgage rates and, even as we speak, keeping families in doubt as to whether they will be undergoing further interest rate rises or even tax rises.

None of this, unfortunately, is mentioned. Neither is the fact that a recent, independent report showed that some 30,000 secondary school students become homeless over a year. Instead, the government has devoted 21 pages to:

SPEECH.PARA: The following national policy initiatives and programs, in which the Commonwealth plays a major role . . . provide structures and support for schools and systems. . .
That is, families. Let me turn to the issue of literacy. The committee concluded, and I quote, that:
The Committee supports the views of principals and teachers that there is a link between student behaviour and poor literacy.
The committee goes further, to recommend that a concerted literacy program would lead to reduced levels of anti-social behaviour in schools.

PARA.TAB: The true extent of literacy in this country was revealed by the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Mr Free) in an interview on SBS World News on 18 January this year. The minister was asked what the current state of our literacy was. He replied, `We're not sure.' The minister says `not sure', despite the schools council report of December 1994 showing that up to 25 per cent of Australian school children are battling literacy problems, despite the International Literacy Year in 1990, the International Literacy Day on 8 September 1990, The literacy challenge: strategies for early intervention for literacy and learning for Australian children of December 1992, early literacy programs, adult literacy programs, the 1991 Australian language and literacy policy, the `Book it' program of 1990 and the literacy awards in 1992. After all this, the minister says, `We're not too sure about the state of our literacy.'
It would appear that the government is somewhat confused by the relationship that the committee says exists between literacy and school violence. Remember the committee explicitly stated that:

SPEECH.PARA: The committee supports the views of principals and teachers that there is a link between student behaviour and poor literacy.
However, to quote from the response:
The Government believes that the causes of violence in schools are many and varied, and notes that any causal link between literacy and violence is not established.

Not only does the government not agree with the views of principals and teachers, but, it would appear, the government disagrees with the committee and, therefore, does not agree with its own members.

PARA.TAB: The fallacy of the government's position on this issue is no more clearly shown than on page 34 of the response, where it proudly asserts that the students at risk—Star—program funds a range of school based projects which may assist in addressing violence in schools. Guess what one of the programs is which Star suggests will address violence in high schools? You guessed it, Mr Deputy Speaker: it is basic literacy. The government has fallen in a heap on the issue of literacy. When trying to justify its failings, it does little more than expose its total confusion and ineptness on this issue.

There are many examples of the government's attempting to deflect conclusions made by the committee. So insecure is the government on this issue that it has deliberately tried to avoid the committee's findings. The report identifies increasing retention rates and changes in student population as factors that encourage violence in schools. I stress that the committee did not state that these factors cause school violence, but merely stated that they encourage violence in schools. However, so stung is the government by this claim that the government response states:

SPEECH.PARA: The assertion is made in the context of assumptions about causes—
I repeat `causes'—
which have not been supported by credible research.

That comment demeans the extensive and far-reaching results of the committee inquiry, pays no regard to the committee's very exhaustive investigation into violence in schools, and is a totally unwarranted attack on the members of that committee.

PARA.TAB: Let me say that the standard, conclusions and recommendations of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training are in stark contrast to this pitiful reply made by the government. Where the committee has sought answers, the government has sought excuses. Where the committee has sought to place responsibility, the government has run a mile from it. Where the committee has sought team work, cooperation and facts, the government has sought to demean the committee's work and to demean the outcome of the committee's exhaustive inquiries. When taking note of the paper, let the House take note of the quality of the report—a quality that stands in stark contrast to the qualities of the government's response. I think, Mr Deputy Speaker, that the government's response should be called `12 pages of platitudes and 21 pages of excuses'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I should remind the member for Ballarat (Mr Ronaldson) that there are only two governments in this country that have shown a commitment to education: one is Queensland, and the other is the Commonwealth. Every other state government in this country that is largely responsible for children of this age group has denied funding and reduced funding. In fact, Mr Kennett in Victoria has reduced funding for education by some half a billion dollars. The member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) will know that his Premier has reduced funding to education in South Australia by $40 million, with more to come. The member for Franklin (Mr Quick), the colleague behind me, knows that the Liberal government in Tasmania has reduced funding. Western Australia has reduced funding. Let us not get facts in the way of a good story!

PARA.TAB: In taking note of the government's response to the report by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training called Sticks and stones: report on violence in Australian schools, I would like to comment on four of the seven major matters raised. They are positive parenting, best practice in schools, data collection in schools and early intervention. Parents are key partners in education. Their role as primary educators of their children and their continuing support during the years of schooling are critical elements in ensuring successful outcomes from their children's education. Along with those statements, the Commonwealth government recognises the pivotal role that parents need to play in strategies to tackle violence in schools.

No-one in this chamber would disagree with the sentiments of the government's response, but what exactly is positive parenting? What are the fundamental and essential attributes? I spent 25 years of my working life as a teacher and a principal of primary-aged children and obviously I came across children predisposed to verbal and physical violence and antisocial behaviour. In dealing with those children and their parents, I learned by experience and analysis of what happened that certain characteristics were always common. The child always had a parent or parents whose own behaviour and relationship with the child were dominated by inconsistency. Let me try and explain with a few real life examples.

I remember a child whose parents were obviously part of the alternative society. In that family there were very few, if any, rules other than that, if a problem arose, a situational negotiation took place to attempt to solve it. The parents' dress and behaviour was often remarked on in the community as outlandish, and I am sure that the parents in question enjoyed their shock on the local community with quiet humour. However, the point I want to make is that the child was very well adjusted indeed, and in fact was a real asset to the school community. From the child's point of view—and that is often overlooked—his parents, in their behaviour and relationship with him, were totally consistent, fair, predictable, and providing the child with the necessary security and certainty in dealing with everyday situations, without the need to resort to verbal or physical violence.

I also experienced examples at the other end of the spectrum from that laissez-faire example. Another child I remember had parents who had a rule for everything and a punishment that, without exception, was always carried out if a rule was transgressed. It was a very strict household but, as with the laissez-faire family, I would not try to emulate it myself. Nevertheless, the child from that strict family was extremely well adjusted. Again, from the child's point of view, his parents were fair, consistent and totally predictable—even if I thought they were too strict.

In other words, whether parents were strict or laissez-faire or somewhere in between did not seem to matter, as long as the relationship was consistent between the parents and the child. It also did not seem to matter—and this goes against a lot of the research—whether the child was a girl or a boy. Gender issues did not matter. Socioeconomic status did not seem to matter. Religious, cultural or racial status did not matter.

By contrast, and without exception, all children I have dealt with who were predisposed to violence had a parent or parents unable or unwilling to develop a relationship with their offspring that could be described as consistent. The result was children whose sense of self-worth was confused, diminished, or even inflated; whose relationships with other children and adults were marked with conflict; and whose skills in dealing with often everyday trivial circumstances were minimal. The point I make about positive parenting, and I much prefer to call it `consistent' parenting, is that the views of children themselves must be valued and acknowledged.

Although I welcome the government's response on initiatives to ask parent groups to provide advice about the role schools should play in promoting positive parenting, and I acknowledge the positive parenting approach underpinning the national prevention strategy for child abuse and neglect—as well as a major community education campaign and an independent assessment of all major parenting programs currently delivered in Australia—that information will never be complete or effectual, and will provide a poor framework for policy if the views of children themselves are ignored. All the partners in the relationships between children and adults need to be considered, and to leave children out of the equation is totally unacceptable and downright foolhardy.

There are many schools in this country which, in different ways, exemplify outstanding behaviour and school management—and then there are others in both the private and the public system. I find it very hard to accept that, after well over 100 years of compulsory education in Australia, some things have simply not changed in many primary schools. The most remarkable aspect is the basic structure used in these schools: that is, one teacher is largely responsible for the school education of a class of around 30 children for 10 months of the year. That structure is repeated year in, year out, for seven years. It is too bad if there is a relationship breakdown or indifference between pupil and student; too bad if the teacher has neither the interest nor the skill in the four major curriculum areas of language—including a foreign language—mathematics, environmental studies and the expressive arts and physical education. In 25 years I have never seen a teacher expert in all of those areas; the expectation that any teacher could be is totally unrealistic.

Thirty years ago, some primary teachers could get away with basic English, simple arithmetic, a bit of history and geography, music lessons from a radio broadcast, a pastel lesson once a week and a game in the park. But that curriculum structure is long gone; it has outlived its usefulness. Today, primary teachers are expected to teach all aspects of language, including a foreign language. They are expected to teach all aspects of mathematics: sets, logic, graphing, basic algebra, geometry and numeration. They are expected to be up to date with computer and information technology. They are expected to teach health and science. They are expected to teach environmental studies. They are expected to be aware of behaviour management, gender issues, sociology, psychology, collaborative learning and to be sensitive to cultural and racial matters. The list goes on and on.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sex education.

—Civics is now being introduced. The member for Wakefield mentions sex education, and there are many other subjects. Teachers are expected to teach art and craft and design; music, including the learning of a musical instrument; dance; gymnastics; and major and minor sports, including personal fitness. The message is clear—it is impossible.

PARA.TAB: Children need to be skilfully exposed to all of that curriculum. No-one would disagree with that contention. The problem is that no one teacher has the interest or the skills to do what is expected. The expectation from the community and government that teachers should do this is patently ridiculous. It is too bad if you are a child with a teacher whose interests and skills differ—you are stuck. Bored and uninterested students are potentially violent and anti-social students. Students unable to succeed in their chosen areas are potentially violent and anti-social students. Students unable to develop a positive relationship with a teacher, because of different interests or personality, are potentially violent and anti-social students.

The chief determinant of a successful school will always be a quality education program, enhanced by the principal's leadership, in which a group of teachers—not individuals—with complementary skills and interests are responsible for children: that is, the children in any school year will be exposed to several teachers and not just one. However, with the teacher resources available in most primary schools, that is not possible. In many cases it cannot even be considered. But in the few schools that do expose children to a range of teachers, what do we find? We find that behaviour management is a very minor issue. It does not matter whether they are middle class or working class or top-of-the-range schools. Interested, motivated, happy, enthusiastic students do not become behaviour problems, irrespective of their home circumstances.

I am, therefore, very pleased that the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Mr Free) has indicated a willingness to investigate the possibility of establishing, in cooperation with state and territory governments—we might remember that these are the people who are largely responsible for the education of these children—and non-government school authorities a best practice award for schools that display leadership. They are out there, but they are seldom acknowledged other than in their local community, and even then sometimes not acknowledged for the right reasons.

The third area I would like to address is the matter of data collection in schools. It is extremely important that the Commonwealth support the standing committee proposal for a consistent approach to the collection of accurate data, not only on violence but on a whole range of matters that affect our younger generation. We cannot afford to ignore any more the generation of the future now aged under 12 years. I am very pleased that the minister and the government concur on this matter.

The current data on primary schools in this nation is appalling and it is a very sad indictment of state governments, bureaucracies and the education community in general.
