All areas—universities, TAFEs, secondary schools—have appalling leadership when it comes to education, across the whole area. Young children in this nation are served poorly by this nation. What national organisation has successfully looked after the interests of the children under 12? No-one in this chamber could name one, because the answer is `None.' Yet here we are, in an age of national lobby groups for everything—almost one for ink lovers; you name it, there is a national lobby group. There is basically no effective, successful national lobby group for children between the ages of five and 12.

Why are the resources allocated to this age group so much lower than for any other age group in Australia? Why are they so powerless? Why are per capita grants for a 12-year-old in a primary school up to $1,000 lower than for a 12-year-old child in a secondary school? Does something magic occur to children in the Christmas vacation before entry to secondary school? Does paper cost more, do books cost more, do photocopiers cost more? Nonsense. Why are there, for exactly the same number of students, up to half as many teaching staff in a primary school as in a secondary school or TAFE institution? One would think there must be an educational reason for those huge differentials. There is not.

The current allocation of educational resources in this nation reflects historical tradition and power. There is very little or no educational merit or rationale whatsoever. It is about power, and these children and their teachers do not have any. That is why they do not have adequate funds. That is what seems to be the continued fate of primary schools in the bringing up of our children.

The younger the learner, the more dependent, the more vulnerable, the more precious, and the greater the chance for something to go wrong. The older the learner, the more independent, the more self-reliant, the easier to teach, and the less the chance for something to go wrong. That is not rhetoric. That is facts. Why is not it acted upon? Even if acknowledged, it is acknowledged in a very disingenuous way.

Collection of data on children is a sensitive matter and is recognised as such by teacher and parent groups. But this is little excuse for the political naivety of teachers and parents in resisting some forms of data collection and being manipulated, albeit in a subtle way, by bureaucracies to, in reality, sit on their hands and conduct talkfest after talkfest.

The 10 or 20 per cent of children who have literacy problems in our schools and their lack of success in school are potentially the angry and violent students of tomorrow. Poor parenting increases the risk dramatically. Poor schooling also increases the risk dramatically. Add a failure by the community and governments to adequately allocate a fair share of resources to children aged five to 12, and this nation has a recipe for a monumental and very expensive problem which is now evident to anyone who cares to observe what happens in schools and the community.

Early intervention works. Many members here this morning have mentioned that. It is cheaper than remedial measures. Remedial measures often do not work, and the increasing need for remedial measures in schools is ample evidence of system failure. Early intervention makes good sense, and prevention is cheaper and more effective than cure. (Extension of time granted)

I welcome the standing committee's report, and I commend the minister for the government's response in moving the debate onwards; but no-one ought to be deluded. This nation needs to acknowledge the needs of young children, and eventually will be forced to do so for a very simple and fundamental reason: that it is in the best interests of this nation, in a very non-forgiving and highly competitive world that will be ever more so in the future.

In this opportunity to take note of the report this morning, members of both the opposition and the government have shown that there is a great deal of interest in this; but there has to be a lot more than talk. It is time that a group of people in Australia who have the most minimal resources spent upon them by state and federal governments is recognised, because it is in all of our interests that children get off to a very good start, both socially and academically and in all other ways. That happens in our primary schools and in the relationships between parents and children. They need assistance, and it is time both Commonwealth and state governments, with all the members of this parliament, recognised that. I thank you for the extension of time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, in rising to participate in this motion that we take note of the report Sticks and stones, done by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, I first congratulate the member for Port Adelaide (Mr Sawford) on the contribution he has made to the debate. I hope he does not regard this remark as in any sense belittling his speech: I think it is a speech that could have been made by members on either side of this committee chamber.
—And should be.

—And should be, I clearly agree. I simply did not want him to feel that for some strange reason, because we were not being antagonistic, we in some way belittled the contribution he had made. I would also say that it reflected the professionalism that he brings into this chamber in view of his 25 years of experience in the teaching profession. I was very appreciative of the illustrations he brought from the experiences he had had as an educator.

PARA.TAB: I am not one who has had any professional involvement in education at all. But I have, in common with other people in the chamber, an interest in what education is all about; because I am, in common with most others, a parent. As a parent all too frequently absent from the role that ought to be exercised in the education of children—and that is a frustration we all face as members of the federal parliament—I nonetheless have endeavoured to be familiar with what was happening to my children in schools. I have been advantaged by the fact that my wife was herself, prior to the children arriving, a secondary school teacher, and that she is therefore anxious to ensure that their education is of the highest order. She has always kept me briefed on what she thought were the various strengths and weaknesses of their education and of the schools they were attending.

In thumbing through the report Sticks and stones—and I am not on the standing committee, so I was not directly involved in its preparation—what impressed me most was that violence is not a regular feature of Australian school life. That was an observation I expected to be able to make, because my children have not been any more exposed to bullying and violent behaviour than I was 40 years ago, as illustrated by the comments by member for Port Adelaide. In fact, as other members would be aware, the reports of antisocial and violent behaviour in New South Wales schools affected, it was alleged, only 0.04 per cent of students. In the case of ACT schools, in 1991 the number of suspensions was 447 out of 40,000 students, representing 0.01 per cent.

My observations are that my children are no more exposed to verbal harassment and physical harassment than I was—and, in fact, probably less so. I think that children have a right, as everyone else would agree, to attend a school feeling safe and secure, being reassured that they will not be belittled, and to feel that, in the school environment, they will have a real opportunity for their own self-esteem to be enhanced. If there is one thing that has been brought home to me as a parent, it is that the self-esteem of individual children is of fundamental importance.

The honourable member for Port Adelaide reinforced this not only with the illustrations he used from his own experience but also with the comments he made as a professional. If people feel they have self-worth and feel they have a contribution to make to society, it is highly unlikely that they will be involved in violent behaviour. I have only one problem with the honourable member for Port Adelaide's comments. He said that interested, motivated, enthusiastic students do not become problems regardless of their home background. I expect he is right; however, very few interested, motivated, enthusiastic students come out of a difficult home background.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not true.

—Rather than debate this across the chamber, we can pick it up later. I am merely making the observation that it is much easier to be an interested, motivated and enthusiastic student if the parents have already cultivated that sense of enthusiasm at home. I well remember what for me was the most terrorising book I have read. I read it very early in my primary school days, which was probably a mistake. I was amused by one of my colleagues who observed the other day that the best three years of his life had been spent in year one—that was a mischievous remark. I remember that it was not long after I acquired the capacity to read that someone gave me the book Tom Brown's Schooldays. I read it and I was mortified. I feared that I would experience either in the latter part of primary school or in secondary school the sort of bullying that was characterised in the book Tom Brown's Schooldays. I was obviously much too immature to have read the book at the time; it set an artificial scene for me of what secondary school life would be like.

PARA.TAB: For most of us, some sort of verbal harassment and, I suspect, for most of our generation, some physical harassment was a reality of the schools in which we grew up. That did not make it defensible, but it was a reality, and I suspect that exhibits itself less frequently today than it did in my own day.

From my experience as a parent, bullying and harassment is less of a feature of all-girls schools than it is of all-boys schools. My children spent their primary school years in public schools. They spent their secondary schooling in private schools, with the exception of one child, who had two years of his secondary schooling in a public school. From my daughter's experience in an all-girls school in Adelaide, it was the best thing we did for her. Her sense of self-esteem was enhanced and there was relatively little physical bullying. Of course, there was some verbal bullying that characterises what we would loosely call—and I use the term advisedly—the `bitchiness' of an all-girls school environment.

On the other hand, my oldest son for the latter part of his secondary schooling went to an all-boys school where bullying was more a part of the scene—and we all know what goes on at all-boys schools. As a result of his experience, we have sent our younger son to a school catering for both sexes. Lest it be thought that I am being critical of the schooling experience of my older son, I should say that, in confronting the headmaster with our decision not to send our younger son there, I was impressed with what had been done in the intervening years by that school community to address the problem of both bullying and verbal abuse. I frame my remarks this morning around the fact that I believe that, without exception, switched-on schools are doing something about bullying and verbal abuse.

I pick up the remarks made by the member for Port Adelaide. I entirely agree with him that it does not matter whether it is a private school or a public school; what is happening in violence in schools is very much a reflection on the principal and the staff of a school. My own view of the public school system has been that my children were being well served there by teachers who deserved to be paid twice the salary they were being paid, because of the effort they put into effectively parenting at school, and were served there by other teachers who were not worth feeding and who could not be disciplined in an effective way.

I have no doubt the member for Port Adelaide faced some of this frustration as a principal when he had staff members for whom he wanted to offer a greater remuneration and was unable to do so, and staff members whom he would gladly have shown the front gate but was unable to do so. And that has been one of the difficulties that I felt has characterised the public school system more markedly—not exclusively but more markedly—than the private school system. What is important for all of us is to ensure that our children, both at home and at school, have a real sense of self-worth and self-importance. Any form of bullying, whether it is physical or verbal, breaks that down and does untold damage that takes a long time to address.

I want to pick up the recommendations that were made to the minister and his response. I am not quite as enthusiastic as the member for Port Adelaide about data collection, though I clearly recognise his professionalism in this area. My attitude comes rather as an observing parent. The first recommendation was that the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, in consultation with state and territory ministers for education, fund the evaluation of successful approaches adopted by schools to determine the best practice, and that the result of that evaluation be published and disseminated. This recommendation was encouraging the ministers to hold a series of forums and to thoroughly consider the practices that were working effectively in schools.

That recommendation ran parallel to the second recommendation, which was that the Minister for Employment, Education and Training finance the development of a national school violence data collection system referred to by the member for Port Adelaide. My own view was that, frankly, it is not this sort of data that we need as much as we need concerned parents anxious to ensure that at home there is a positive home environment to reinforce the positive environment that we would seek to cultivate in schools. It may well be that data collection is necessary, but I fear that data collection of itself achieves very little and I would not want the resources funnelled into data collection to be at the expense of resources that we could make available to encourage young parents to be more effective and more positive parents and to take the assets they have in children and build them up and give them a greater sense of self-esteem.

The third recommendation was that the Minister for Employment, Education and Training discuss with state and territory ministers the need for early intervention strategies to address violent and anti-social behaviour in students. We would all agree with that. I think it is important that students' capacity to live with others, to cooperate with others and to recognise the worth of others is inculcated at an early age, because the later it gets the harder it is to develop the sort of human behaviour techniques that we would want to encourage.

The next recommendation was that the Minister for Communications and the Arts examine the effects of television, video, film and video games on the learning outcomes and behaviour of Australian children. This is a recommendation that has largely been endorsed by people on both sides of this chamber, and the plea has been for greater recognition of the damage that violent television viewing can do to young minds. It is the reason we have some sort of categorisation system and it is the reason all of us, as concerned parents, are very anxious to ensure that our children do not see the sort of movies that we would not want them to see. The problem we face, once again, is where there has been family breakdown and there is not the same level of intervention in children's viewing.

I pick up the interesting remark made by the member for Port Adelaide about a family experience he had had where the parents were rather laissez-faire in their approach to upbringing and the children were nonetheless well adjusted because the children knew the parents cared. The secret, of course, is in reassuring parents and children, where they are in a disciplined house, or what we would call a relatively non-disciplined house, that mum and dad are worried about their outcome. In that sort of environment, what they view is conditioned by mum and dad's attitude anyway. It is to those who grow up in families where mum and dad clearly appear not to care that the damage is truly done.

Recently, I reluctantly went to see the film Once Were Warriors. My post-teenage children recommended that father should see it. I was sure they were anxious to cultivate what little was left of my left-wing tendencies. I was wrong. It was an excellent movie. I recommend it to everyone. It was a very graphic illustration, not of domestic violence in an horrific sense, but of the way in which a particular circumstance makes domestic violence almost inevitable. I left the movie chastened by what I had seen. I recommend Once Were Warriors because it illustrates how the breakdown of family life has an impact on every individual member of the family.

Finally, I turn to the recommendation that the Minister for Employment, Education and Training review the attendance and performance eligibility criteria for Austudy for students in years 11 and 12. I represent an electorate in which Austudy is a major problem. The major problem is not that the criteria are unfair. In fact, having spent a lot of time following up Austudy cases, I am not a critic of the way in which the government administers it. The problem that I face—and it is a problem the government is familiar with—is in terms of people who remain asset rich and, particularly in recent times, cash poor.

I do not have a simple solution to make Austudy available to those in rural areas who have assets that they cannot readily dispose of because they need them in order to run an effective business when, in this case, the drought is over. However, no doubt there are many cases where the capacity to educate children is directly affected by the unavailability of Austudy. I encourage the government to look at the way in which Austudy is administered, particularly in rural areas. A number of people are denied it because of their assets, but they are unable to offer their children in years 11 and 12 and in tertiary education the sort of education those children need. This builds up frustration, which can lead to violent behaviour.
Mr Sawford interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the member for Port Adelaide for that. As I said in my earlier remarks, I did not doubt that the government was aware of the problem, but it is a critical one. I once again make the plea that all children be given a greater sense of self-esteem, for that is the secret to a fulfilled life. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Quick Mr H.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also compliment the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Sawford) on his excellent speech on school violence. This subject is something near and dear to me as, like the member for Port Adelaide, prior to coming into parliament a couple of years ago, I had been in the teaching profession for most of my working life. I welcome the opportunity to speak on the motion to take note of the government's response to the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training on violence in schools, which is commonly known as Sticks and stones.

PARA.TAB: As a member of the committee and as a former school teacher, I appreciated the opportunity during the inquiry to broaden my understanding of what to me has always been a most pressing problem, not just for education but because it impacts on so many other aspects of society. While travelling around Australia, hearing from state departments, principals, teachers, parents, and students, one soon gained a feel for what is happening throughout the country. One of the aspects that I enjoy about being a politician is getting the big picture in that way.
It was pleasing to note, as it said in the introduction to its response, that the government welcomes the report. It says that the report is:

SPEECH.PARA: A timely and important contribution to the current debate in Australia about the nature, impact and incidence of violence in our schools.

As previous speakers have noted, the issue of violence in schools is a very complex one, and there are no simplistic answers. Unfortunately, many people in our society—including many politicians—seem to think that the whole issue can be dealt with by schools and within schools.

PARA.TAB: One of the common problems is that many politicians do not focus, as the honourable member for Port Adelaide said, on the primary school years. We are taken to universities, technical colleges and institutes of further education and we are overwhelmed by the technological impact of what we see. Thus, we think that we should fund those areas. However, when we go into a grade 1 class and see a young teacher with 30 young children in front of her imparting knowledge, values, ideals and basic learning techniques, we cannot see any benefit. It is all theoretical. It is only 10 years later that the impact of what has or has not been done in those very formative years becomes obvious.

The manifestation of violence or anti-social behaviour within the precincts of schools very often has nothing to do with what is happening in the educative process of the child. But because it does happen in schools, teachers, students, social workers and parents are forced to intervene in order to impose some order. Very often due to inadequate resources they are never able to properly address the real reason behind the violent outburst.

I would like to provide honourable members with some first-hand true anecdotes of such anti-social behaviour to highlight and complement the recommendations from the report and the government's response to them. The first example is of young Brian. I well remember him coming to school. Not long after we had started work early in the morning in the grade 4 class he violently and without provocation assaulted one of his classmates. I had been teaching for quite a few years at that stage and sensed that something was not quite right. Because he trusted me, after some reluctance and embarrassment on his part and having been withdrawn from the rest of the class, he tearfully explained to me the reason behind his outburst. By the way, it was a very hot day and it was rather unusual that he was wearing a polo-neck jumper.

He finally peeled back the jumper to show me the cuts on his neck where his mother's boyfriend had used a knife to assert his authority over the young child. Brian's mum had just had a new baby by the boyfriend and Brian really was not wanted as part of the new family. He came to school angry and frustrated and hit out at the first person that he came in contact with.

Because we had adequate counselling facilities at that school, the social worker from the department of welfare was quickly able to become involved and the local police responded rapidly and effectively, I am pleased to say that Brian today is a very well adjusted young man who recently finished his apprenticeship and is now living in a loving relationship with his family. That was possible only because we had the resources there and because the teachers fostered a caring atmosphere in the school.

As the inquiry noted, the community at large is becoming increasingly concerned about violence in schools. This concern is placing increased pressure on state governments, which is resulting in the issue gaining a high priority. As previous speakers have mentioned, programs are now being introduced by the states and territories to alleviate this problem.

It was interesting to note that when the inquiry was in full swing only the states of South Australia and Queensland and the territory of the ACT bothered to make submissions. It was rather disappointing that in the case of my state, Tasmania, rather than get involved in the inquiry, the government handed the task over to a Tasmanian education council to do its own special report. Its report consequently dwelt on the problem from an educational perspective in total isolation. The announcement on the solving of the problem was to provide an additional teacher to every secondary school and college to handle disruptive students. To me, that is far too late.

Surely, as a society, we have two issues to address: firstly, to put in place programs to solve the current problems; and, secondly, to ensure that we have in place strategies which will reduce the number of children leaving primary schools who are still at risk. Just to address the first issue is self-defeating. The numbers keep on rising and the problems will surely escalate to what is happening overseas, especially in the United States of America. I have had the privilege—doubtful though it might be—of actually working in schools there, and I know exactly what the problems are that they face: they are horrendous.

In all states, as the member for Port Adelaide mentioned, education departments have initiated large cutbacks, especially in the area of support staff. I think it is vital that all primary schools have a full quota of specialist teachers. In most schools in Tasmania—in primary schools—there are in excess of $70,000 or $80,000 of library books and no librarians. There are no music, phys. ed. or special ed. teachers, and those kids are at risk.

As we found out in the violence in schools report, close to 15 per cent of primary school children who leave and go to high schools are now at risk. We need to solve the problem before they leave. From my 20-odd years in primary school teaching, one of the ways is through providing strategies and teachers to enable a child to reach his or her full potential in those specialist areas as well as providing the excellent teaching that takes place in the classrooms. We will not then be putting those children at risk.

On that point, one of the principal recommendations and one which I think the government supports wholeheartedly is the need for this identification of best practice in schools. As the previous members have mentioned, too many schools in Australia have been working in isolation and merely solving the problems associated with their own neighbourhood. Their best practice school behaviour, peer support and development of a school-wide ethos of non-violence must be extended throughout the nation. Part 1.12 in the report states:

SPEECH.PARA: A whole school approach to student behaviour necessarily involves a number of elements:
.the provision of a caring environment;
.the establishment of firm behaviour limits where students' rights and responsibilities are clearly stated;
.the implementation of fair and consistent sanctions when rules are transgressed;
.monitoring of children's behaviour both in the classroom and playground;
.the adoption of a method of `mediating' poor student behaviour;
.the training of staff in `mediation'; and
.the encouragement of parental involvement in their children's lives.

All these sound so simple and so self evident, but I can assure members that these criteria are missing in many schools throughout our nation. I can take members to a school close to my electorate office where the primary school principal refuses to allow parents to become involved in his school. There are schools where caning is still meted out to deter anti-social behaviour. These activities are knowingly condoned by the education departments.

PARA.TAB: In my electorate I am delighted to say that we have some visionary teachers who, despite all the setbacks, have some wonderful early intervention programs. I would like to take this opportunity to note them in public: Herdsmans Cove Primary School and the excellent work of Doreen Lutjens in running an early intervention program pre-school for in excess of 60 parents and about 90 children; Geilston Bay High School under Trevor Rootes; Rugby High School under Greg Cairnduff; Geeveston District High School and the excellent work in the Star program by Greg Suitor; Bridgewater High School and the tireless work in the intervention process by Graham Speight; and, Peter Marmion and his wonderful staff at Franklin Primary School.

I also welcome the federal government's support for a series of forums on schools held in each state and territory. I think it is essential that, rather than having the bureaucrats and the experts as the member for La Trobe (Mr Charles) mentioned, we identify these best practice schools, document what they are doing, have them talk together and then follow up the key findings of these forums and develop policies, programs and performance indicators based on their best practice activities. These best practice schools do have the answers. We need the bureaucrats from the education department and from the departments of community welfare, health, housing, sport and recreation, and community services, to be able to listen in and find out just how important their roles are in this process. It is not just an issue solely related to education. To highlight this need for an interdepartmental approach to this problem of violence in schools, I would like to place on record the wonderful work that is happening in the northern suburbs of Adelaide.

My last example of first-hand information is young Jimmy. I first came in contact with him in grade 3. He had serious problems—sadistic behaviour from an early age. He used to feed kittens to his german shepherd to get his kicks. He delighted in hurting young people and girls. We fought in vain to involve the necessary support personnel in Jimmy's case but there always seemed to be someone with a more pressing need. Jimmy stabbed his mother to death and was sentenced to life imprisonment at the age of 17.

Throughout the inquiry the committee constantly heard about the need for early intervention and support for families so that they could deal with the problem of violence in schools. I welcome the government's very supportive and constructive response to the recommendations concerning the piloting of positive parenting programs and the examination of the manner in which government services are delivered to students and families requiring support from more than one agency. The development by state and territory governments of a youth strategy coordinating committee is welcome news. However, one hopes and prays that there will be more benefits flowing from this committee than from the youth affairs departments which each state has—usually attached to the Premier's office—and which were supposedly set up to monitor such issues.

I have mentioned the role of the Commonwealth in the students at risk program as being one of the examples of the government's involvement in initiatives which support issues raised by the Sticks and stones report. My only criticism of the students at risk program is that it is far too late. I want to see the program widened and supported financially by the states so that it can be introduced to primary schools, where, by supporting school based programs, the number of young children leaving primary schools while they are still at risk can be reduced.

I want to point out the role of the media in this situation. Less sensationalist and more investigative journalism is needed to promote the best practice that is happening around our country. I cite two examples from the Mercury of Wednesday, 1 March in its reporting of the government's response. The headline says `Tackling teacher abuse'. One gets a totally incorrect idea from a quick glance at that headline. The Mercury has another headline saying `Call for more resources for problem students'. It can be seen that the whole issue of journalists getting involved needs to be looked at.
I welcome the bipartisan support in this very important issue, and I hope that people take note of the report and of the government's response.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neville Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I broadly welcome the government's response to the Sticks and stones report. In doing so, I must say how much I enjoyed the work of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training in this particular exercise. The committee which worked on this report was a very positive and friendly committee, and it was bipartisan in the way it approached each of the topics that it met during the course of the report.

PARA.TAB: Nevertheless, I have some reservations about the government's response, and I will deal with those reservations. From the outset, I must say that one of the early disappointments was the way in which the government glossed over the connection between violence and bullying. It is very important that this difference is noted. The committee was able to differentiate, as it moved around Australia, that bullying is becoming more prevalent and that overt violence, if anything, is becoming somewhat less prevalent.

It is interesting to note that, while acts of overt physical violence are rare events in most schools, bullying is prevalent. Australian research found that one child in seven reports being bullied at least once a week by other children at school. While the distribution of bullying amongst schools is uneven, in some schools it is as high as one in four. That information is contained in an extract from the report of the committee.

As I said, the incidence of overt violence seems to be on the decrease, at least within the schoolyard. The committee found evidence of overt violence outside the schoolyard, but it also found that bullying is a much more profound occurrence, and, in a way, it is much more insidious. This point was made to the committee by the New South Wales Teachers Federation, which pointed out that, in three-quarters of a million students, there are only 50 to 100 incidents of actual physical violence per semester. Although that would not appear to be a big problem, bullying is prevalent across the spectrum.
The National Committee on Violence, in its report Violence: Directions for Australia, said it agreed that:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . there are disciplinary problems within many schools and that there are offences of various kinds and degrees of seriousness committed in and around schools, but that they are not necessarily cause for alarm or for vigorous reaction.

So, at this point, we need to move on to where we feel the distinction lies. This is where the bulk of the work must be concentrated—at that fine point between violence and bullying. In our report, we defined bullying as:
. . . repeated and unprovoked negative behaviour (both physical and non-physical) directed by more powerful students or groups of students against less powerful students.

However, we went on to say that what seemed to affect the extent to which bullying occurred was the extent to which school staff were involved in the students' lives. Here we discovered quite a distinction as between schools and I believe this distinction revolved around how well the holistic school approach was applied to student behaviour.

PARA.TAB: This approach needs to include a number of major elements which we listed in our report:

SPEECH.PARA: . the provision of a caring environment;
. the establishment of firm behaviour limits where students' rights and responsibilities were clearly stated;
. the implementation of fair and consistent sanctions when rules are transgressed;
. monitoring of children's behaviour both in the classroom and playground;
. the adoption of a method of `mediating' poor student behaviour;
. training of staff in `mediation'; and
. the encouragement of parental involvement in their children's lives.

It is interesting that two of the best schools we found in that regard had invoked all or most of those particular key points. It is also interesting that my colleague opposite, the member for Bass (Mrs Silvia Smith), is here because we found that the Mayfield Primary School in Launceston was one of the best examples, among primary schools, of the adoption of that school regime.

PARA.TAB: Another interesting aspect of this, which was touched on by other speakers earlier in the debate, was the quality of leadership within the school. We found that in Mayfield—as we did at the next school I wish to refer to, which is the Patrician Brothers High School at Granville in the western suburbs of Sydney. This old school is not unlike the ones we used to see in the old English films—the two- or three-storey brick schools surrounded by asphalt courtyards with very little in the way of sporting facilities. The school is in what you would have to describe charitably as one of the more depressed parts of the western suburbs of Sydney, 76 per cent of the students come from ethnic backgrounds, and yet it was arguably the best school we came across in our study.

Again, the reason was that these key pointers we identified were largely invoked in that school. For example, one of the requirements of a teacher being on the staff was that he or she—be they religious or lay teachers—had to participate in the pastoral care of the students. There was a regime of respect—this idea of privilege and responsibility—and that was demonstrated very clearly in a rule that the school had invoked. That was that there was to be no touching of another student, other than at contact sport. In other words, everyone had to respect everyone else's space. There was also a great sense of family both within the school and with the involvement of the students' families from outside the school.

While I have never been a great believer in corporal punishment, I never go to the extent of saying that we should deny all schools in all circumstances the right to administer limited corporal punishment. Although corporal punishment was not administered in this school very often, when I questioned a group of 29 students I asked the worst boy how often he would be punished by the strap. He said, `Perhaps two or three times a year.' People would hardly say that that was a violent atmosphere in that school. Interestingly, it put an ultimate sanction into the system.

Sometimes, in this age of anti-corporal punishment, we have gone too far to the other end of the spectrum in allowing teachers or principals to exercise a right which may prevent worse behavioural problems. If the right to administer corporal punishment came from the degree of control, happiness and general wellbeing that was in a school, then this principal earned the right to administer it because he certainly had a school which, against all odds, was a great example.

Moving on to the government's response to the committee's recommendations, notably that the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, in conjunction with the state and territory ministers, find an evaluation of successful approaches which might lead to best practice, the government has said that it would set up a steering committee for the dissemination of results in this field and that it might consider an award system for schools that show leadership. I commend that particular recommendation.

The government also acknowledged our recommendation that the minister, in conjunction with his state and territory ministerial colleagues, develop a school violence data collection system—I am paraphrasing the recommendation. I do not have any hang-ups about this and about privacy. It is just raw data. The minister has delegated that to the statistics task force of the ministerial council, the MCEETYA. We also had the recommendation that the minister, with his state and federal colleagues, look at early intervention strategies to address violence and anti-social behaviour.

As we worked through the ministerial responses, I had a feeling, as a previous speaker mentioned, that while the government was sensitive to the committee's needs in theory, there was not much happening in practice. Again, it was referred to a ministerial council, and to the committee, saying that it was to reassess the level of Commonwealth recurrent funding to government primary schools. If the government set up this inquiry, gave this committee a reference and went broad-ranging across all of Australia, it could not hide its response in the great litany of programs, many of them most commendable, that are in the addendum to its response on the one hand, nor can it say that it is going to fix it up by a series of ministerial councils. It is going to have to have some hard edged contribution from the Commonwealth. That may mean some form of direct government funding or funding through ministerial councils for specific projects.

I am not satisfied with the government's response to effects of television, video film, video games, et cetera, on learning outcomes and behaviour. The fact that there is an overlap between the Department of Communications and the Arts and the Department of Employment, Education and Training is not a sound basis for stepping away from this problem. Did we not all last Sunday hear the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) say, with his new-found zeal for a fourth family television channel, that the current fare being dished up to families was largely—and I use his own words—`American bilge'.

I think that the Department of Employment, Education and Training must take an interest in these matters. We have had all sorts of inquiries into television, videos and video games. We sit on the edge of the information superhighway, and we turn around and duck the issue

SPEECH.PARA: on the most fundamental level of all entertainment: its effect on children and the spin-offs it has on the children's behaviour and educational outcomes. If we duck this particular issue, we are kidding ourselves. During our inquiry there was a lot of anecdotal evidence, at least, to point to a need for greater attention to that field.

PARA.TAB: In the time remaining to me, I would like to touch for a few moments on the link between violence and educational outcomes. The government has said in its report that it believes the causes of violence in schools are many and varied, and it notes that any causal links between literacy and violence are not well established. I do not think that that is a fair assessment. There may not have been many great causal links between smoking and lung cancer, initially, but there was a lot of anecdotal evidence that should have been acted on. I think this holds true here, because further on in the report, where the government quotes the Star program, it goes on to say that the improvement of basic literacy, numeracy and social skills necessary for students to function in society, raising their self-esteem and skills for coping with conflict and aggression, was an essential feature. But the government cannot say, on the one hand, that there is no causal effect, and then quote its own Star program saying that there is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mrs Silvia

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise today to speak to this House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training report on violence in schools called Sticks and stones, and also to speak to the government response to that report. As my colleague opposite, the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Neville), has said, I was also part of that inquiry. Along with my colleagues, I wish to offer my appreciation to all of those who participated in any way in this report. It was not only those members of this government and those opposite who participated in bringing down this Sticks and stones report: various groups, organisations, schools and children participated, and it is already proving to be a valuable document due to the information that was gathered and the recommendations that it proffered.

PARA.TAB: Our schools must be able to provide a safe learning environment for our children. That environment must be a caring environment, an environment that establishes firm behavioural limits, where students' rights are clearly demonstrated and their responsibilities are clearly stated. There must be sanctions when rules are transgressed, monitoring of children's behaviour in the classroom and in the playground, and a variety of other measures.

We must not automatically assume that schools are either safe or unsafe, and it is by proceeding with inquiries such as the Sticks and stones inquiry that we can assure our children and their parents that the school environment will be safe and conducive to the learning process. The media, in its reporting of often very singular and isolated incidents, has often blown this issue out of all proportion, and has perhaps contributed to the community perception that our education system is violent or chaotic. We need to consider that perhaps schools reflect the behaviour patterns of our society, the society in which they are located.

Throughout the deliberation of the committee, it was found that there are many schools where the principals have shown, and are showing, strong leadership—especially in those instances where there has been recognition that violent behaviour can be changed. These schools have developed a whole school approach to addressing school violence, alongside ensuring that their students are very much aware of their rights. Major importance has been placed on students taking responsibility for themselves and others, as well as on teachers taking their responsibility.
I take this opportunity to focus on two particular recommendations and the government response to those. The committee recommended that:

SPEECH.PARA: .the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, in consultation with State and Territory Ministers for Education, fund the evaluation of successful approaches adopted by schools to determine best practice; and
.the result of that evaluation be published and disseminated.

As we conducted our inquiry, it became quite evident that there were schools operating under a best practice system with a whole school approach—in particular, when dealing with violence in the school environment. I will take the time to quote part of the report itself. The honourable member for Hinkler, who spoke previously, mentioned the Mayfield School in my electorate of Bass. When we visited Mayfield, the committee did so with my encouragement, as the school had not proffered a submission; but I knew what was going on there from close contact with that school, and I was determined that the inquiry and the committee should see that there was a program in place where a whole school approach had been taken to look at this issue.

PARA.TAB: Mayfield Primary School drew its student population from family situations where 70 per cent of parents were unemployed. Mayfield is a very depressed suburb of Launceston in many ways—and, I might add, a suburb where I spent a couple of years of my own life. As recently as four years ago, the playground of that school was considered unsafe. The introduction of the supportive school environment approach eliminated these problems.

The program which operated in the school was not an isolated program but an integral part of every aspect of school life. There was recognition by the principal and teachers that violent behaviour could be changed, and their dedication to effecting that change largely contributed to the turnaround in behaviour which the school experienced. The program endeavoured to promote the wellbeing of all those who worked within the school community. Throughout the program, children in particular learnt skills in behaviour management and conflict resolution. Students learned mutual respect and cooperation. Students in year 6 provided guidance and support for younger pupils, and all students were responsible for observing and reporting incidents which were contrary to the philosophy of the school. By being successful, children gained confidence and felt positive about themselves and others.

The school had developed a clear set of rights, as well as of responsibilities. These were developed between the teachers, pupils and parents, and were considered to be owned by the whole school community. The school developed rules that related to learning, movement, treatment, problem solving, safety, and talking and communication. While there was concern about the lack of resources, the environment in the school was improved immeasurably—without the allocation of additional resources.

This school had clearly stated consequences for behaviour. These consequences were positive for positive behaviour, and negative for inappropriate behaviour. The rules were also applied consistently. In all academic streams, the children were taught appropriate behaviour as an integral part of the teaching process. As an ex-schoolteacher, I know that has been the philosophy in my life: we need guidelines for our young people so that they know what the parameters of behaviour are. They also need to know that they may have to pay some price if they overstep those parameters.

The government's response has been for the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Mr Free) to seek the cooperation of state and territory ministers and non-government systems to hold a series of forums to certify and identify the best in practice in whole school approaches to address violence in schools around Australia. This is a very appropriate action.

As the honourable member for Hinkler said, the government also hopes to establish a national mechanism for evaluating and disseminating the results of those discussions. This can only help and benefit those who look after our children in school hours. There is also to be an investigation into establishing a cooperative best practice award for schools. This would be something to display for leadership in this field.

The committee was also keen to note that principals, teachers and community groups identified violence via the media, film, video games and negative modelling. That was one that came in quite unawares to the committee. In particular, via the media, a lot of negative modelling from some of the negative behaviour of our sports heroes has influenced how children react. I am sure we are all aware of that. They see their peers and their role models doing something and they think it is okay for them to do it as well.

The committee also accepted that the media and entertainment industries were out of the control of the schools. It was hoped that parents could and would exercise control over the programs and video games that their children watch and play.

Therefore, the second recommendation that I would like to focus on deals with the media and entertainment side of violence that is seen in our schools. The committee recommends that the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Mr Lee) commission a national research project to examine the effects of television, video, film and video games on the learning outcomes and behaviour of Australian children.

In this part of the argument, we cannot ignore the influence of parents and the extended family on student behaviour. Therefore, it is essential for the government to respond to the needs of families. All children should receive the necessary support to provide a safer and non-violent school environment.
There was evidence of violence by the media throughout the committee's deliberations. It is stated vehemently in the Sticks and stones report. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: The influence exerted on children by the media and entertainment industry in general, was overwhelmingly identified in evidence as a contributor to the acceptance of, and the use of, violence by children.
Children do not distinguish between violence outside the school and violence inside the school environment. The report continues:

Evidence from the Australian Children's Television Action Committee stated that on average, by the time an Australian child was fourteen or sixteen years old he or she would have seen some eighteen thousand murders on television.
This is quite alarming. It goes on:
They referred to three thousand studies which identified a connection between the impact of media violence and the instigation of later violence.

Mr Deputy Speaker, you must agree that is damning evidence of the control that some media may have over our children's future lives. It is not only in that type of movie or video that children gather violent behaviours. The report goes on:
For example, teachers also referred to changed playground behaviours, such as kicking and punching by primary pupils, which coincided with the televising of Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles.
I have evidence of that in two nephews whose behaviour changed quite violently after having watched that particular program.

PARA.TAB: Further, television series such as Neighbours and Home and Away were identified as programs providing questionable role models for children developing social values and models for future behaviour. These programs were watched by children from six upwards. As G-classified programs they did not require parental supervision but, while not explicitly violent, they modelled belligerent attitudes and showed little respect for important values which children were learning.

To counter the effects of programs such as these, the council argued for two levels of G-rated programs, one for adolescents and one for six- to 12-year-old children. It is interesting to note that so many people and so many groups identify media as having some influence on the violence of children. That is not necessarily just in the school environment, although it does manifest there in particular, as we found in this inquiry.

In the government's response it was agreed that there was some concern that the media and entertainment industries have a clear responsibility to discourage the production of material which promotes violent and aggressive behaviour and attitudes. Processes to disseminate results of findings in this area to organisations such as school parent bodies will be a focus of the government's response.

The communications and arts portfolio is already acting to safeguard the wellbeing of children in relation to media content, as well as the broadcasting services through the Broadcasting Services Act 1992; and committee members, along with other interested members, groups and organisations, will keep a watchful eye on all research projects and processes in place now, to ensure that wherever possible children are not subjected to undue violence and harmful material via films, media, video games and even advertising material.

This report must be looked at by everyone. I am pleased to say that within my own electorate many schools have asked for copies of this report so they can look at our findings, look at our recommendations and develop whole school approaches and best principles for looking at violence within their schools. I support the motion that the House take note of the paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too welcome the opportunity to say a few words about the report on violence in schools. I speak as a member of the education, employment and training committee, even though coming in a little later, not initially being a member of that committee for that inquiry.

PARA.TAB: First I would like to say a few words about the history of our schooling system over the last 20 or 25 years, in my experience of it. You, Mr Deputy Speaker Hollis, are a former teacher and many former teachers bring their professional background and their understanding of educational issues into the parliament. I bring a somewhat different perspective, as someone who experienced the education system for only about 10 years of my life.

However, in my early adult experience of the education systems, as my children were growing up, I became aware that the education system had approximately a doubling of the resources in the early 1970s and a doubling of the staffing, as the government of the day saw that as a priority. I guess the promise in those times was that, if we could put more resources into education, we would reap a reward. Looking back over that 20- to 25-year period, however, at best we could say that the results were mixed. I offer one statistic—the youth unemployment statistic.

We might look back over the last few years and say that there are certain areas where the resources are limited and where resources have been reduced. But if we look at the span of history, especially over the last 20 or 30 years, we find that there has been a very significant taxpayer contribution to education. I have to say that some of the social issues around that expenditure bear greater scrutiny.

What happened in that time was we had the three Rs being taught in the general curriculum of the day, which was seen to be appropriate. Then we saw more social experimentation, if you like. We got into a range of extra activities and put greater burdens on schools. Sadly, at the same time, parents were left out in the cold. I make these comments in preface to my remarks on this report because I think we have to see the report, and where our schooling system is at, in the context not just of the last few years but of a generation or two.

As I said, parents were left out in the cold. As time went on, those in the teaching profession found that the load got too heavy. Parents were important after all. Parents were not just nuisances to be sidelined and prevented from being involved in the lives—and, particularly, the education—of their children. The moral self-righteousness that not all but many teachers had in those early years of enthusiasm in the 1970s gave way to a greater realisation that it was a full team and full community approach, that there were, indeed, limitations to what the schools could achieve, and limitations to the role of our teachers, that schools should not just be a social experiment, and that families were important in the overall situation. Gradually, as time has gone on, there has been a lesser expectation of what schools can achieve and of their role in society.

In my own state of South Australia, the dear old South Australian Institute of Teachers will always campaign against anything Liberal, and I understand that. That is the traditional line-up of the political equation. But, in that process, we must be very careful that our schools, as much as possible, be apolitical. Our schools should not be involved too much in what is deigned to be `politically correct' from a particular perspective. There should not be excessive denigration and ridicule of a person's value judgments, religious beliefs or, indeed, political beliefs.

The atmosphere of a greater political tolerance that I hope might be emerging in our education system brings us to the topic of the day—the violence in schools report and the government's response. Violence in schools is, of course, only indicative of the greater violence in the wider community. Children are great mimics. We must remember this when forming any anti-violence policies for children. We must remember that children are just reflecting what they see around them, and they are highly influenced by family, friends, television and other segments of society. In that, of course, we must include the education system, their teachers and their friends and peers at school.

One of the things which this committee found was that there is a lack of concrete evidence about the level of violence and bullying in schools, and a lack of research on the effects of television and media violence. That is a great pity, because it makes it that much harder to formulate policy. Therefore, the committee has recommended that further research and data needs to be collected.

The previous speaker, the member for Bass (Ms Sylvia Smith), made the point that I was going to make about the 18,000 murders that children may view on television in their first 14 or 16 years of life. If it were not for television and other forms of entertainment, how much experience of murders would children have? Of course, we would all say, `Very little or none, except perhaps some information from books and newspapers.' Therefore, clearly, television and movies have a very significant influence on bringing the world of violence into the homes of children. It is that casual exposure that, after a while, we need to understand far more, as a nation.

The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) made some comments about a family TV channel, and maybe the idea has some worthy notions around it. It appears that his idea is called highly impractical, inherently unlikely, and ill-thought through. Be that as it may, the Prime Minister makes a reasonable point that the exposure of the family and of young children to these sorts of programs is something that the nation should be more aware of. We cannot have a slapdash solution thrown at the level of violence which children see through the media, and this is why the committee believes that substantial research should take place.

Yesterday, the Advertiser, my home state newspaper, discussed a national survey on how TV influences children in the United States. More than two-thirds of the 10- to 16-year-olds interviewed claimed that they were influenced by television, and that this influence includes an increase in aggressive behaviour. Although I do not know how comprehensive the survey was, I believe it is time, and the committee believes it is time, that more work was done in Australia on this issue. In the state of South Australia, extensive research has been done on the subject of school bullying. I am currently involved with another inquiry which will expose more about the issue.

Parents, of course, are concerned about the level of violence on television, particularly violence in cartoons and in daytime programs which are especially for children. Violent programs often have their own line of merchandise in toy stores, allowing young children to dress up as their heroes and to re-enact the violent behaviour they have seen on television. Children are simply being exploited in the violence industry, and parents cannot constantly monitor what their children are watching. There is a role for parents to play, and they should be involved to a greater extent and have a greater input into film classifications

We have come to the question of what governments can do. In my earlier comments I touched on the span of history over the last 20 to 25 years. The index shows that we have expended a significant amount of resource into our education system. The previous speaker, the member for Bass, mentioned a school in her electorate which the committee visited. Although I was not able to be involved at that time, I make the point that the committee found that extra funding does not necessarily ensure the success of an anti-violence campaign in schools. The point which I make with reference to that particular school in Tasmania is that a successful anti-violence campaign was put into place without extra funding. It is an issue, but, as the report and the response acknowledges, it is not extreme. However, it is something that we need to understand more about.

The issue of Austudy is raised in the report. I support the comments of the member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) when he said that there is a need for greater recognition of the problems in regional Australia. Regional Australia is going through massive adjustment—more so, I suggest, than most of metropolitan Australia. The people who live in regional Australia are primarily less well-off than people in the metropolitan areas of our country, and I represent one of the electorates in regional Australia. Access to education represents the main opportunity for the people who live in regional Australia to break out of the very severe adjustment process that has been going on out there over the last decade or so. We must, in the Austudy situation, recognise the extra costs and the pressures which these people have. It is now clearly recognised by almost everybody that rural students are the most disadvantaged of all students when it comes to accessing tertiary studies. I believe that the general issue of violence is very much tied up with the necessity for a broader educational understanding of the issue and in giving people greater opportunities. The regional Australian needs to be recognised much more so than was the case in the past.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would just like to deal with a couple of matters that the honourable member for Grey (Mr Wakelin) dealt with. He was talking about the political equation as far as teachers unions were concerned. He never really addressed private schools and the political equation that comes from that side of education, and maybe he should have a look at that some time in his long term.

PARA.TAB: The TV question is certainly one that we need to be conscious of. A lot of violence—a lot of murders—is shown on TV, including in ongoing TV programs. We need to be conscious of the quality of those TV programs. There were murders before TV and you cannot just draw the conclusion that TV causes all the problems. The committee did try to have a look at that, but I do not think there is any research that actually ties that together.

One of the recommendations of the committee was that there probably needs to be a reference, some time in the future, for work to be done in that area. That is very true. It is about quality TV, and I despair a bit in relation to that when I think about all the new channels that might start to enter homes in the future. The quality of all that cable TV could be something that we as a parliament will need to deal with in the future. I think there will be a lot of junk on it and it will come back. I was quite heartened by being able, on another committee, to visit the Australian Children's Television Foundation and see the work that it does in children's programming in this country. That is an excellent foundation, which needs support constantly to continue its good work and to lift the standard of children's TV.

Sticks and stones is the report of a wide-reaching and detailed study of violence in schools and the possible causes and effects, with thoughts on what could be achieved if changes could be made. This government has welcomed the report brought down by the committee, because it has raised the profile of the problem of violence in the schools and the nature of that violence, and will seek state and territory cooperation in developing a national approach in addressing this difficulty.

As we saw in some of the visits the committee made around the country, there are solutions being developed and there are mechanisms in some places that more than address much of the problems of violence and disruption that takes place in the schools. These need to be shared and to be taken out into the broader context of every state and territory. I look forward to hearing more of how that comes out of a state/territory-federal government committee process. But there were also places in which an enormous amount of work needs to be done and I am pleased to see that this government is prepared to pick up most of the recommendations from the committee, including a number of very positive parental programs as recommended.

I was disappointed in the comments that it had not been established that there was a causal link between literacy and violence and therefore there was no link. I think that was a little short-sighted. For sure, if people cannot read and write it does not mean that they are, by definition, violent people, but an inability to communicate, on top of all the other frustrations that life can offer, must lead to expression in other ways. That can mean aggression, diversion, evasion and, if none of those work, violence. We need only to look as far as our gaols to see how many people in there have low literacy skills—a very high percentage.

Illiteracy thus is not a cause of violence but an expression of the causes, which may include such things as violence or assault at home, loss of self-esteem, hopelessness, lack of achievement, lack of parental assistance or understanding—so many things can contribute to a young person not being able to pick up essential skills.

I am happy that the government has responded to the fact that literacy is a problem. There is to be research funding that will investigate how literacy development can be encouraged in the home and the school, and how to deliver that encouragement. There will also be an investigation of different approaches to overcome literacy problems.

I cannot stress strongly enough how important literacy is to an individual. The inability to read and write can be very easily passed through generations if there is no-one in a family who believes in the importance of literacy. Some families only have newspapers and magazines in their homes because their skills are limited. How are their children to go on and understand the need for greater skills in reading and interpreting the written word?

I recently participated in a seminar on youth suicide in my electorate that was set up to learn why so many young people, particularly adolescent boys, had found it necessary to harm themselves or kill themselves. This finding had come out of a study in Tasmania. I have also been reading in the press about how girls are now becoming the high achievers in schools, which is adding to the pressure on young males. We, as a society, are putting pressure on our children that can be so untenable that they can only see the `final' solution—the bottle of barbiturates or the end of a gun.

Since the 1960s, our communities have moved so quickly. Technology is allowing us more time to consider such issues as the environment. There are those of us who can remember marching to ban the bomb—I am sure, Mr Deputy Speaker, that you have been on those marches as well over your long political career—searching our souls after reading Rachel Carson's Silent Spring, and demanding that something be done about our increasingly polluting lifestyle. We were full of doom and gloom: the world would definitely end if we did not do something.

But the thing is that we did do something, and things have improved considerably since those days. Although some of us are still marching on some of those issues, each day something advances the environmental cause so that there is hope, there is change, and there is considerable improvement. What we have forgotten to do is tell our children. They do not believe that anything positive has happened. They still believe the world is about to end and they are hard pushed to do anything about it. They have not had the experience that we have had and cannot see the change.

It is the same in education. Our understanding of the need for flexibility and adaptability, and not to be frightened by change or technology, is gradually occurring. But our kids still do not seem to understand the value of education. It is still too hard to find a job, so they say, `Why should we bother to learn?'

Violence in schools has a base in many paradigms that face our young people every day. How do we equip them better? I still believe that there needs to be an enormous change in the learning process. Teaching must become a communal process. Children should learn that participation in the learning process gives them certain responsibilities and challenges, but that there is a lot of hope and excitement in meeting them and there is a meaningful life after school—even if it does not mean full-time work in a traditional job. Our job as parents and teachers is to make sure that the message gets through. I believe that this report and the government's response to it helps us greatly in moving along the way to achieving a rewarding life for most of our youngsters.

I am very happy to have participated in the inquiry. I certainly learnt a lot from the process and from the different communities around the country that I was able to visit. I am very pleased that the past chairman, the member for Forde and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Housing and Regional Development (Ms Crawford) has now arrived in the chamber. She was a great leader until she moved up the parliamentary ladder to become a parliamentary secretary.

I found the visits to the Northern Territory very expanding. So was the information that was taken, even within my own state and especially at the school of Mayfield in the Bass electorate. The work done there all came back to very strong and good leadership, and a commitment from the whole community, as well as the school community, to achieve goals. I found that in just about every school that I have looked at: where there is good leadership and good support from the community and from parents, you will find good support and a good achievement rate. I look forward to the recommendations that the government has undertaken to implement, and to following those through.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Filing Mr P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to make a contribution to this debate and I would firstly like to acknowledge the opportunity that is provided by these take note debates in this chamber. The member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan) and I are both members of the Standing Committee on Procedure and we were signatories to a minority report on the Main Committee in which we indicated a number of concerns about how this may operate. We still have a number of concerns about aspects of it, in particular about the fact that, apart from occasional visits, there never appear to be instances where ministers are available to sum up the debate. I would have thought that that would have been very important in ensuring that the Main Committee enjoys an equal standing—or, if not equal, certainly a very high standing—as the second chamber of the House of Representatives. So I indicate the concern that a number of us have with that particular aspect of the conduct of this committee.

PARA.TAB: But other than that, the take note debates do provide members of the House with a tremendous opportunity to debate in more detail those reports that are tabled in the House and—as the member opposite, the member for Lyons (Mr Adams) has indicated—the government responses to those reports in a way that, until the creation of the second chamber, was very rarely possible. This is a tremendous opportunity, particularly for backbenchers, to represent the views of their constituents.

Turning to the reports we are referring to today—the report by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training on violence in Australian schools, the Sticks and stones report, and the government's response to it—I would like to make a couple of opening remarks. First of all, bullying and violence in school is nothing new. In fact, those who have taken an interest in literature, particularly some of the literature of the 19th century, would know that bullying and that type of violence was quite endemic in some schools. This was particularly so in the United Kingdom where the public school system was in full force. One looks back at Tom Brown's Schooldays and other similar works which describe a situation where bullying was an integral part of what was a very brutal and unpleasant schooling system, something which the author of that work was very keen to reform.

So, in the first instance, we are dealing with something that has been going on ever since there have been schools and, in particular—because it happens to be a predominantly male problem—in schools with males in them. Of course, I acknowledge that it is a matter that affects both genders, but it particularly has been in the past, and I imagine it is predominantly now a problem among male students.

With the Commonwealth taking an interest in this problem area, there are a number of issues that relate to the Commonwealth's role in the education system. When the member for Fremantle and Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) was minister for education in the Western Australian government, she made a particularly pertinent comment about going to a conference on education in Darwin. She made the comment that, on arrival, she found herself in the position where she was educating hundreds of thousands of students in the Western Australian education system and had three or four advisers with her from her department, while the Commonwealth minister, who educated no students whatsoever, fronted up with about 20 advisers. It was an interesting comment, coming from someone who is now a Commonwealth minister, because it reflects somewhat the attempts by the Commonwealth to make inroads into areas which are essentially state jurisdiction—quite substantially so.

Having read the report and the government's response, I believe that there are a number of areas in which the Commonwealth can provide quite handy assistance. In particular—and I intend to go through the recommendations shortly—the key areas are: collation of information, which obviously the states are not in a position to do on a national basis; and the compilation of that type of information and research, et cetera that is likely to be of assistance to those charged with the responsibility for administering education systems within the states and territories.
I find it somewhat of a contradiction in terms to look at the Commonwealth government's response to the report on page 3 where it states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government also fully endorses the proposition put by the Committee that it is the right combination of action at the school level that can have the most effective impact on addressing violence in our schools.

TAB.EMPHASIS: A division having been called in the House of Representatives—

PARA.EMPHASIS: Sitting suspended from 12.31 p.m. to 12.42 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before we were interrupted, I was referring to page 3 of the government's response. I agree entirely with the committee's finding, and I am pleased to see that the then chairman of the committee, the member for Forde is actually in the chamber. The response says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government also fully endorses the proposition put by the Committee that it is the right combination of action at the school level that can have the most effective impact on addressing violence in our schools. The Committee found that strong leadership by the principal and the teachers working together on the basis of a whole school approach to addressing school level violence has proven to be most effective in achieving changes in student behaviour.

I agree with that entirely, and add that I think it is in fact in the devolution of the administration of schools that we will see a greater level of that grassroots evolution of the whole school approach. I believe that it is when you have the imposition or overlay of central policy decisions or programs that one tends to see the distancing or the separation of that grassroots level of school life and, of course, the objectives that pertain to this particular report.

PARA.TAB: In my own case, I am the elected member for the fastest growing area in the country, with the city of Wanneroo being the fastest growing municipality, outstripping the shire of Albert and having a growth rate of around 12,000 in population per annum, so it is a particularly large and growing area. According to the statistics that are provided from time to time to us as members, the area has the greatest concentration of five- to 15-year-olds in the country.
