Ironically, it also has the greatest concentration of four-bedroom homes, which tends to suggest that this is an area where there are larger families than perhaps there are elsewhere, with children of between five and 15 years of age—with all the responsibility, cares and concerns that parents have in relation to their children's schooling. That is what makes the discussion of the issues arising from the Sticks and stones report of great note.

I was a policeman for nine years before I became a member of parliament, and I can say that the question of bullying at school and violence at school is a very difficult one indeed, particularly in relation to the investigation of particular offences and the treatment of complaints where people have been assaulted. How does one treat a complaint? How does one have the matter dealt with? Is it dealt with in school, or is it something that ought to be automatically dealt with by the police or other authority?

The member for Lyons (Mr Adams), who spoke before me, made the most telling comment that it is a matter of leadership, in particular on the part of the principal, the teachers of the school and, in conjunction with them, the parents. I note that particular remark and agree with it wholeheartedly. Within my particular electorate, with well over 66 schools—and I am talking about major schools—I have found time and time again that where there is good leadership in the school the management of these particular problems tends to be much more effective. Particularly effective is a cooperative leadership among the staff, the principal, the parents and, to a certain extent, the students themselves. A grassroots, whole school approach is required in the context of this problem of violence in schools.

I take a great interest in schools. I have a youth policy advisory committee, which meets monthly and comprises students from years 10, 11 and 12 at the schools, in my area. I have been running that now for five years since becoming the member for Moore, and I have always been very interested at the beginning of each year in putting together the issues which the students think are of most concern to them. We have a straw poll whereby we elicit the types of issues that they and their peers feel most strongly about.

In all of the five years, the question of violence in school has never really arisen, and that somewhat surprises me when I read the report and some of the evidence of the submissions that were received by the committee. That is not to say that it is not a problem; I am just saying that the people on the committee that I run—and I take the trouble to canvass their views—have not once indicated that violence is a particular problem. They have indicated, however, that juvenile crime is a problem, and I think that there is a convergence between the problems of violence and juvenile crime. We know from the evidence around us in the community that the two groups most heavily affected by violence in the community are the young and the aged. In the case of the young, more often than not the violence is perpetrated by one of their own. So it is, I suppose, a peer problem.

I am not entirely sure whether it was identified in the report itself—I think there was some mention of penalties—that penalties in relation to violence, and particularly in relation to assaults, have lagged somewhat. It seems that assaults clearly deserve more stringent and substantial punishment. Because of a decline around the country in punishment being meted out, it seems that people have felt less constrained, less fearful, about the prospects of being detected and then punished as a consequence of their actions.

It is very difficult for schoolteachers these days, and I have a great deal of sympathy for many of them in their job. It is a very difficult role to play in this day and age because of the limited sanctions available to them to be able to deal with a very difficult problem. Mostly it is a problem that involves a very small minority and, as my own students in their committee identified, it is often a small recidivist group—to use a term that is perhaps a current one—who re-offend or commit the same offences over and over again. The students on my committee were very concerned about the unfortunate image young people have of being law-breakers, violent, or in some way less socially responsible. It is an unfortunate image because in 99 per cent of cases that is not the case. In newspapers and on television, we get to see only the extreme examples where some youngsters are identified as being problems to their local community with their antisocial behaviour.

In the report, there is talk in the government's response about the problems associated with computer games and violence on television. There is clear evidence for this. The honourable member for Franklin (Mr Quick) talked about causal effects. There is a very strong causal link between violence on television, in computer games and the young. There is a general ambience of violence in the community these days because of those particular media. There is clear-cut evidence that it affects adults and there is evidence that the young are affected too.

My interest in computer games extended to warning the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Mr Free) in relation to his own inquiry and the legislation in relation to computer games, especially violent computer games. There are a number of loopholes within the legislation that would allow particular types of games—for instance, games with extremely unpleasant sound tracks—to slip through the legislation. I am very concerned about that. In particular, I am concerned that the Internet—this vast new information superhighway, as I think it is somewhat wrongly called—provides an opportunity for young people to have access to a free exchange of violent computer games or other material.

In conclusion, I endorse the areas where the Commonwealth can have a role in education, compilation of statistics and other useful information on a national stage. I do not believe the Commonwealth has a particular role to play in the imposition of programs at the school and state level. I think it is to the Commonwealth's advantage to be an assisting and cooperating influence with the states to ensure that the problem of violence and bullying in schools is overcome. I look forward to the days when my children no longer come home and tell me about instances of bullying and that type of standover-type behaviour in our Australian schools.

TALK.START.PARA: —Violence is the raw exertion of power. It is not confined to gender, race, or any of the other areas of conflict that exist between people. As a general rule, society needs to express how intolerable violence is to it. That can be expressed in a number of ways, as it should be with other intolerable aspects that pervade our society: racism, sexism and so on. But one needs to have some inner strength to be able to stand up to the mob. In politics, we are always faced with this issue as, for example, with the Human Rights (Sexual Conduct) Bill 1994, where the vast majority of the House stood up against minorities and the minority viewpoint, in a conflict situation.

PARA.TAB: My message is that it is an attitude. I will put that in the context of the government's role as referred to by the honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing) in his summation. I think his suggestion that the Commonwealth does not have a role in specific programs has failed. I do not say this with any party political basis; I do it on a personal basis. I concede and bow to the honourable member for Moore's experience of police matters, since he worked for nine years in that job. I worked for 12 years in education as a librarian. I also went to both public and private schools for my schooling, in a heavily ethnic area. I saw the violence first-hand as a young male growing up in a school that was strictly split into four different groups. To be able to go through and mix with all of those groups, to stand up and say something against the violence and violent interaction, is a very hard thing to do. For young Australians in our schools to have the guts to stand up and say, when a fight is beginning to emerge in the playground, `Don't be stupid; pull your head in' there needs to be a backup from the staff and the rest of the pupils in that school.

My attitude as a teacher when a fight erupted was to go in and collar the lot. Every person was treated in the same manner in terms of the punishments dished out by me. That included every observer. I would front a fracas, and everyone who was prepared to stand by, to allow it to take place and not object, I felt was partaking in it. In many instances, two frightened little boys or two frightened little girls would be pushed into a fight by a crowd egging them on. So we need to understand the nature of violence in schools.

We also need to understand the plight of a 13-year-old Vietnamese boy who came to Warrawong High School where I worked. He was in the migrant unit, which was run by Bob King. This boy's family had been shot in front of him. To say that that child—

TALK.START.PARA: —By communists, presumably.

—I did not ask about the politics of it, and I do not think it really mattered. This 13-year-old child had witnessed something that no Australian child, we hope, would witness. That child had been put in the situation of being in a country whose language and customs were foreign to him. That child was also part of a minority, which fortunately in the case of Warrawong High School was not unusual—and I am sorry that the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) is not in the House now, as that school is in his electorate.

PARA.TAB: That Vietnamese child reacted violently to things. Should that child have been treated in the same way as every other child, or should we have tried to understand his unique situation? If the government has an immigration policy, I suggest that it should be backed up with services. We should look at being able to ameliorate the situation. Whether it is government interference or government influence with government programs involved in schools, I commend it. It should be done.

The previous speaker, the honourable member for Moore, as a former police officer, would understand that his job was only as good as the people who were around him. The community has to be behind him. That is what he referred to and I fully agree with his comments about parents and the broader community being involved. However, what I suggest—and that is what the government report seems to be hoping for—is an attitudinal change. When people incite racism for political purposes, or use ethnic groups in a political way to score points, or when people can or cannot speak about something because of fear of racism, I think the whole community, starting with politicians should not callously use those arguments and jump on those bandwagons.

I was a teacher for 12 years. I went through public and private school education in a predominantly ethnic area. I am married to a Croatian who is now an Australian. I have heard my father-in-law called a wog. I understand these things. When we look at violence, we must look at the real causes. The report and the government's response have addressed the basic cause of violence. When the Australian Labor Party addressed the question of the number of women in parliament, it did it by setting targets and goals, achievable things, to make it happen, rather than letting rhetoric suffice.

When we determined that we are going to take on Aboriginal affairs in this area and clean up 200 years of misgivings, we took it on and we led. We find elements in Western Australia and elements in the Northern Territory using base core racism, and we know which political parties they were a part of. When those opposite talk about violence and talk about keeping violence out of schools, I would suggest that what they should do is address the real issue. If they talk about leadership, their own behaviour should be involved. In terms of schools and violence, my experience at Wyrallah High School was that we had a whole staff of people who did everything that they could to promote an optimistic framework, but, as I first said, violence is a raw exertion of power. Schools and police are no different in that they exert power rawly at times, sometimes for very good reasons.

TAB.EMPHASIS: A division having been called in the House of Representatives—

TALK.START.PARA: —I have had 12 years experience as a teacher. From that time as a teacher I would like to pay a compliment to people I worked with. Those that I think found problems and assisted in maintaining old attitudes to violence in schools were those who would not listen, would not consult, would not talk and would not be open.

PARA.TAB: As I said, violence is the raw exertion of power. Before the division I was about to speak of the police, any form of authority, of government itself. We were ringed around here with trucks. We had the potential to use violence as a raw exertion of power and bring in troops. I think there is not one of us here who would not suggest that, if we had brought in troops to move that blockade away, the outcome might have been violence. I think there are many of us who believe that the level of temperature amongst those troops out there might have been such that it would be that way. I am not trying to assert that in any way, but if we exerted raw power that would have been a response such as comes from human beings and animals. I do not think that most of us want to see that within our schools. The point I made before, the point that I have tried to reiterate, is that that needs to be part of our whole life and it needs to be an attitudinal thing. This government needs to take pro-active measures to put aside those levels of hatred in the community.

One would have thought—this is of particular relevance to my family—when I was teaching at Warrawong High School, with every republic of the former Yugoslavia represented, during the conflict when war was raging, that there would have been violence in the school. One would have imagined that that would be the case. It was not the case, because the attitude of the teaching staff there was one of caring and of being non-tolerant of intolerance.

This is the Year of Tolerance, yes. But even if tolerance suggests that I have to tolerate fascist viewpoints I will not. I will speak out against them. I will do all I can to make sure that the other person has the right to express those views but I will not do anything to assist. I will not make media platforms for such people to stand on. I reflect back to the attitudes and the behaviour of us here in this House, because if it starts with anyone, anyone who wants to open their mouth on this subject, it starts with that person. That person should reflect on how they vote and how they talk up or talk down violence.

Mr Kennett, in Victoria, with a passionate plea to the Greek community, touched on something which I felt was extremely worrying in a country such as Australia. The debate about land bills and the divisions that we have just had in relation to the land fund bill, and the divisions that are projected because of that, do nothing for this nation. It is the community, the families that call themselves Australians, who should change the attitude. We lead through what we do. All of us should examine our own lives.

I have taught in schools with Asians who became Australians. I have taught in schools with Australians of all denominations and I have had the pleasure of the company and the pleasure of the insights that that can bring. We can look and count and go through the motions of describing and drawing a picture of this thing—violence in schools. But if we truly wish to do something about taking violence out of schools, we should do it by taking it out of our society.

I will mention two last things. I came in as a schoolteacher when canes were allowed to be used. I refused to use them. I had great difficulties in that environment getting through to students. When I asked one class, `What do I have to do to get you to work?' they called out in unison, `Cane us, sir. Cane us.' They were a product of the environment in which they lived. A lot of those teachers had a hell of a hard time when caning was taken away. But you do not respond to violence with violence.

Sir Julius Chan has had the courage of his convictions in standing up and saying that capital punishment is not on. That man, I suggest, is showing leadership. If we want to look at leadership to take violence away from women, to take violence out of our relationships and our schools, then we look at our own attitudes. It starts with each and every one of us as individuals. I ask that, when we each responsibly put our metal to the earth, when we try to do our job, we do it with the conviction in our hearts that we will do that. Then we will change it. Then the government's response, be it with dollars or programs, will actually have some modicum of chance of winning. I thank the House.
Debate (on motion by Mrs Sullivan) adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 17 October 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Will he provide a list of all dispensations to Civil Aviation Regulations which have been (a) granted, (b) withdrawn or (c) varied by the Civil Aviation Authority since 1 January 1993.
(2) Which of the dispensations referred to in part (1) are current.

(3) With respect to each of the dispensations referred to in part (1), (a) which persons or organisations were affected by the dispensation, (b) what was the term of the dispensation, (c) on what grounds was the dispensation granted, withdrawn or varied and (d) which parties were notified of the dispensation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1)&(2) The Civil Aviation Authority has provided the following answer:

The Civil Aviation Regulations (CARs) do not provide for formal `dispensations' as the term is used in this question. However, the CARs do allow for exemptions to be granted for the handling of special or exceptional circumstances. Exemptions which may be granted include: general and specific exemptions, permissions, authorities and approvals.

The question may also be intended to cover delegations and appointments issued under the Regulations. In this regard, regulation 7 of the CARs provides for the delegation of the powers and functions vested in the Authority and regulation 6 provides for the appointment of `authorised persons'.
A list of the types of exemptions and delegations, which can be granted under the CARs, is attached.

(3) A comprehensive list of the exemptions granted under the CARs would take some time to assemble as, apart from exemptions under CAR 308, the remainder would have to be collated from information held by the Central Office, the Regions, and the District Offices in order to answer the question in the depth that is required.

Regulation 308 of the CARs is a general exemption power. It provides that the Authority may exempt a particular aircraft or specified type or category of aircraft from compliance with specified provisions of the CARs. It may also exempt persons from compliance with such provisions while they are in, or associated with, the operation of such aircraft. An exemption under regulation 308 is a disallowable instrument under section 46A of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901, and is subject to disallowance by the Parliament.

Under certain provisions of the CARs, (for example regulation 89ZD, sub-regulation 139(3) the Authority may exempt persons from compliance with the requirements of a particular CAR. Specific exemptions granted under these provisions are not disallowable instruments.

Under numerous provisions of the CARs, (for example regulations 134, 143, 144, 149 and 156) the Authority may give permission for a person or an aircraft to undertake an activity which would otherwise be unlawful. These permissions operate, in effect, as exemptions.

Certain provisions of the Regulations (for example regulations 137, 151 and 152) provide for the Authority to authorise activities for particular purposes. Again, authorisations of this kind are essential exemptions under another name.

There are provisions of the Regulations (for example sub-regulation 163AA(2), regulation 254) under which the Authority may approve certain activities. These approvals are also exemptions by another name.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Delegations under Regulations 6 and 7 of the CARs Authorised Persons/Delegations

PARA.TAB: Under regulation 6, the Authority may appoint persons to be authorised persons for the purposes of any regulation in which the term `authorised person' occurs (for example regulation 42J, 42M, 42R and 42Y).

Under regulation 7, the Chief Executive Officer of the Civil Aviation Authority may delegate to a person all or any of the Authority's powers and functions under the CARs. In the interest of administrative efficiency, many of the powers and functions referred to in the preceding list have been delegated to officers of the Civil Aviation Authority.

The Chief Executive Officer has also delegated the Authority's powers and functions as necessary, to persons outside the Authority. In particular, the Authority's powers and functions in relation to the testing of flight crew have been extensively delegated to persons outside the Authority.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 31 January 1995:

PARA.TAB: What would be the total cost of upgrading the RAAF air base at Williamtown near Newcastle to international airport capacity.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: The Government announced in the 1990 Budget that it had decided to transfer remaining Commonwealth aerodromes to local authorities and to encourage full local ownership for Aerodrome Local Ownership Plan aerodromes. Negotiations on arrangements were held with each local authority involved in the program.
To facilitate the completion of the program the Commonwealth provided maintenance grants to bring the aerodromes to reasonable order for the current level of traffic.

RAAF Base Williamtown (Newcastle Airport) is owned by the Department of Defence. The civil areas of the airport were the responsibility of the then Department of Transport and Communications, until 18 December 1992 when the Newcastle City Council and the Port Stephens Shire Council agreed to take over responsibility for the civil areas of the airport on long term lease arrangements.
The councils now operate the civil area under a 30 year lease from Department of Defence.

The Federal Government provided a grant of $2,75 million from the Newcastle Economic Development Program for works at the airport at the time of the transfer. This allowed considerable development work at the aerodrome to be carried out. The councils are responsible for the management of the works and the transfer agreement provides that no additional Commonwealth funds will be provided. Any further upgrading of facilities is a matter for the councils and Department of Defence.

Williamtown is not currently designated as an international airport. The Commonwealth is not considering upgrading the RAAF base at Williamtown for international aircraft operations and has therefore not sought cost estimates for such work.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs: Expenditure

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs, upon notice, on 7 February 1995:

PARA.TAB: Has (a) the Minister, (b) any member of the Minister's staff or (c) the Minister's office had any (i) bills or accounts paid on their behalf or (ii) equipment provided by their Department or any other organisation for which the Minister has portfolio responsibility since 13 March 1993; if so in each case, (A) in respect of bills, (I) what sum was paid and (II) for what purpose was the bill or account rendered and (B) in respect of equipment, what are the full details.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: All bills or accounts paid and any equipment provided to me, my staff or my office by the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau (AIDAB) are in accordance with the `Guidelines for providing services to Ministers', pp 154-156 in the Ministers of State of the Commonwealth Parliament `Office Handbook'. No such bills or accounts have been paid by the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research.
I am not prepared to authorise the time and resources needed to provide a fully-itemised list of all accounts or bills paid for and equipment supplied by AIDAB since 13 March 1993.
